data.reading_hint: Watch Ryu as he French kisses this willow tree. Hear him slurping and moaning in ecstasy. Why are you watching this? This is gross. Wait – is this turning you on!? Ew.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>leader</radical> and <radical>Wolverine</radical> take a <radical>slide</radical> to <kanji>Italy</kanji>. Wolverine’s leader is Professor X, and they are both sliding down a big slide to Italy. How fun!
data.meaning_hint: Imagine Wolverine and his leader Professor X going down this slide to Italy. Hear them wooping and cheering as they ride down the slide. Whee~
data.reading_mnemonic: Before Professor X can get off the slide into <kanji>Italy</kanji>, a large <reading>ea</reading>gle (<ja>い</ja>) swoops down and plucks him right out of his wheelchair. That eagle is very strong. Goodbye, Professor X!
data.reading_hint: Imagine this eagle carrying Professor X away from Italy and out over the ocean. You can also remember this reading easily because Italy starts with the letter I. Super simple stuff.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>leader</radical> of a <radical>narwhal</radical> <radical>construction</radical> crew needs all the <kanji>help</kanji> he can get. The narwhals are beginning construction on an underwater city. The leader knows the narwhals are hard construction workers, but they’ll need some help building this city.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine being the narwhal leader and asking others for help. Ask a shark for help. Ask a whale for help. Ask a shrimp for help. Go on, ask.
data.reading_mnemonic: Then you discover a <reading>saw</reading> (<ja>さ</ja>) who would be a great big <kanji>help</kanji>. This saw is very strong and would help you and your narwhal construction team out a lot. You should make use of this saw right away.
data.reading_hint: Imagine using this saw and realizing how big of a help it is. Hear the saw sawing away as you and your fellow narwhals get to work.

data.meaning_mnemonic: This <radical>shrimp</radical> is the exact length of a <kanji>shaku</kanji>, or <kanji>Japanese foot</kanji>. That’s how they came up with this form of measurement. They measured the length of this shrimp and it was the length of a Japanese foot which they deemed the shaku. It’s equal to 30.3cm, very close to one imperial foot.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine this foot long shrimp. It’s pretty big. Imagine it squirming about making a “shaku shaku” sound as it worms about.
data.reading_mnemonic: How is <kanji>shaku</kanji>, the <kanji>Japanese foot</kanji>, pronounced by <reading>Shaq</reading> (<ja>しゃく</ja>) in Japanese? Why Shaq pronounces it shaku. It’s pronounced shaku in both English and Japanese.
data.reading_hint: Imagine Shaq dribbling the shrimp like a basketball, saying “shaku, shaku, shaku” every time he bounces the shrimp.

data.meaning_mnemonic: With a <radical>lid</radical>, you hit yourself in the <radical>mouth</radical> and then <radical>kick</radical> it like a <kanji>pathetic</kanji> loser. You kick the lid, even though it is your fault that you hit yourself in the mouth with it. It’s not the lid’s fault. You don’t need to kick it. You’re being pathetic.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine kicking this lid and with each kick you feel a little bit more pathetic. Your mouth hurts a lot too.
data.reading_mnemonic: You kick the lid one last time and it bounces off the wall and hits you in the <reading>eye</reading> (<ja>あい</ja>). How <kanji>pathetic</kanji>. You are a pathetic mess. You should have never kicked the lid. Now both your eye and your mouth are in pain, you pathetic fool, you.
data.reading_hint: Hold your eye with one hand and your mouth with the other. Feel them pulse in pain as you reflect on how pathetic you are today.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>landslide</radical> came out of your <radical>mouth</radical> and created your <kanji>lips</kanji>. Before the landslide, you just had a wide open mouth hole.
data.meaning_hint: Picture your mouth as an open hole. Now a landslide of something (words? food? something worse?) comes pouring out, and when it's done you have lips. You flap them open and closed to test them out.
data.reading_mnemonic: Now you can use your new <kanji>lips</kanji> to enjoy a nice, cold <reading>Kuchi beer</reading> (<ja>くちびる</ja>). The Kuchi people are Afghan Pashtun nomads. They are lesser known for their amazing beer. And you've never been able to get this delicious beer into your mouth, but now that you have lips you can get it all in there.
data.reading_hint: Imagine wrapping your new lips around the mouth of this Kuchi beer bottle. It's so good! And you aren't spilling any of it!

data.meaning_mnemonic: In the <radical>dirt</radical> there are <radical>flag</radical>s and <radical>horns</radical> lined up with a <radical>lantern</radical> attached to them, making a <kanji>fence</kanji>. It's a little weird looking, but these things are definitely supposed to fence something in.
data.meaning_hint: Can you see the fence made of horns and flags through the light of the lantern?
data.reading_mnemonic: You want to know what this <kanji>fence</kanji> is fencing in, so you take a step closer. As the light from the lantern gets brighter you see that the fence is around a ton of <reading>hay</reading> (<ja>へい</ja>).
data.reading_hint: Picture yourself climbing over this fence (that you're definitely not supposed to climb based on all these flags and horns) and falling into the piles of hay. It's a little scratchy, but otherwise pretty comfy!

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>pig</radical> with <radical>horns</radical> runs into a <radical>building</radical> and makes it fall into the <radical>dirt</radical>. This makes a loud <kanji>crash</kanji> sound. I mean, how could it not? The building literally crashed to the ground when the horned pig attacked it.
data.meaning_hint: Picture a pig with horns crashing into a building and both of them crashing into the dirt. Uh oh, is the pig dead?
data.reading_mnemonic: You're worried about the pig, that was a pretty big <kanji>crash</kanji>, after all. So you yell, "<reading>SOOEY</reading> (<ja>つい</ja>)!" Here pig pig pig. SOOEEEYYY! You know—the universal call for pigs
data.reading_hint: Imagine walking around the crash site yelling "Sooey! Sooey!" over and over. You'll never know if the pig survived the crash if you don't.

data.meaning_mnemonic: With a <radical>woman</radical>'s <radical>mouth</radical>, you have a <kanji>likeness</kanji> to me.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine someone's putting a woman's mouth over your mouth, looking at you, and commenting on your likeness. All it took was this woman's mouth.
data.reading_mnemonic: You have a <kanji>likeness</kanji> to <reading>Jo</reading>-Anne (<ja>じょ</ja>) when you wear that mouth.
data.reading_hint: Jo-Anne popped her mouth off and put it on you. Indeed with that mouth on, you have an extreme likeness to her.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>wave</radical> crashes into a <radical>woman</radical>, transforming her into an <kanji>old woman</kanji>! The wave washes away all of the woman’s makeup, revealing her to be an old woman. The makeup she had on made her appear to be a much younger woman, but once the wave washed away her makeup, she was revealed for the old woman she is.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine a gorgeous woman. Now see her get hit by a wave of water and turn into an old woman. The old woman could still be pretty too, she just looks way old now. Like ancient.
data.reading_mnemonic: In an attempt to distract you from the fact that she is actually an <kanji>old woman</kanji>, the old woman starts to <reading>baa</reading> (<ja>ば</ja>) and act like a sheep. The old woman goes “Baa! Baa!” and hops around on all fours like a sheep.
data.reading_hint: Imagine this old woman acting like a sheep, just saying “baa” over and over and over again. Baa! Baa! Baa!

data.meaning_mnemonic: There is a <radical>mountain</radical> on top of a bunch of <radical>dirt</radical> with a steep <radical>cliff</radical>. This is a bit redundant, but the mountain and the dirt just make the <kanji>cliff</kanji> even bigger and steeper and scarier.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine a cliff. Now add two big helpings of dirt and a mountain to the top. It's still a cliff, it's just more cliff than before.
data.reading_mnemonic: As you’re peering over this tall <kanji>cliff</kanji>, somebody behind you shouts, “Hey, <reading>guy</reading> (<ja>がい</ja>)!” This startles you and you tumble down the cliff. Apparently so did he, because you can hear him saying, "Hey guy! OOF! Are you okay? OOF! Guy? Guy!!!” as you both fall.
data.reading_hint: Imagine falling down this huge cliff and the last words you have to hear before you splat on the ground is someone yelling "Guy" at you over and over. What a way to go.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You take a <radical>towel</radical> and wrap it around your head to keep the <radical>sun</radical> out of your <radical>eye</radical>s. You've invented... the <kanji>hat</kanji>!
data.meaning_hint: A hat is just a piece of cloth or a towel you get to stay on your head. Extra points if it protect your eyes from the sun.
data.reading_mnemonic: People see you wearing this fancy new <kanji>hat</kanji> thing and start asking you to share. You grab all your extra towels, roll them up, and <reading>bow</reading>l (<ja>ぼう</ja>) them down the street toward everyone who asks for one.
data.reading_hint: Imagine bowling with hats. Thankfully, they work as bowling balls just as well as they work as hats. You're so innovative!

data.meaning_mnemonic: That <radical>penguin</radical> over there seems to have a <radical>towel</radical> stuffed with <kanji>cash</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: The towel the cash is in even has a big $ on it like the ones they have at the bank. You follow the penguin into a back alley.
data.reading_mnemonic: Your eyes follow the <kanji>cash</kanji>, and you watch as the penguin stuffs it, towel and all, into a <reading>hay</reading> (<ja>へい</ja>) stack. What a smart penguin, people don't look for cash in hay, they're too busy looking for needles.
data.reading_hint: You wait for the penguin to leave and you run over to the hay stack and stick your hand in. But you don't feel the towel or the cash! Instead you pull out your hand and it's full of hay and needles. Ouch! No fair, gimme that cash!!

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>soul</radical> will only inhabit a <radical>root</radical> if it's holding a <kanji>grudge</kanji>. Have you ever seen a nice, haunted tree? No! They're always angry and trying to get someone back for something.
data.meaning_hint: Don't die with a grudge, or your soul might end up angry and trapped in some roots.
data.reading_mnemonic: If you see one of these <kanji>grudge</kanji> trees, it's probably inhabited by the soul of a <reading>con</reading>dor (<ja>こん</ja>). Humans tend to kill condors and take their trees away to build houses and make toilet paper. So condors hold pretty bad grudges against us, and so their souls end up stuck in a lot of trees.
data.reading_hint: Picture a tree with the soul of a condor with a grudge in it before you. You feel bad about being so wasteful with paper and chopsticks now, huh?

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>soul</radical> <radical>mask</radical> helps you to see the deepest part of anyone's soul. You look around and in all the people you only see <kanji>hate</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: You're supposed to see all the emotions, so why do you only see hate inside everyone?
data.reading_mnemonic: It turns out you're not looking at normal people. You see so much <kanji>hate</kanji> because all the people you're looking at are actually just a group of <reading>zo</reading>mbies (<ja>ぞう</ja>).
data.reading_hint: Zombies are pretty filled with hate, so it makes sense that you'd see a bunch of hate if you used the soul mask on them.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You keep your <radical>tongue</radical> to your <radical>self</radical> to give your <radical>heart</radical> a <kanji>rest</kanji>. You’ve been talking and moving your tongue around all day expressing your feelings. This has tired both your tongue and your heart out, so you stop your tongue moving and decide that you need some self rest time.
data.meaning_hint: It's important to let yourself rest every now and then, you know.
data.reading_mnemonic: What better way to <kanji>rest</kanji> than to eat some cake (<ja>けい</ja>)! No talking necessary. Just enjoy the delicious taste of cake on your tongue and feel your heart let out a sigh of relief.
data.reading_hint: You should rest right now. Take a break from Japanese and go eat some cake. (Just remember to come back when your tongue and heart are sufficiently rested!)

data.meaning_mnemonic: After passing through a <radical>door</radical>, you use a <radical>feather</radical> to put the finishing touches on a <kanji>folding fan</kanji>. The door leads to your folding fan workshop where you make all your folding fans. This folding fan is now complete that you’ve added a feather to it. How lovely it is.
data.meaning_hint: Use this folding fan to fan your face. Feel the refreshing breeze as you admire the gorgeous feather you just added. What a fashionista you’ve become.
data.reading_mnemonic: Your biggest <kanji>folding fan</kanji> customer is a <reading>cen</reading>taur (<ja>せん</ja>). This centaur just loves your folding fans and this one you just made with the feather was for the centaur’s latest order. You go back out your door and deliver this folding fan to the centaur.
data.reading_hint: Imagine handing this newly made folding fan to the centaur. See his face light up with delight as he examines your fine craftsmanship and starts fanning himself with it. Another satisfied customer!

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>door</radical> a <radical>criminal</radical> will get into is the <kanji>front door</kanji>. Now hold on, you may be thinking, wouldn't they go for the back door? No! 99% of home invasions happen when you leave your own front door unlocked!
data.meaning_hint: You better check the locks on your front door right now, because odds are you left it open and didn't even notice. It's the perfect door for a criminal to get access to your home.
data.reading_mnemonic: To protect your <kanji>front door</kanji> from criminals you plan to fill it with <reading>hea</reading>t (<ja>ひ</ja>). Oh yeah, we're gonna Kevin McCallister this.
data.reading_hint: Imagine how you'd heat up your front door. A hot iron? A blow torch? A small fire? It doesn't matter how, as long as the heat makes it all the way through your front door and hurts any criminals trying to get into it.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You have <radical>fingers</radical> in the <radical>thousand</radical>s and while looking up at the <radical>sun</radical> you decide you want to <kanji>insert</kanji> them in there.
data.meaning_hint: Hold your thousand+ fingers up to the sun and imagine inserting them into the sun's super-hot ... s-sun lava. (That's what it is, right? Yeah, let's go with that.)
data.reading_mnemonic: You <kanji>insert</kanji> one finger, it burns up immediately, and its <reading>sou</reading>l (<ja>そう</ja>) comes flying out screaming for a moment before it disappears. Hmm. You insert another finger and as it burns up, another little soul comes out screeching, "WHY WOULD YOU INSERT ME IN THERE!" and is gone.
data.reading_hint: Since you have a thousand fingers too many, you decide to insert them all into the sun and watch as their souls pop out. You listen to the little souls scream at you.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>Viking</radical> moves your <radical>mouth</radical> with his <radical>hand</radical> to <kanji>manipulate</kanji> it. He sticks his hand into your mouth. With the Viking's hand in your mouth, he can make you look like you’re saying anything he wants.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine the Viking having his hand in your mouth. Taste his salty flesh on your tongue. Imagine him manipulating your mouth and your jaw and making it look like you are saying all sorts of funny things.
data.reading_mnemonic: The Viking is manipulating you so that he can <kanji>manipulate</kanji> the <reading>Shou</reading>gun (<ja>しょう</ja>)! You and the Shougun have grown pretty close over the last year or so, and this Viking is going to take advantage!
data.reading_hint: You don't want to manipulate the Shougun, but you can't seem to get the Viking's hand out of your mouth. You frantically imagine all the manipulative things the Viking could get the Shougun to do for him like this.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> hits your <radical>mohawk</radical> and it begins to <kanji>drip</kanji>. The water from the tsunami continues to drip from your mohawk long after the tsunami has passed. There’s a lot of water in your hair now, so it’s probably going to drip for a while.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine having all this tsunami water in your hair. Hear it drip from your mohawk. Drip… drip… drip…
data.reading_mnemonic: Luckily, you’re a self-proclaimed <reading>techie</reading> (<ja>てき</ja>), so you develop a device to stop the <kanji>drip</kanji> drip dripping. This techie device of yours is like a hair dryer helmet. You put it over your mohawk, it does its thing, and your hair is dry! Being a techie sure does have its benefits.
data.reading_hint: Feel the weight of this dryer helmet on your head as you listen to it whirr away. The dripping has finally stopped! Success!

data.meaning_mnemonic: Without a <radical>fire</radical>, you will <radical>lack</radical> the ability to <kanji>cook</kanji> anything. You really need a fire to cook properly. Having a fire will make sure any cooking endeavors you attempt will not fail.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine yourself as you cook with a fire very confidently. Knowing you cannot fail, feel the heat and hear the crackling embers of the fire. Smell the delicious smell of whatever you are cooking as well.
data.reading_mnemonic: You <kanji>cook</kanji> your meal evenly by <reading>swi</reading>nging (<ja>すい</ja>) it back and forth over the fire. You swing it left, you swing it right. You swing it to, you swing it fro. All this swinging ensures a properly cooked meal.
data.reading_hint: Imagine swinging this meal over the fire. Feel the flames licking at your fingertips as you cook this meal by swinging it back and forth over the fire.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>big</radical> <radical>treasure</radical> <radical>treasure</radical> <radical>treasure</radical> <radical>treasure</radical> is <kanji>refreshing</kanji>! Sorry, I can’t say treasure treasure treasure treasure without saying it four times. See? I did it again. Anyway, this big treasure treasure treasure treasure is really refreshing. It’s been a long time since you found a treasure treasure treasure treasure, so finding this big one is really refreshing.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine finding this big treasure treasure treasure treasure and being really refreshed and relieved and happy. This treasure treasure treasure treasure is so big, you’ll be set for life!
data.reading_mnemonic: You’d had a <reading>sour</reading> (<ja>さわ</ja>) taste in your mouth for not being able to find any treasure treasure treasure treasure for such a long time, but now that you found this big one, the sour taste is totally gone and it’s sooooo <kanji>refreshing</kanji>!
data.reading_hint: Imagine the most sour taste you could ever imagine. So super-duper sour! Now imagine that sour taste instantly melting away once you discover this big refreshing treasure treasure treasure treasure. Jackpot!

data.meaning_mnemonic: In the <radical>rice paddy</radical> there is a <radical>forehead</radical> with a <radical>top hat</radical>. It sits atop an area of <kanji>tatami mat</kanji>s.
data.meaning_hint: The meaning you're trying to learn is tatami mat, so focus on the beautiful tatami mats that are strangely in the middle of this rice paddy. On top is a forehead with a top hat. It almost looks like the tatami mats are an altar for this gruesome scene.
data.reading_mnemonic: Who made this creepy <kanji>tatami mat</kanji> altar? It was <reading>Jou</reading>rm (<ja>じょう</ja>) the increasingly concerning farmhand who lives in your village.
data.reading_hint: You saw Jourm setting up the tatami mats a day earlier, but you thought he was just making an area for workers in the field to rest in. Does the forehead with a top hat have anything to do with Jourm? Did he... do something bad?

data.meaning_mnemonic: Rub <radical>charcoal</radical> under your <radical>eye</radical>s if you want to see <kanji>clear</kanji>ly. Sports players also rub charcoal under their eyes to see nice and clear in the bright sun.
data.meaning_hint: You can even rub charcoal in your eyes if you really want to clear them up, but you should probably only do this under the supervision of your eye doctor.
data.reading_mnemonic: You have to have <kanji>clear</kanji> vision because you're about to go out in your <reading>row</reading> (<ja>りょう</ja>) boat. The light off the water shines right into your eyes and you need the charcoal to clear that up for you. Otherwise you'll end up crashing into the shore or going over a waterfall to your death.
data.reading_hint: Imagine how dangerous it would be not to have clear vision while you row around in a row boat. You might even smack yourself in the face with your own oars.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You give <radical>bamboo</radical> to <radical>someone</radical> and they make them into <kanji>chopsticks</kanji>. They are very talented at turning bamboo into bamboo chopsticks. This someone is an expert at their profession.
data.meaning_hint: Watch this person take ordinary bamboo and transform it into chopsticks right before your eyes. Hear the whooshing and whittling sounds as they form the bamboo into chopsticks with expert speed and precision.
data.reading_mnemonic: Now use those <kanji>chopsticks</kanji> to eat some delicious <reading>hash</reading> (<ja>はし</ja>) browns! That's what chopsticks were made for. That's what they're always made for.
data.reading_hint: Imagine trying to pick up hash browns with your chopsticks. They would be really hard to eat if you didn't have these handy eating tools!

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>moon</radical> is the <radical>same</radical> as your <kanji>torso</kanji>. Because you’re so FAT! AHHAHAHAHAHA. I’m sorry, that was mean. But really, if your torso was as big as the moon, you’d have one large torso, y’know?
data.meaning_hint: Imagine if your torso was as large as the moon. You’re a gigantic human. Imagine floating around in space like this. Wooooaaaahhh.
data.reading_mnemonic: Your <kanji>torso</kanji> got so big because of all the <reading>dough</reading>nuts (<ja>どう</ja>) you ate. You ate so many doughnuts that your torso got to be the size of the moon and then you floated away into space with your own gravitational pull and everything. Doughnuts are dangerous things.
data.reading_hint: Imagine how many doughnuts you would have to eat to get your torso this size. Now imagine eating all of those doughnuts. I hope you like doughnuts, because you’re going to be eating a lot of them.

data.meaning_mnemonic: There are <radical>flowers</radical> growing around a <radical>heart</radical> with a <kanji>wick</kanji> sticking out of it. The heart is a sacrifice to the old gods and the life energy bleeds from the burning wick to feed the flowers. The wick burns, releasing the power of the heart which spreads into the ground around the heart causing the flowers to grow.
data.meaning_hint: See this morbid scene. As the wick burns you can smell the smell of burning organs. The flowers are pretty though.
data.reading_mnemonic: Sometimes the <kanji>wick</kanji> burning the heart isn’t enough for the flowers to grow properly and they get thirsty for the blood from your <reading>shin</reading> (<ja>しん</ja>). So, you slice open your shin with a sacrificial knife and drip your blood over the thirsty demon flowers.
data.reading_hint: Imagine slicing your shin with a knife, causing blood to drip on the flowers around the heart with a wick in it. Your shin really hurts from the injury, but the flowers are rejoicing as they’re showered in blood.

data.meaning_mnemonic: An <radical>insect</radical> specializing in <radical>construction</radical> builds a <kanji>rainbow</kanji>. Did you ever wonder where rainbows come from? Construction insects build them. Construction insects build rainbows.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine this insect with a construction hat on, building a rainbow. He works very fast. The resulting rainbow is beautiful!
data.reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>rainbow</kanji> building insect is so <reading>needy</reading> (<ja>にじ</ja>). He is needy because he needs everyone to look at his rainbow and praise him for what he’s done. “Look at my rainbow! Look at how good it is and I am! I’m so needy! Needy for praise and recognition!”
data.reading_hint: Imagine this construction insect being all whiny and needy for attention and stuff. It’s pathetic. Hear him whine and whine because of how needy he is.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Take your <radical>towel</radical> and make it <radical>long</radical>. It has to be longer than that! For this will be your <kanji>notebook</kanji>, which you will write all your notes in.
data.meaning_hint: You are making the towel really long, because it's white and it might be good for writing in. It's going to become your notebook.
data.reading_mnemonic: Inside your long towel <kanji>notebook</kanji> you just write the same name over and over again: "Mrs. <reading>Chou</reading>" (<ja>ちょう</ja>).
data.reading_hint: Something bad is going to happen, and you need to warn everybody. It's her, it's her, it's her. Mrs. Chou, Mrs. Chou, Mrs. Chou!

data.meaning_mnemonic: The type of <radical>insect</radical> that ruins your <radical>writing</radical> is the <kanji>mosquito</kanji>. You're trying to write, when you hear that horrible high-pitched mosquito noise in your ear. You jerk your head and swat and it's gone. But when you look down, there's lines all over what you were writing.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine sitting at your desk writing when a mosquito starts bzzzzing in your ear. You can't ignore it, it's gonna bite you. So you flail around helplessly.
data.reading_mnemonic: That <kanji>mosquito</kanji> noise sounds like it's driving a tiny <reading>ca</reading>r (<ja>か</ja>) in your ear. How are you supposed to write with a bug driving around going bzzz bzzz like a revving car?
data.reading_hint: You can't. You can't write like this. You need to kill the mosquito and its little car too.

data.meaning_mnemonic: There is an <radical>insect</radical> on the <radical>roof</radical> in a <radical>spoon</radical>. It's there for the eating, and it's how you plan to attract a <kanji>snake</kanji> to your roof.
data.meaning_hint: Snakes love insects, especially when they're ready to eat on a spoon. But, snakes don't usually go on top of the roof, so that's why you have to tempt one with an insect in a spoon.
data.reading_mnemonic: Why don't you just bring a <kanji>snake</kanji> up to the roof yourself? Because snakes are <reading>heavy</reading> (<ja>へび</ja>).
data.reading_hint: Especially big snakes. They're really, really hebi.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>shellfish</radical> are worth a <radical>fortune</radical> because you decided to <kanji>paste</kanji> your fortune to the shellfish.
data.meaning_hint: Picture all of your riches, your money, your jewels. They're all pasted directly onto all of your shellfish!
data.reading_mnemonic: You're a little crazy, which is why you decided to use <kanji>paste</kanji> to paste your entire fortune to these shellfish, and as you paste each one you yell out, "<reading>Ha</reading> (<ja>は</ja>)!" Paste.
data.reading_hint: "Ha ha!" Paste paste. "Ha ha ha!!" PASTE PASTE PASTE.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>landslide</radical> <radical>measurement</radical> <kanji>humiliate</kanji>s you. You told everyone you couldn't come to work, that your house had been destroyed and your car was carried away, but then scientists measured the landslide, and it only went a few feet.
data.meaning_hint: Honestly, that's what you get for lying. But it doesn't make it any less humiliating even if you deserve it.
data.reading_mnemonic: Your friends and coworkers <kanji>humiliate</kanji> you more by making <reading>joke</reading>s (<ja>じょく</ja>). "Uh oh, I heard it might rain later, I hope you don't drown in the inch of water that's coming!"
data.reading_hint: Imagine all of the cruel jokes people say to humiliate you. Feel your face burn and your stomach flip.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Cast a <radical>book</radical> in <radical>gold</radical> to make a <kanji>bowl</kanji>. Books can be bent into the shape of a bowl, so then all you have to do is pour gold over it to keep it in that shape and ta-da! A bowl has been born!
data.meaning_hint: Imagine creating this bowl yourself. Try not to burn your fingers with that hot gold.
data.reading_mnemonic: The gold <kanji>bowl</kanji> has a <reading>hatch</reading> (<ja>はち</ja>) attached to it, which used to be the book's back cover. That's fine, you use the hatch as a lid for the bowl!
data.reading_hint: Okay, so this may not be the best bowl. You usually don't need a hatch or this much gold coating. But that's how they used to do it in the old days, so that's good enough for you!

data.meaning_mnemonic: This <radical>gate</radical> makes the <radical>sound</radical> of <kanji>darkness</kanji>. The gate looks like darkness, but it’s even more creepy that it sounds like darkness too.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine this gate making an ominous sound. The sound of darkness. Look deep into the darkness of the gate as you hear the sound it makes. Ouummmmm…
data.reading_mnemonic: You decide to taste the <kanji>darkness</kanji> and discover that it is so <reading>yummy</reading> (<ja>やみ</ja>)! Who knew that darkness was so yummy? Mmm… this darkness tastes so yummy!
data.reading_hint: Take the darkness in your hands. It’s like really dark cotton candy. Imagine eating it and how yummy it is. Keep hearing the sound it’s making as you eat. Yummy!

data.meaning_mnemonic: In this <radical>building</radical> there's a <radical>small</radical> <radical>sun</radical> that's <radical>small</radical>. They keep this small, small sun inside of a <kanji>crevice</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: You wouldn't want to keep a sun out in the open, even if it's small (and small). You'd put it inside something, like a crevice. Imagine walking into the building and seeing the small sun right inside, in a crevice.
data.reading_mnemonic: They keep the sun in the <kanji>crevice</kanji> because this is a place where people <reading>ski</reading> (<ja>すき</ja>).
data.reading_hint: If the sun were out in the open, it'd melt all the snow, making it hard to ski here. So they hide the sun away in a crevice so people can ski.

data.meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Rain</radical> falls off a <radical>tree</radical> and lands in your <radical>eye</radical> where it turns to <kanji>frost</kanji>. It turns to frost because it’s super cold outside and your body is freezing. The rain that fell off the tree turns to frost as soon as it hits your eye.
data.meaning_hint: Feel the rain hit your eye and then crystalize into frost immediately. The rain in your eye is wet, and then very cold as it becomes frost.
data.reading_mnemonic: This whole description is pretty emo. You came up with this whole emo <kanji>frost</kanji> idea because you are a <reading>shemo</reading> (<ja>しも</ja>). An emo who goes by she pronouns.
data.reading_hint: Picture yourself walking proudly, casting your frost gaze at all who you pass. "Wow look at that frosty, cool shemo. She's sooooo cool!" you hear them whisper. (Haha cool, get it? Because you're frosty and also a little sad, which is totally in when you're a teen.)

data.meaning_mnemonic: You’re so hungry that you <radical>eat</radical> a <radical>table</radical> so you won’t <kanji>starve</kanji>. If you don’t eat this table, you will most definitely starve, so you eat the table to stay alive.
data.meaning_hint: You don’t want to starve, do you? Feel your tummy gurgle in pain. You gotta eat this table. Taste the dry wood taste on your tongue as you eat the table and get splinters in your tongue and gums.
data.reading_mnemonic: After you finish the table, you still feel like you might <kanji>starve</kanji> so you decide to eat every <reading>key</reading> (<ja>き</ja>) off your key ring. One by one, you eat each and every key so you don’t starve.
data.reading_hint: Imagine eating every key. Taste the cold metal on your tongue. After you swallow each key, you hear it clink against the other keys already in your tummy. Clink!

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you have nothing to <radical>eat</radical> but your <radical>ego</radical>, you'll <kanji>starve</kanji>. You can't eat it, and your ego is keeping you from accepting actual food or help from other people.
data.meaning_hint: You have to check your ego at the door, because you'll definitely starve otherwise.
data.reading_mnemonic: You <kanji>starve</kanji> (thanks ego) and turn into a <reading>ga</reading>rgoyle (<ja>が</ja>). As your stomach aches, your skin turns gray and you slowly harden into a crouched position.
data.reading_hint: Now your starved body has been moved to the top of a castle, where you scare away people and birds with your loud grumbling stomach and scary face.

data.meaning_mnemonic: In the <radical>mysterious</radical> <radical>rice paddy</radical> there is some <kanji>livestock</kanji>. This livestock is also mysterious because no one knows where it came from. The mysterious livestock are only seen in the mysterious rice paddy. How mysterious indeed.
data.meaning_hint: Examine this mysterious livestock from a distance. Imagine them floating around the mysterious rice paddy like they aren’t even walking. Hear them moo and oink as well.
data.reading_mnemonic: Your favorite member of the mysterious <kanji>livestock</kanji> crew is a little <reading>chick</reading> (<ja>ちく</ja>). The chick is very cute and little. The chick is also very mysterious because it floats about without even flapping its little wings.
data.reading_hint: Look at this chick bobbling about in the air. It looks very ephemeral and other worldly. Still a very cute chick though. You want to pet it.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You drive your <radical>scooter</radical> off this <radical>cliff</radical>, holding your <radical>cross</radical> tight to your chest, at a <kanji>swift</kanji> speed.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine swiftly shooting off the side of the cliff on your scooter, holding the cross for dear life.
data.reading_mnemonic: Because you had such a <kanji>swift</kanji> take off, you didn't notice that your <reading>jean</reading>s (<ja>じん</ja>) were ripped right off your body. Until now.
data.reading_hint: Now you're swiftly shooting through the sky as your jeans flutter down toward the ground behind you. You also feel a swift breeze on all of your downstairs bits now.

data.meaning_mnemonic: An <radical>odd</radical> <radical>horse</radical> is still a <kanji>horse</kanji>. It may look a little funny, but that doesn't change what it is on the inside.
data.meaning_hint: Look at this odd horse. Hear it whinny and neigh like a normal horse. It's not so odd, after all.
data.reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>horse</kanji> is particularly odd because it knows how to use a <reading>key</reading> (<ja>き</ja>). It carries a key around its neck and uses it to get in and out of its stable.
data.reading_hint: Watch the horse take the key in its mouth and open the stable doors. It may be odd, but it sure is resourceful.

data.meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Flowers</radical> are <radical>mysterious</radical>ly appearing in the <radical>rice paddy</radical>. No matter what you do to them, they continue to <kanji>amass</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine yourself spraying poison on these mysterious flowers, but they just double in size, and continue to amass.
data.reading_mnemonic: As the flowers <kanji>amass</kanji> it starts attracting wildlife. Soon thousands of baby <reading>chick</reading>s (<ja>ちく</ja>) are amassing in the rice paddy as well.
data.reading_hint: Feel the wetness of the rice paddy under your feet and the fluffiness of the chicks pressing in on you. Watch the looming, mysterious flowers above you as the chicks smother you.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You see <radical>shrimp</radical> on <radical>ice</radical> at the market in the morning. "I'll get some on the way home" you think to yourself. Later that evening, you see no shrimp, just ice. The supply of shrimp has been <kanji>exhaust</kanji>ed. It's all gone!
data.meaning_hint: Imagine the lack of shrimp on the ice. All you wanted was some delicious shrimp for dinner, but now it's all gone 😩
data.reading_mnemonic: How could the store <kanji>exhaust</kanji> its shrimp supply so quickly? Suddenly you notice the worker behind the fish counter has shrimp stuffed into their <reading>jean</reading>s (<ja>じん</ja>) . Aha! The culprit!
data.reading_hint: Imagine the worker's jeans and how gross they are with all those shrimp stuffed into them. Yuck!

data.meaning_mnemonic: You use a <radical>cleat</radical> to climb a <radical>tree</radical> and your <radical>hair</radical> gets the same <kanji>coloring</kanji> as the foliage because your hair is like a chameleon. The coloring of your hair changes to whatever color is around you, so you use your cleats to climb trees to make your hair turn green and brown, and in the fall, yellow and orange and red!
data.meaning_hint: Imagine digging your cleats into the bark of the tree until you get high enough for your hair to start coloring itself tree colors. It might be a lot of work, but it's worth it.
data.reading_mnemonic: This cool <kanji>coloring</kanji> can only happen because you turned yourself into a <reading>cy</reading>borg (<ja>さい</ja>). Your hair and scalp are now made of high tech parts, not human ones.
data.reading_hint: You couldn't take the pain of losing your cyborg, so you've become one. Your robo-hair can change its coloring, but soon you'll be even more cyborg-y than before!

data.meaning_mnemonic: When your <radical>soul</radical> has an <radical>idea</radical> it's just a <kanji>recollection</kanji> of something you already know. Only your brain can have original ideas, so when your soul tries to come up with one, it's just a recollection of something you thought before now.
data.meaning_hint: When you have a recollection of some idea or thing in the past, it's just your soul saying, hey remember this? Let's not forget this.
data.reading_mnemonic: Your soul is sending you a <kanji>recollection</kanji> right now of... your past life as a farmer in <reading>Ok</reading>lahoma (<ja>おく</ja>). You see yourself farming and sweating and living a wonderful life. Hmm, maybe you should move to Oklahoma and live the simple life again.
data.reading_hint: Imagine recollecting a past life in Oklahoma. Life was simple and nice. You should consider taking this as a sign to move there again!

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>tsunami</radical> hits your <radical>form</radical> and you begin to <kanji>melt</kanji>. You are a witch and water makes you melt. The tsunami is a lot of water, so once it touches your form, you begin to melt.
data.meaning_hint: Feel the water from the tsunami crashing into your form. Feel the water on your body as your form begins to melt. I’m melting! I’m mellltiinnnggg!
data.reading_mnemonic: The only way to reverse the <kanji>melt</kanji> process is to eat some <reading>yo</reading>gurt (<ja>よう</ja>). The yogurt counteracts the melting from the water and your form will become whole again. Quick, eat some yogurt!
data.reading_hint: Feel the melt begin to reverse as you eat your yogurt. Taste the yogurt on your tongue as your form begins to solidify once again.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You take a <radical>rake</radical> in for a <radical>measurement</radical> but it is <kanji>resistant</kanji>. The rake doesn’t want to have its measurements taken. The rake is resistant to have any measurement taken because it feels inferior to the other rakes and doesn’t want to be embarrassed if it ends up being smaller than the others.
data.meaning_hint: Try and move this rake over to the measurement table. It is resistant so you have a hard time moving it. Imagine the rake struggling and resisting endlessly.
data.reading_mnemonic: Because the rake is persistently <kanji>resistant</kanji>, you eventually tie it to the table with your neck <reading>tie</reading> (<ja>たい</ja>). The tie won’t hold for long, so you need to take each measurement quickly.
data.reading_hint: See yourself tying the tie around the rake and attaching it to the measurement table. The rake is still jostling around, but the tie keeps it from moving about too terribly much.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>foot</radical>, as your <radical>mama</radical> says, was given the <radical>task</radical> to <kanji>dance</kanji>. Shake those two foots your mama gave you and dance dance dance!
data.meaning_hint: Picture your mama asking you to dance. The two of you pick up and kick your feet to dance, spinning 'round and 'round.
data.reading_mnemonic: You both <kanji>dance</kanji> so much that you develop an <reading>odo</reading>r (<ja>おど</ja>). Not just any odor, an odor particular to stinky dancing feet.
data.reading_hint: Lean down and take a big whiff of your dancing feet. The odor is... HORRIBLE! AHGH!

data.meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>servant</radical> uses a <radical>stool</radical> to break open <radical>shellfish</radical>. You know how much work shucking shellfish is so this method is really <kanji>clever</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: You knew hiring this servant was a good idea. "Clever girl," you say, as your servant sits on some shellfish again.
data.reading_mnemonic: "More <kanji>clever</kanji> than you!" your servant yells, tearing off his wig. "It is I, <reading>Ken</reading> (<ja>けん</ja>) the samurai. I saw you take this shellfish from my master's lands."
data.reading_hint: You thought you were being so clever, taking shellfish from someone else. It turns out, there is a cost for being shellfish.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>sunlight</radical> shines on your <radical>forehead</radical> in your <radical>car</radical> with a great <kanji>radiance</kanji>. The car you are in is a convertible, so the sunlight shines right onto your big bald forehead. The sun has a pretty powerful radiance as it is, but the sheen from the sunlight hitting your forehead is the most powerful radiance ever witnessed by man.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine this radiance emanating from your shiny dome. The radiance is blinding!
data.reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>radiance</kanji> is the <reading>key</reading> (<ja>き</ja>) to powering your car. Your car runs on reflected solar energy, and the radiance coming from your forehead is the most powerful source of radiant sunlight ever imagined. Your forehead is a perfect key for this car.
data.reading_hint: Point your shiny forehead, filled with radiance, at your car. Hear the engine start and jump to life as you power it with the reflected sunlight from your forehead.

data.meaning_mnemonic: There's <radical>power</radical>, <radical>power</radical>, and <radical>power</radical> stacked on top of the <radical>moon</radical>, <kanji>threaten</kanji>ing to bring it down!
data.meaning_hint: The moon actually looks like it wants to threaten you now too. It seems to have grown a big, smiling, angry mouth and it's way closer to you than you've ever seen it. All that power is radiating out of it and down towards you, threateningly.
data.reading_mnemonic: This extra power-filled moon is now trying to <kanji>threaten</kanji> the safety of <ja><reading>きょう</reading>と</ja>. All of <ja>きょうと</ja> is shaking and getting dark as the moon comes closer and closer.
data.reading_hint: Picture the powerful moon, threatening to crush <ja>きょうと</ja> and all its residents. If only a small green boy could turn back time and save everyone from this powerful moon!

data.meaning_mnemonic: This <radical>canopy</radical> of <radical>tree</radical>s isn't actually a canopy of trees at all. When you look closely, you see these trees are actually giant stalks of <kanji>hemp</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Wow, these hemp plants are so big that they look like trees. But, despite their size they're still just hemp.
data.reading_mnemonic: Who planted all this <kanji>hemp</kanji>? Your <reading>ma</reading>ma (<ja>ま</ja>) did.
data.reading_hint: Your mama knew that you were going to like hemp in the future, so she planted these hemp plants for you. What a great mama.

data.meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Fire</radical> you use to light up the <radical>street</radical> needs to go in a <kanji>lamp</kanji>. Campfires, matches? No, none of those work. You need bright, safe lamps to keep the street nice at night.
data.meaning_hint: Picture these lamps lining the street, with their little fires burning brightly. Nowadays we don't have real fire in them, we use electricity!
data.reading_mnemonic: These street <kanji>lamp</kanji>s were first used in <ja><reading>とう</reading>きょう</ja>. It was the most advanced city after all. And more people were out at night in <ja>とうきょう</ja> than anywhere else in Japan. So they needed lamps to light things up!
data.reading_hint: Picture <ja>とうきょう</ja>, not lit up by all of the electricity, signs, shops, and things that light up its streets today, but by old-fashioned fire lamps!

data.meaning_mnemonic: Having a foul <radical>mouth</radical> and <radical>horns</radical> will prevent you from getting into <radical>Heaven</radical> where you would <kanji>blossom</kanji> into an angel. If you have horns, you are not meant for Heaven and will not blossom there. To blossom in Heaven, you must not have horns or a foul mouth.
data.meaning_hint: Swear like a sailor as you imagine yourself with some horns. You’re not going to blossom in Heaven. You’re going to blossom in Hell and become a demon.
data.reading_mnemonic: You don’t want to <kanji>blossom</kanji> into a demon so you <reading>saw</reading> (<ja>さ</ja>) off your horns with a saw. If you saw off your horns, maybe you can beg for forgiveness and have your foul mouth forgiven.
data.reading_hint: Imagine taking a saw to your horns and sawing them off. Hear the reverberation of the saw in your skull as you painfully saw off your horns.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You need to put a <radical>clown</radical> in the <radical>dirt</radical> if you want to <kanji>cultivate</kanji> good crops there. Clowns act as a natural fertilizer, and this will make it super easy to cultivate any crops you could ever want in this dirt. Isn't nature amazing?
data.meaning_hint: Imagine burying a dead clown in the dirt and then planting some seeds on top. It's worth it, you think, if it helps cultivate your crops.
data.reading_mnemonic: Before you can start this whole <kanji>cultivation</kanji> process however, you have to say <reading>bye</reading> (<ja>ばい</ja>) to the clown. Say bye to him, then bash his head in, and drop him in the dirt.
data.reading_hint: Saying bye is polite. Never forget to say bye, even in the middle of a cold-blooded clown murder.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you try to put your <radical>soul</radical> into <radical>every</radical>thing, you'll <kanji>regret</kanji> it. It's not so much that putting your soul into things is bad, but every single thing? You'll burn out immediately. You won't be able to be good at any of those things. And you'll regret all the time you wasted trying to be the best at everything.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine if you went full force into everything you've ever even thought of doing. Imagine how burnt out your soul would be. Imagine all the regret you'd have that you didn't just stick to one thing and do it well.
data.reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>regret</kanji> is too strong for you to ignore, so you decide to drop everything but <reading>ka</reading>yaking (<ja>かい</ja>). If there's one thing you refuse to regret, it's your bright orange kayak and all the friends you made at kayaking club.
data.reading_hint: Throw everything you regret away. Only kayak from now on.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>moon</radical> has a lot of <radical>power</radical> that is <radical>power</radical> it gets from the <radical>power</radical> of every <kanji>armpit</kanji> of every human on earth! Why does your armpit smell? It’s because the moon is draining the power from your armpit. The moon saps power from your armpit and that power is sucked up into the sky where the moon collects the power for its own devices.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine an aura of stinky power traveling from your armpit to the moon. Feel the power leaving you as the moon saps your power through your armpits.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a pretty <reading>wacky</reading> (<ja>わき</ja>) <kanji>armpit</kanji> image isn’t it? Seeing lines of power traveling from your armpit to the moon. Definitely wacky. Have you ever seen something this wacky in real life?
data.reading_hint: Imagine this whole scene again but keep in mind how wacky it all really is. The moon sapping power from you through your armpits? So wacky.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>scooter</radical> with <radical>horns</radical> with a <radical>pig</radical> riding on it will be able to <kanji>accomplish</kanji> anything.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine the pig scooting around. It is able to accomplish anything you can imagine (so go nuts with your imagination).
data.reading_mnemonic: It was even able to successfully <kanji>accomplish</kanji> a feat that involved it jumping its scooter right into a <reading>swi</reading>ng (<ja>すい</ja>), swinging back and forth, then jumping off.
data.reading_hint: Perhaps it even takes the swing all the way around in a full 360 degree rotation. This horned scooter riding pig can truly accomplish anything.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If the <radical>king</radical> gives you a <radical>knife</radical> you become part of his <kanji>squad</kanji>. Every king has a knife squad or two protecting him and making sure his subjects keep in line.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine if you were given a knife and allowed into the king's squad. Would you let the power corrupt you?
data.reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>squad</kanji> is led by <reading>Han</reading> (<ja>はん</ja>) Solo, so it's basically a 50/50 shot that the king is gonna die.
data.reading_hint: I'm not saying Han Solo is a bad squad leader, but his track record isn't the greatest. I mean, best case scenario the king gets stabbed in the arm and they manage to win.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> <radical>surplus</radical> will cover all the <radical>dirt</radical> with <kanji>paint</kanji>. The surplus of tsunamis will strike the paint factories first (everyone knows paint factories are built close to the ocean). Then the paint will flow over all the dirt and paint it a ton of rainbow colors.
data.meaning_hint: Picture all of the different colors of paint being swept along by tsunami after tsunami, painting the dirt as it goes.
data.reading_mnemonic: You touch the <kanji>paint</kanji> in the dirt with your <reading>toe</reading> (<ja>と</ja>) to see if it's still wet. It is. The paint is still very wet and now your toe looks like a tiny rainbow.
data.reading_hint: Imagine dipping each of your toes into the paint-dirt, one by one, to paint each of them a different color. Why are you doing this?

data.meaning_mnemonic: You have a <radical>surplus</radical> of <radical>ladle</radical>s laid out <kanji>diagonally</kanji> in front of you. Why are they diagonal? And why do you have so many ladles? Why the surplus? Hang on, we'll get there.
data.meaning_hint: Look at all these ladles lying diagonally in front of you. Pick them up. Feel the wood grain. Wonder why you have so many.
data.reading_mnemonic: In front of this <kanji>diagonal</kanji> pattern is a <reading>sha</reading>man (<ja>しゃ</ja>) who is currently staring at you. You slowly reach down and turn one of the ladles around, diagonally, and look back up. The shaman's eyes are wide, and now they're scribbling on in a notebook.
data.reading_hint: Uh oh, is this one of those weird tests where they find out if you're the chosen one or some old scholar reincarnated? Who knew laying ladles at diagonal angles could reveal this kinda stuff?!

data.meaning_mnemonic: Give a <radical>district</radical> <radical>weapon</radical>s and it will <kanji>assault</kanji> other districts.
data.meaning_hint: Picture two districts using weapons to assault each other from above. Like in a video game, with little arrows showing you where they're launching each assault.
data.reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>assault</kanji> is all the <ja><reading>王</reading></ja>'s (<ja>おう</ja>) fault. The <ja>王</ja> gave the weapons to each of the districts on purpose so this would happen.
data.reading_hint: Picture the districts assaulting each other from above again, and then pan out and see the <ja>王</ja> standing above, watching it all happen. He's cackling.

data.meaning_mnemonic: On a <radical>cliff</radical>, the <radical>pope</radical> is holding a <kanji>shield</kanji>. The pope is near the edge of the cliff and is using the shield to fend off demons. The demons want to shove the pope off the cliff, but the pope is using his holy shield of popery to fend them off.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine the shield glowing brightly as hymns play in the background. The demons try to get close to the pope to shove him off the cliff but the holy shield is too bright and popey.
data.reading_mnemonic: The light of the pope's <kanji>shield</kanji> begins to fade. The shield's holy power is waning! Just as the demons are about to push him off the cliff, the sun begins to rise. That's right! It's <reading>June</reading> (<ja>じゅん</ja>) and summer has just begun. The pope's shield reflects the power of June's bright sun into the eyes of the demons, casting them off the cliff behind him and back into hell!
data.reading_hint: This pope would have been in a lot of trouble if June's summer sun hadn't risen at just the right moment. His shield would have become useless and he might have been shoved off the cliff if it was a less sunny month.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You need to feed this <radical>grain</radical> to a <radical>flower</radical> wearing <radical>turkey</radical> on a <radical>stool</radical> so you start the <kanji>harvest</kanji>. Grains don't pick themselves, you have to harvest them.
data.meaning_hint: Picture this fat turkey with flowers on its head, sitting on a stool. It's gobbling for grains and you need to be the one who harvests them.
data.reading_mnemonic: You're just starting to <kanji>harvest</kanji> the grains when an angry <reading>cock</reading> (<ja>かく</ja>) shows up! He's mad because these are his grains and you're about to harvest them and feed them to a turkey instead of him.
data.reading_hint: Imagine an angry cock chasing you around as you try to harvest grain. He keeps pecking you, ouch!

data.meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the radical are the same, so remembering the meaning of this kanji is as simple as making sure you know the radical for <radical>towel</radical> first! If you know the radical, you know this kanji means <kanji>towel</kanji> as well.
data.meaning_hint: Make sure you know those radicals, yo!
data.reading_mnemonic: You know who loves <kanji>towel</kanji>s? The <reading>Kin</reading>g (<ja>きん</ja>) of England. He loves towels so much that he went around and put <ja>きん</ja> on every towel in the land, so you think of him whenever you use one.
data.reading_hint: Go into your bathroom or your linen closet right now. Look at your towels. Look for the small <ja>きん</ja> hidden there.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>horse</radical> who can write a <radical>paragraph</radical> gets to be a <kanji>chess piece</kanji>. Only the most erudite of horses gets selected to be a chess piece. The knight’s chess piece is represented by a horse, and for a horse to earn this honor, they must first write a paragraph explaining why they deserve the honor.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine a horse trying to write a paragraph about why it deserves to be a chess piece. See the horse struggle with his hooves to write out a paragraph as he neighs in nervous frustration.
data.reading_mnemonic: Upon being told that he will never be a <kanji>chess piece</kanji>, the horse slips into a <reading>coma</reading> (<ja>こま</ja>). The horse will never awaken from this coma as he knows he will never fulfill his dream of becoming a chess piece, so he has nothing to live for.
data.reading_hint: See this horse in its coma. You feel bad that it will never be able to be a chess piece, but this is a bit dramatic.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You <radical>stop</radical> a <radical>spoon</radical> from moving by tying it with <radical>thread</radical> that's <kanji>purple</kanji>. The spoon wouldn't stop moving around, so you had to use your favorite purple thread to make it stop. It's the strongest thread you have.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine tying this spoon down with thread that's a color other than purple. Ah, the thread snaps. Darn, you better use your extra strong purple thread (the best color for strength!).
data.reading_mnemonic: You have to use all of your purple thread, and now you need more. You go into the back yard and call over your <kanji>purple</kanji> <reading>shee</reading>p (<ja>し</ja>).
data.reading_hint: Oh, did you think purple things were made with dye? No no, purple is a special color. You have to find unique purple sheep to make purple thread and clothes.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>fingers</radical> give you a good <radical>reason</radical> to <kanji>pluck</kanji> things. You pluck flowers out of the ground. You pluck a cat out of a tree. Why? Because you have fingers! That's your reason.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine using your fingers to pluck grapes and apples and other things, maybe non-fruit things.
data.reading_mnemonic: Now that you have a reason to <kanji>pluck</kanji> things (you have fingers, after all) you decide you want to pluck all the fur off of <reading>Chew</reading>bacca (<ja>ちゅう</ja>). He is very furry, and you want to know what he looks like under there.
data.reading_hint: What reason could you have for wanting to pluck the fur off Chewbacca? Because you have fingers! So why not?!

data.meaning_mnemonic: With your <radical>fingers</radical> under an <radical>axe</radical>, you <radical>say</radical> a <kanji>vow</kanji>. A vow is a sacred promise, so you have to be really serious when you say one. That's why you do it with an axe hovering above your fingers—it's a reminder that if you break this vow your fingers are gonna get chopped off.
data.meaning_hint: Picture the axe hovering above your fingers. Now say the vow. But don't lie. The axe knows when you're lying.
data.reading_mnemonic: When you finish your <kanji>vow</kanji>, you take out your holy blue <reading>sa</reading>ber (<ja>せい</ja>) and cut the axe in half! You know you're never going to break your vow, and if you do, you'll use your own saber to cut off your fingers.
data.reading_hint: Imagine what it would be like to slice off your own fingers with the saber you've carried for so long. You better not break that vow.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>soul</radical> connects to <radical>five</radical> different <radical>mouths</radical>, enhancing your <kanji>comprehension</kanji>. You can easily comprehend what each of those souls belonging to those mouths wants and feels deep down.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine being able to comprehend everything about not one, but five other people. Deep down you can feel everything they think and feel.
data.reading_mnemonic: Your <kanji>comprehension</kanji> is the strongest with the fifth mouth, belonging to <reading>Go</reading>dzilla (<ja>ご</ja>). You finally get why he wants to destroy buildings and cities.
data.reading_hint: Your comprehension of Godzilla reveals so much: he's warning the Japanese people about the use of new technology and warfare and experimentation. He just wants everyone to be able to comprehend these new, seemingly incomprehensible things!

data.meaning_mnemonic: You use your <radical>fingers</radical> and a <radical>stone</radical> to begin <kanji>cultivation</kanji> of the land. You use your fingers to till the soil, the stone to flatten the ground, and you carefully poke the seeds into the dirt and then use the stone to smash them further down.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine being in a field, using your fingers and a stone to cultivate the whole thing, by hand.
data.reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Cultivation</kanji> is suddenly halted because a <reading>tack</reading> (<ja>たく</ja>) sticks into your finger. You pull the tack out, throw it away and start cultivation again when... ouch! There's another tack. This field is full of tacks!
data.reading_hint: Now cultivation is going to involve getting all the tacks out of here, preferably with the stone and not your fingers, so they don't get stuck anymore.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You run your <radical>fingers</radical> along the words of a  <radical>paragraph</radical>. You are learning about the law because you plan to <kanji>arrest</kanji> somebody.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine reading the paragraph very slowly. You find your answer. It looks like you'll be able to arrest that person...
data.reading_mnemonic: Who do you want to <kanji>arrest</kanji>? You want to arrest <ja><reading>こう</reading>いち</ja>. Even though he's started wars, created a religion, and trapped a child in a cavity, it's going to be tricky to arrest him because he's the emperor now.
data.reading_hint: Still, according to this paragraph you're running your fingers through, you can do it. You can arrest <ja>こういち</ja>.

data.meaning_mnemonic: There’s a <radical>stone</radical>, a <radical>tree</radical>, another <radical>tree</radical>, and a <radical>coat rack</radical>. That stone and two trees will make the perfect <kanji>foundation</kanji> for a house to put that coat rack in! This stone is flat and heavy and both of the trees are flexible and durable.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine making a foundation with the stone and the two trees so you’ll have a place for your coat rack. Feel the wood grain and cold stone against your skin as you move them around to form the foundation.
data.reading_mnemonic: After you finish the <kanji>foundation</kanji>, the only step that's left is to wash the entire thing with <reading>so</reading>ap (<ja>そ</ja>).
data.reading_hint: Imagine getting on your hands and knees, rubbing a bar of soap all over the foundation you built. The soap gets into all the nooks and crannies in the wood and stone. Now if a coat falls off the coat rack onto the floor, you just add water and poof! Clean!

data.meaning_mnemonic: On the <radical>roof</radical> there's some type of <radical>turkey</radical> <radical>bird</radical>, but thinner and longer. You look closer and realize it's a <kanji>crane</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Picture the beautiful black and white crane dancing gracefully on the roof. Now that you know what it is, you feel a little bad about calling it a turkey bird.
data.reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>crane</kanji> leans down toward you from its roof perch and squawks, "<reading>Too ru</reading>de (<ja>つる</ja>)!" You're shocked! You didn't know the crane could speak English, but even worse, it knew you called it a turkey bird.
data.reading_hint: The crane keeps saying you're too rude whenever other people come close so they know what kind of person you are. Yikes, you really shouldn't have gotten on this crane's bad side.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Take your greatest <radical>treasure</radical>, hold a <radical>knife</radical> nice and close to it, and <kanji>prune</kanji> away all the weak and dead bits.
data.meaning_hint: All treasures need to be taken care of, no matter what they are. Prune away anything that isn't necessary.
data.reading_mnemonic: Currently, you want to <kanji>prune</kanji> your greatest treasure: your <reading>ca</reading>r (<ja>か</ja>). Your car is made of wood, and it keeps trying to grow new buds and branches, so you have to prune them off.
data.reading_hint: You want your car to be small and sleek, not a giant truck, so you have to carefully prune it when it grows too much.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>hill</radical> <radical>knife</radical> is the most <kanji>sturdy</kanji> knife you can find.
data.meaning_hint: The reason hill knives are so sturdy is because they are shaped like hills. Very wide, very thick, not so long. So, they don't break and are more sturdy.
data.reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>sturdy</kanji> (but strangely shaped) knife is used by <ja><reading>ごう</reading>いち</ja>.
data.reading_hint: Imagine <ja>ごういち</ja> rolling the knife back and forth over various things to cut them. "I love my sturdy hill knife," he says.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>mouth</radical> of that <radical>turkey</radical> is <kanji>solely</kanji> his. It’s very unique, so that mouth could belong to no other turkey but him. That mouth is solely his.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine what makes this turkey’s mouth so unique. This beak is solely his. It belongs to no other. This turkey is the only turkey with a mouth like his.
data.reading_mnemonic: You traveled a long way to see this turkey and the mouth that is <kanji>solely</kanji> his but you missed your exit on the highway and you have to hang a <reading>U-ey</reading> (<ja>ゆい</ja>). You know what hang a U-ey means, right? It’s making a U-turn. Well, you have to hang a U-ey on the highway so you can get off at the right spot to see this turkey and the mouth that is solely his.
data.reading_hint: Imagine hanging a U-ey on the highway. Hear your tires screech as you turn around and get off where you’re supposed to.

data.meaning_mnemonic: On the <radical>dirt</radical> there is a <radical>lid</radical> trying to cover the number of <radical>times</radical> the <radical>dawn</radical> has risen here. You walk over and pull the lid off and the whole thing transforms into a <kanji>podium</kanji>. A podium for the dawn to tell you how many times it's risen over this dirt over and over again. It just keeps going and you realize the lid was here because this dang podium can't seem to keep a lid on it! (Get it? Figure of speech!)
data.meaning_hint: This kanji also just... really looks like a podium right? With a guy wearing a graduation cap, pointing toward you, in the crowd.
data.reading_mnemonic: You listen to what the <kanji>podium</kanji> has to say for so long you finally can't help but ask, "Who are you?" "I'm the <reading>dawn</reading> (<ja>だん</ja>), of course!" And this is my podium where I spread the good news about the dawn!
data.reading_hint: I guess that makes sense. This podium is by the dawn for the dawn.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You give a <radical>flag</radical> and a <radical>spoon</radical> to a <kanji>nun</kanji> as an offering. You give her this flag and this spoon because they are very precious to you and you want to show the nun how serious you are about repenting for your evil deeds.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine handing the nun your country’s flag. And also a spoon that is very valuable to you. Imagine getting down on one knee as you do so.
data.reading_mnemonic: You’re getting down on one <reading>knee</reading> (<ja>に</ja>) as you present the flag and the spoon to the <kanji>nun</kanji>. The nun accepts your offer and takes your flag and spoon from you. Your soul is saved!
data.reading_hint: Feel your knee digging into the cold floor as you present your offerings to the nun. You feel slightly sad as she takes your precious belongings from you.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Bite a <radical>tree</radical>'s <radical>root</radical> with your <radical>fang</radical> to get an <kanji>approximation</kanji> on its age. It won't be exact, this isn't scientific or anything, but it will be pretty close.
data.meaning_hint: Once you have an approximation on the age, you'll be able to come up with an approximation on how much it's worth too.
data.reading_mnemonic: As you're recording your <kanji>approximation</kanji> down,  somebody comes up and shouts, “Hey <reading>guy</reading> (<ja>がい</ja>)! I’ll give you $10,000 for that tree there, guy!” This guy must be crazy. That’s much more than your approximation of the value of this thing. But you sell it to the guy anyway.
data.reading_hint: The guy is trying to look at your approximation now, while calling YOU "guy" over and over, and you just want him to buy it and leave you alone!

data.meaning_mnemonic: In the event of a <radical>tsunami</radical>, <radical>Wolverine</radical>, your <radical>forehead</radical>, and a <radical>stool</radical> will all be <kanji>immersed</kanji> in it. You will become immersed in the tsunami after it hits because tsunamis are gigantic and bring a lot of water. Now you and your forehead are immersed in the tsunami along with Wolverine and a stool.
data.meaning_hint: Feel the water all around you as you become immersed in this tsunami. See Wolverine trying to swim his way to the top as you watch the stool floating about in the water.
data.reading_mnemonic: Still <kanji>immersed</kanji>, the stool floats over and hits you in the <reading>shin</reading> (<ja>しん</ja>). The tsunami gave the stool a good push and while it was fully immersed, it ran into your shin. It really hurts.
data.reading_hint: Hear the stool crack against your shin and feel the pain erupt through your leg. You try to scream but you’re under water so you just get a big mouthful of tsunami.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> and a couple <radical>fire</radical>s run into each other. They cancel each other out completely, and the remainder left behind is a <kanji>faint</kanji> remnant of what was once there.
data.meaning_hint: You go to see if you can find any remainder of the fire + tsunami battle. You can, but it's so faint.
data.reading_mnemonic: Just like the tsunami and fire canceling each other out, leaving a <kanji>faint</kanji> remainder of what was, your <reading>tan</reading> (<ja>たん</ja>) is extremely faint as well.
data.reading_hint: Look at your skin. It has such a faint tint.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If <radical>someone</radical> wants to <radical>boil</radical>, you let them <kanji>boil</kanji>!
data.meaning_hint: There's someone in your face yelling about how they want to boil! You yell back, "Okay, if you want to boil, just boil!"
data.reading_mnemonic: Welp, the pot is at a rolling <kanji>boil</kanji> and your <reading>knee</reading> (<ja>に</ja>) is in there. The person wasn't saying they wanted to boil, they said they wanted to boil someone. And that meant you. Well, your knee anyway.
data.reading_hint: Once your knee is done boiling, the person kneels down in front of you and presents it on a platter, mocking you, since you can't kneel anymore. You should pay more attention to what's going on from now on or you could find yourself in... HOT WATER. Ohohoho.

data.meaning_mnemonic:
If a <radical>helicopter</radical> <radical>loiter</radical>s near a <radical>black hole</radical> then it's going to <kanji>capsize</kanji>. I mean, yeah, it's not a boat, but just look, that's what's happening! That helicopter is going down!

If you want to save it you better <kanji>cover</kanji> up the black hole! The only way to save it from capsizing is to cover it right up!
data.meaning_hint: Imagine trying to cover up a black hole so that the helicopter doesn't capsize. It's one or the other, dude. Cover or capsize. You decide.
data.reading_mnemonic: You're doing your best to <kanji>cover</kanji> the black hole to stop the helicopter from <kanji>capsiz</kanji>ing but it's not working! “<reading>F**k</reading> you (<ja>ふく</ja>) black hole!" you shout. You just want to cover it up! You just want to do the right thing!
data.reading_hint: Man, f**k you you, black hole. F**k you you. Making that helicopter capsize and then refusing to be covered?

data.meaning_mnemonic: Watch what you <radical>say</radical> to what appears to be a <radical>sweet</radical> <radical>tree</radical>, because that tree will 100% <kanji>conspire</kanji> against you.
data.meaning_hint: Trees may look all sweet and innocent, like they aren't listening to every word you say, but it's a front! They're conspiring against you!! They'll blackmail you and take everything!!!
data.reading_mnemonic: Now you're getting it! That tree is trying to <kanji>conspire</kanji> against you and take you down. Take your <reading>bow</reading>ling (<ja>ぼう</ja>) ball and bowl it and all its friends down!
data.reading_hint:
Watch as the conspiratorial tree and all it's gossiping friends are bowled over by your bowling ball. Phew. You're safe from the trees.

For now.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The only type of <radical>can</radical> you'll be <radical>building</radical> in <radical>prison</radical> is one made of <kanji>pottery</kanji>. Do you honestly think they would let you have anything made of metal or plastic? No, too dangerous. You have to make all of your cans and plates and underpants the old-fashioned pottery way.
data.meaning_hint: Picture the first piece of pottery you ever made. Feel it in your hands. At least you've learned something new while you've been stuck in prison.
data.reading_mnemonic: You get so good at <kanji>pottery</kanji> that the guards start to notice and offer to sell what you make in <ja><reading>とう</reading>きょう</ja>. <ja>とうきょう</ja> is a big pottery town, after all. You'll make a fortune! Well... the guards will at least.
data.reading_hint: Selling your prison pottery in <ja>とうきょう</ja> might even help you get out faster. Yippee!

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>building</radical> that has a <radical>bully</radical> will <kanji>isolate</kanji> itself. Building have feelings like people, you know.
data.meaning_hint: Picture a single building, isolated from the rest of the city and those mean, bully buildings that live there.
data.reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>isolate</kanji>d building only has one companion, and it's the <reading>cock</reading> (<ja>かく</ja>) that lives inside of it.
data.reading_hint: Picture the sun rising behind an isolated building. A cock lets out a cry from the roof. It's a sad and lonely scene.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If someone <radical>loiter</radical>s it's <radical>correct</radical> to <kanji>subjugate</kanji> them.
data.meaning_hint: You can't just let people do whatever they want. If it isn't correct to loiter here, then it IS correct to subjugate them, and force them to do what you want. You control them now. And they're gonna get it!
data.reading_mnemonic: You <kanji>subjugate</kanji> these loiterers with your holy blue <reading>sa</reading>ber (<ja>せい</ja>)! It's the correct thing to do, after all, and you were given this saber all those levels ago because you did the correct thing.
data.reading_hint: As you swing your saber around, subjugating the loiterers, and making them do as you say, you remind yourself that this is correct. And if it's correct, you have to use your saber to enforce it.

data.meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Compare</radical> a <radical>building</radical> to some <radical>dirt</radical> and you'll see the difference between you and His and Her <kanji>Highness</kanji>. You live outside and sleep on the dirt. But His and Her Highness both live in a huge building.
data.meaning_hint: Picture Her Highness, high up in her building. Now compare her home and life to yours, you dirt person.
data.reading_mnemonic: I bet His <kanji>Highness</kanji> has never had to sleep in <reading>hay</reading> (<ja>へい</ja>) either, like you do every night. Hay is what you use as a pillow, mattress, blanket. Basically hay and dirt are all you have. Unlike His Highness.
data.reading_hint: Picture His and Her Highness coming out of their huge building and walking by you in your hay pile. "My goodness, Highness, have you ever seen such a dirty, fluffy creature?" "My no, dear, let's move quickly to remove it from our sight!"

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>leader</radical> of this <radical>valley</radical> is very <kanji>vulgar</kanji>. The name of the valley is Vulgar Valley, so it makes sense for its leader to be very vulgar.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine meeting the leader of Vulgar Valley. Imagine all the vulgar things he says to prove he is worthy of being the leader of Vulgar Valley. He is so very, very vulgar.
data.reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>vulgar</kanji> leader leads his Boso<reading>zoku</reading> (<ja>ぞく</ja>) bike gang through Vulgar Valley, patrolling the area and spreading vulgarity as he goes.
data.reading_hint: Hear the motorcycles rev and purr as they carouse the Vulgar Valley. Hear the leader screaming vulgar things as he and his Bosozoku bike gang ride all around.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You take a <radical>stool</radical>, another <radical>stool</radical>, and yet another <radical>stool</radical> and stack them on top of a <radical>tree</radical> to make a <kanji>mulberry</kanji> bush. This is how mulberry bushes are made. You take three stools and you put them atop a tree.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine putting three stools on top of a tree and watching it transform into a mulberry. The science of nature!
data.reading_mnemonic: You then eat a <kanji>mulberry</kanji> because a mulberry will <reading>cure</reading> (<ja>くわ</ja>) any and all ailments. A mulberry is the cure-all of nature.
data.reading_hint: Have something you need to cure? Eat a mulberry. Taste the mulberry taste on your tongue as you become cured. Ahh, nice.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> at the <radical>gate</radical> of the <radical>king</radical> makes sure all of his plants get <kanji>watered</kanji>. The gate prevents the tsunami from damaging anything inside the king’s home, and the plants around the gate get watered by the water of the tsunami.
data.meaning_hint: Hear the tsunami crash into the gate as you see the water slosh around and make sure that all of the king’s plants get good and watered.
data.reading_mnemonic: These plants are getting <kanji>watered</kanji> in <reading>June</reading> (<ja>じゅん</ja>), the month they need watering the most. June is a hot month, so it’s good that this tsunami came and got the king’s plants watered when it did.
data.reading_hint: Again, watch and hear the tsunami crashing into the gate and getting the plants watered. This time, remember that the month is June and it is very hot and sticky outside. You’re sweating and very hot.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>king</radical> takes his <radical>slide</radical> into his private <radical>jet</radical> and is given a <kanji>pearl</kanji> as a gift, by you! He's letting you ride in his jet today, and you were told the king should be presented with a pearl as soon as he boards.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine giving this gorgeous white pearl to the king after he slides down his slide and boards the jet. See his king face light up as he sees the pretty pearl.
data.reading_mnemonic: The king takes the <kanji>pearl</kanji> and tosses it into a <reading>chu</reading>te (<ja>しゅ</ja>) next to the slide he took to get into the jet. You watch as the pearl goes down, down, down until it lands into a huge vat of pearls.
data.reading_hint: Oh. I guess the king didn't need your pearl, since he has a pearl chute to get them off his jet before takeoff. You feel silly. And you kind of want to jump into the pearl chute yourself.
