data.meaning_mnemonic: You take a <radical>lid</radical>, and aiming it at the <radical>sun</radical> you <radical>kick</radical> it into the air and eventually it begins to <kanji>decline</kanji> and crashes into the sun, causing it to supernova. Imagine kicking this lid so hard that it flies into space. See it fly up to the peak of its arch, then watch as it begins the decline until it finally collides with the sun.
data.meaning_hint: As you watch the lid decline, keep in mind that the sun radical its middle line extending outside the box on both sides. This is because the sun is going supernova. Pew!
data.reading_mnemonic: As the lid begins to <kanji>decline</kanji> in the sky, you realize what’s going to happen so you attempt to <reading>swi</reading>ng (<ja>すい</ja>) to safety. Swing on some vines in the direction opposite of the sun. You know that once that lid finishes its decline and collides with the sun, there’s gonna be trouble.
data.reading_hint: Imagine swinging on these vines as you hear the sun explode and go supernova behind you. Swing faster! Swing faster!

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>commander</radical> who's <radical>big</radical> will use his size to <kanji>encourage</kanji> his troops.
data.meaning_hint: "Look at me! You can be a big commander someday too!" he shouts, encouraging everyone.
data.reading_mnemonic: He <kanji>encourage</kanji>s the <reading>Shou</reading>gun (<ja>しょう</ja>) too! You've never seen the Shougun express any emotion other than intense indifference or intense dislike.
data.reading_hint: Picture the encouraged Shougun: his eyes are shining with tears, his heart is pounding, he's been encouraged to be better!

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>few</radical> members of society without <radical>power</radical> suffer from severe <kanji>inferiority</kanji> complexes. Most people in this world have lots of power, so the few that do not feel quite inferior. It is this feeling of inferiority that fuels their inferiority complexes.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine you are one of the few without power. Feel the inferiority crushing down on you. It feels terrible and there is nothing you can do about it.
data.reading_mnemonic: Since you suffer from such extreme feelings of <kanji>inferiority</kanji>, when someone offers you and your friends the chance to gain power, you yell “<reading>Let’s</reading> (<ja>れつ</ja>) go!” without a second thought. “Let’s go, guys! Come on! Power awaits us!”
data.reading_hint: Let’s go, let’s go! Time’s a wastin’! I’m tired of this inferiority and want to gain some power!

data.meaning_mnemonic: This <radical>crab trap</radical> has the <radical>power</radical> of <kanji>intuition</kanji>. By the power of intuition, this crab trap can trap like, every crab. Through intuition, it knows where the crabs will go and how they will react, so it is much easier to trap them.
data.meaning_hint: Look at this crab trap and see it visibly glowing with intuition. Its powers of intuition are so strong that you can actually see it shimmering with intuition as it expertly traps all those crabs.
data.reading_mnemonic: This crab trap's <kanji>intuition</kanji> powers were extracted from Genghis <reading>Khan</reading> (<ja>かん</ja>) himself. And as we all know by know, Genghis Khan was the absolute master of intuition, he always knew what his enemies and his allies were about to do.
data.reading_hint: Genghis Khan probably has the strongest intuition of anyone in history. This crab trap is getting close though.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>woman</radical> sees herself (<radical>oneself</radical>) as a <kanji>princess</kanji> or a <kanji>queen</kanji>. As women should!
data.meaning_hint: Just remember, when you're around other women (and woman-aligned peoples), it's important to treat each other like princess and queens, not just oneself.
data.reading_mnemonic: All of us <kanji>princess</kanji>es and <kanji>queen</kanji>s share a special <reading>hea</reading>t (<ja>ひ</ja>). When we see another princess or queen that heat passes through us and we nod to one another.
data.reading_hint: All princess and queens can feel the heat coming off of the others.

data.meaning_mnemonic: At the top of the <radical>mountain</radical> is a <radical>signpost</radical> to tell you you've reached the <kanji>summit</kanji>. Literally every mountain that humans have reached the top of has one of these summit signs.
data.meaning_hint: If that signpost wasn't there how would you know you reached the summit? Like, if you were on top of Everest and there was a bad storm... you'd just topple off the other side. Those summit signposts are important!
data.reading_mnemonic: At the <kanji>summit</kanji>, you decide to build your new <reading>ho</reading>me (<ja>ほう</ja>). It's been destroyed so many times, and you're sick of it. Maybe if you build you home at the summit of this mountain it will be safer.
data.reading_hint: Picture your beautiful summit home. You know, George Washington had one of these too. So. That's cool, I guess.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>construction</radical> <radical>beggar</radical> is one who begs for construction projects. He doesn't do it for money or fame, he begs for construction because he is so <kanji>adept</kanji> at what he does.
data.meaning_hint: The construction beggar looks like any other beggar, which makes it even stranger that he's so adept at what he does. He really puts everything into his construction work.
data.reading_mnemonic: "The most <kanji>adept</kanji> at construction in all the land is me," says the construction beggar to emperor <ja><reading>こう</reading>いち</ja>.
data.reading_hint:
The construction beggar is giving a presentation on why he would be the best choice for making a grand new palace for Emperor <ja>こういち</ja>. Point number one: he is the most adept at construction.

Hint: When you see <ja>工</ja> in a kanji it will often take the <ja>こう</ja> reading.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>fang</radical> on a <radical>building</radical> shows that it's <kanji>wicked</kanji>. Something wicked probably lives in the building too.
data.meaning_hint: Not like, wicked cool, but like wicked evil. I see you, New Englanders.
data.reading_mnemonic: You peek inside the <kanji>wicked</kanji> building and a wicked <reading>ja</reading>guar (<ja>じゃ</ja>) suddenly pounces at you! You let out a sigh of relief when it's stopped by the window, but then... the window opens?! What a wicked building! It's letting the jaguar get you!
data.reading_hint: Imagine being chased around the outside of this wicked fanged building as the wicked fanged jaguar tries to eat you. Ahhh!

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>horse</radical> that is <radical>fat</radical> is a <kanji>burdensome</kanji> animal.
data.meaning_hint: A fat horse. So burdensome. Not to mention the burden on the horse on top of the fatness.
data.reading_mnemonic: But you have to be nice to the <kanji>burdensome</kanji> horse because this horse is your <reading>da</reading>d (<ja>だ</ja>).
data.reading_hint: Go visit your dad the burdensome horse because you have to visit your dad. It's weird because you're a human and he's a horse.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Under a <radical>canopy</radical>, someone thinking with a <radical>brush</radical> in their <radical>mouth</radical> has a <kanji>sudden</kanji> thought, and uses the brush to write the word "<kanji>China</kanji>". Thus, China was born.
data.meaning_hint: All of a sudden China existed! Pretty crazy, right?
data.reading_mnemonic: Believe it or not, this <kanji>sudden</kanji> invention of <kanji>China</kanji> happened in <ja><reading>とう</reading>きょう</ja>. Well, it wasn't <ja>とうきょう</ja> yet. And it was a traveling Chinese person who did it. But you know legends, they're just all over the place.
data.reading_hint: Oh my gosh, can you imagine how mad China will be when you tell them they were invented in <ja>とうきょう</ja>? Maybe you shouldn't tell anyone this story. Just keep it between you and me, kay?

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>Yoga</radical> <radical>King</radical> presides over all <kanji>courts</kanji>: law, imperial, and so forth. In this case, you've met him in the court of law, where he is judge, jury, and executioner.
data.meaning_hint: Picture him sitting above you in the judge's chair in court. He's about to make his judgement.
data.reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>court</kanji> of the Yoga King is against you. You have to turn this around, so you start pushing <reading>ta</reading>ter (<ja>てい</ja>) tots into his tater-tot-hole shaped mouth.
data.reading_hint: "I hereby sentence you to..." *ploop* "Ooh, this is really good. I hereby sentence..." *ploop* "Wow, are these tater tots? Court dismissed."

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tree</radical> <radical>can</radical> be a <radical>tree</radical>, but it can also be a <radical>psychopath</radical>. The tree goes from being a regular tree to being a psychopath. Such mood swings are so rough. Especially when the tree slips to <kanji>gloom</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine all the mood swings of this tree. Psychopath tree! Also very gloomy sometimes.
data.reading_mnemonic: Then the tree switches from <kanji>gloom</kanji> to being super excited (these moodswings!). The super excited tree starts doing dubstep. <reading>Uts</reading> (<ja>うつ</ja>) uts uts uts uts <ja>♬</ja>.
data.reading_hint: Sing along with the moody tree. Gloom to dubstep. Such a big change.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>fish</radical> in its <radical>mouth</radical> and in the other <radical>mouth</radical> is half a <radical>beggar</radical> (the head is cut off). The other half is on the <radical>ground</radical>. The animal that has fishes and beggars in its mouth, is an <kanji>alligator</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Just imagine the blood  and fishes and beggars everywhere. The alligator is having a good meal tonight.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the <ja>わに</ja> in "Wanikani." Ever heard of it?
data.reading_hint: So long as you've ever used WaniKani, you probably know the reading of the word alligator.

data.meaning_mnemonic: This is an animal with an <radical>angle</radical>d <radical>sword</radical> claw that's filled with <radical>cow</radical> meat but looks like an <radical>insect</radical>. What kind of animal is that? It's a <kanji>crab</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: If you think about the different parts you can see why this is a crab. A delicious, delicious crab.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the <ja><reading>かに</reading></ja> in WaniKani.
data.reading_hint: If you've used WaniKani before, you probably know this reading, hopefully. All praise the great allicrab!

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>bamboo</radical> <radical>tsunami</radical>'s <radical>specialty</radical> is to crush everything in front of it, smash down, and turn into multiple <kanji>record book</kanji>s.
data.meaning_hint: The bamboo flattens as it hits the ground then turns into papers. The papers combine to become record books that show what happened here, this day.
data.reading_mnemonic: A <kanji>record book</kanji> is a <reading>bo</reading>ok (<ja>ぼ</ja>), when it comes down to it.
data.reading_hint: Bamboo can also become <reading>bo</reading> staffs too, if they don't turn into record books.

data.meaning_mnemonic:
You want to write a <radical>chapter</radical> about <radical>hair</radical> in your new book so you have to make sure it's really <kanji>clear</kanji>. Clear enough so that ANYbody can read it.

It's so clear and concise you decide to <kanji>patent</kanji> it. Now it's yours and yours alone.
data.meaning_hint: Can you file a patent on a chapter? It's not very clear, but what is clear is how great your writing is.
data.reading_mnemonic: Your <kanji>clear</kanji> writing got the attention of the <reading>Shou</reading>gun (<ja>しょう</ja>) and now he's at your door once again, but this time he's angrier than usual. Apparently he was going to steal your clear explanations but since you've patented it, he can't.
data.reading_hint: Picture the Shougun angrily holding what is clearly your patent and shouting in your face.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> crashes into the <radical>sun</radical>, which is then caught in a <radical>net</radical> tied to a <radical>stool</radical>! Wait a second... this doesn't sound realistic, this is from that pirate <kanji>manga</kanji> you're always reading!
data.meaning_hint: Imagine reading this issue of your favorite stretchy pirate boy manga, Lumpy uses his arms as a net, his legs tied to a stool, and traps the sun in a net right as the tsunami hits. Gee what kind of crazy trouble is he getting into this time?!
data.reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Manga</kanji> starts with <reading>man</reading> (<ja>まん</ja>)!
data.reading_hint: You already know all about manga and now you can read them too. Look how far you've come. Wow, what a journey. And you're almost at the end. Gosh, I'm just so proud of you, kiddo.

data.meaning_mnemonic: What you <radical>say</radical> on the <radical>street</radical> needs to be <kanji>revise</kanji>d. Your words need to be polished, you can't publish improv. Revise your street word inspiration before you share it again.
data.meaning_hint: Think about all the stupid things you said on the streets today. Do you want those exact phrases, mistakes, and mouth sounds following you around forever? Revise it before you write it down!
data.reading_mnemonic: You want to <kanji>revise</kanji> the song you wrote about <reading>ta</reading>ter (<ja>てい</ja>) tots at lunch today. But it needs a lot of revising.
data.reading_hint:
"Tater tots, tater tots, tater tots, man.
Bake me a tater tot as fast as you banana."

Well that's bad. Better revise this so it rhymes.

"Tater tots, tater tots, tater tots, man.
Bake me a tater tot as fast as you want."

Nope, still bad. Revise!

"Tater tots, tater tots, tater tots, man.
Bake me a tater tot as fast as you clam."

Yes. It's gold.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Watch what you <radical>say</radical> to the <radical>next</radical> <radical>mouth</radical> over, because they hired you to <kanji>consult</kanji> them.
data.meaning_hint: The person with the next mouth in the room is waiting for you to open yours to consult them. He'll do whatever you say.
data.reading_mnemonic: You panic, and <kanji>consult</kanji> the man into buying a <reading>shee</reading>p (<ja>し</ja>).
data.reading_hint: He was asking for love advice, so I guess you consulted that he give a sheep to the person he likes? Uh oh. Remind me never to consult with you when I'm feeling unsure about things.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>gold</radical> <radical>name</radical> on this piece of wood is the <kanji>inscription</kanji> that shows the artist's signature.
data.meaning_hint: This inscription refers to a signature or something similar. This is an artisan's signature in the form of an inscription.
data.reading_mnemonic: The inscription is a name written on something, right? Remember the kanji for "name"? It is <ja>名</ja>, and it shares the reading with this kanji as well, making both names <ja><reading>めい</reading></ja>.
data.reading_hint: If you need to review <ja>名</ja> go ahead and do that. It will help you to remember this kanji.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>woman</radical> is making a <radical>dirt</radical> <radical>cage</radical> in the <radical>sun</radical>. She's using it to trap water, making this a dirt <kanji>dam</kanji>. If you think about it, dams are just dirt cages anyway.
data.meaning_hint: Picture the woman working tirelessly in the hot sun, moving and shaping the dirt around this river into a dam to make a pond.
data.reading_mnemonic: Something about the woman working hard to build this <kanji>dam</kanji> makes her super <reading>sexy</reading> (<ja>せき</ja>) to you. Maybe it's because the sun is so bright, making her shine, or maybe it's because hard work is attractive. Who knows.
data.reading_hint: If you wanna be sexy maybe you should build a dam too.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>correct</radical> way to block the <radical>sun</radical> with <radical>dirt</radical> is with an <kanji>embankment</kanji>. Build a huge, sloping embankment correctly and the sun won't be able to bother you ever again!
data.meaning_hint: Imagine an embankment made of dirt, in the correct place, blocking the sun from your eyes.
data.reading_mnemonic: Unfortunately, building a correct <kanji>embankment</kanji> doesn't just take dirt, but <reading>ta</reading>ter (<ja>てい</ja>) tots too. You pile up the dirt and the tater tots so the embankment can be nice and high.
data.reading_hint: Picture an embankment made of dirt and tater tots. Not like, tater tots just thrown in the embankment, you probably see those all the time. But dirt AND tater tots in the embankment itself.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If a <radical>tsunami</radical> hits your <radical>helicopter</radical> while you are <radical>jackhammer</radical>ing, it will <kanji>drift</kanji> out to sea. What were you doing with a jackhammer at a time like this? Now your helicopter is drifting away!
data.meaning_hint: Picture your helicopter as it drifts out to sea with the tsunami.
data.reading_mnemonic: As it <kanji>drift</kanji>s away you shout, "<reading>Heyooo</reading>! (<ja>ひょう</ja>)." You know the helicopter probably can't hear you (or understand you) but maybe it will turn on and stop drifting away if you shout it enough.
data.reading_hint: "Heyoooo stop drifting awaaaay!!"

data.meaning_mnemonic: You have a <radical>number</radical>ed <radical>feather</radical>. Pick your favorite number and put it on the feather. Then, put the numbered feather on your head. When you put it on, you're able to <kanji>flip</kanji> and <kanji>flip</kanji> over and over.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine yourself doing flips with this feather on your head. Flip flip flip.
data.reading_mnemonic: You're pretty good at your <kanji>flip</kanji> technique, but you're not that good. You really need to practice and <reading>hone</reading> (<ja>ほん</ja>) your skills and get better.
data.reading_hint: Or, maybe you get so good that you write a <ja><reading>本</reading></ja> (<ja>ほん</ja>) about doing a flip. Wow, you're good!

data.meaning_mnemonic: There are <radical>nine</radical> <radical>car</radical>s all driving in the same place. With so many cars driving in the same place, they create a <kanji>rut</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine the cars spinning out in the rut. Spin spin spin. The rut gets bigger. Nine is too many cars.
data.reading_mnemonic: To get out of the rut you have to put in a second <reading>key</reading> (<ja>き</ja>) that turns on the thrusters. You put in the key and press the "take off" button.
data.reading_hint: Imagine turning the thrusters key, then feeling the car lift off the ground. You'll finally get out of this <kanji>rut</kanji>!

data.meaning_mnemonic: You walk out on a <radical>cliff</radical>, where you find in the <radical>ground</radical> a <radical>mouth</radical> poking out. It speaks: "It is me, the <kanji>empress</kanji> of these lands!"
data.meaning_hint: She was buried in the cliff down to her mouth so nobody would find her! You pull her out of the ground and soon what was just a mouth becomes a whole empress!
data.reading_mnemonic: When you finish unburying the <kanji>empress</kanji>, the first thing she says to you is: "Please, you must hurry and take me to Emperor <ja><reading>こう</reading>いち</ja>."
data.reading_hint: It's only natural the empress would want to see her emperor. And right now, the emperor of these lands is Emperor <ja>こういち</ja>.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>big</radical> <radical>turkey</radical> in the <radical>rice paddy</radical> is getting all <kanji>stirred up</kanji>. He's kicking up all the rice. Who stirred him up?
data.meaning_hint: He is a really big turkey too. Like, 12 feet tall, or something. Don't want to stir up a turkey that's that big.
data.reading_mnemonic: While the turkey is <kanji>stirred up</kanji>, it also looks like it's having a lot of <reading>fun</reading> (<ja>ふん</ja>).
data.reading_hint: Is it laughing? Oh no, this is bad, it's enjoying being stirred up, now we'll never stop it.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>restaurant</radical> radical and the <kanji>restaurant</kanji> kanji are the same!
data.meaning_hint: Know your radicals, yo!
data.reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>restaurant</kanji> only serves <reading>tater</reading> (<ja>てい</ja>) tots. Really, would you ever want to go to a restaurant that didn't have tater tots? No.
data.reading_hint: Imagine going to a restaurant and seeing a menu of all different types and styles of tater tots and nothing else. Even the drinks are tater tot based. Mmm mm.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>leader</radical> <radical>cat pirate</radical> is the greatest cat pirate of them all. It leads all the cat pirate leaders, even! This is truly a cat pirate <kanji>to look up to</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine this majestic cat pirate leader of leaders. Feel in your heart that you look up to this cat pirate, truly.
data.reading_mnemonic: Your job is to bring this leader of cat pirates (whom you <kanji>look up to</kanji>) its favorite food: <reading>gyo</reading>za (<ja>ぎょう</ja>).
data.reading_hint: Of course, the gyoza is filled with fish, because we're talking about cat pirates, here.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>leader</radical> all in <radical>white</radical> is the <kanji>chief</kanji>. All the other leaders are wearing some other color, but that's how you tell the chief apart from the other leaders.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine all the leaders standing around, then the chief person standing there all in white.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as <ja>白</ja>, which is included in this kanji. The other reading is <ja>お</ja>, and it's like the honorific <ja>御</ja>, in a way. You'd want to be polite to someone who is the chief ______, right? That's why it could be <ja>お</ja>, too.
data.reading_hint: You'll learn more about which reading to use when the vocabulary roll around. In the meantime, try to remember both of them the best you can!

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>leader</radical>, Master <radical>Splinter</radical> (the rat from Ninja Turtles) isn't even supposed to exist. He exists because someone <kanji>accidentally</kanji> poured ooze on him.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine someone accidentally spilling ooze on a rat, then watch the rat turn into a sentient rat martial artist.
data.reading_mnemonic: But really, if you do something <kanji>accidentally</kanji>, it's probably a <reading>goo</reading>d (<ja>ぐう</ja>) thing in a way. You learn a bit about how you can improve yourself so you don't do it again, or in Splinter's case, it's just a good mistake!
data.reading_hint: However you look at it, try to make this accident be a good accident.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> hits a <radical>roof</radical> and then <radical>correct</radical>s itself. This causes it to swirl around, creating an <kanji>eddy</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: An eddy requires water to change direction and then twirl around, and when the tsunami hits the roof, that's exactly what it does.
data.reading_mnemonic: There is a person trying to create an <kanji>eddy</kanji> with a tsunami, and when their roof correction device is shown to be effective, they sing: "This is how <reading>you do</reading> (<ja>よど</ja>) it."
data.reading_hint: Imagine them singing this, emphasizing the "you do" part of the song as they watch the eddy being formed.

data.meaning_mnemonic: There's a <radical>cross</radical> in the <radical>dirt</radical> and the dirt is surrounded by <radical>flowers</radical> and shells from <radical>shellfish</radical>. This is a <kanji>tomb</kanji>. The flowers and shellfish were put here as decorations and to honor the dead that currently lay under the dirt. And the cross marks the tomb, obviously.
data.meaning_hint: Can you picture this big dirt tomb, with flowers and shellfish decorating it and a cross right on top?
data.reading_mnemonic: This may be a <kanji>tomb</kanji>, but it feels really <reading>fun</reading> (<ja>ふん</ja>). It is decorated, after all. This tomb isn't a sad place, it's a fun place to remember the people you loved.
data.reading_hint: The next time you see a tomb think about how much fun that person had while they were alive. This tomb is motivating you to try and have as much fun as you can while you can!

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>samurai</radical> who can fight with <radical>icicle</radical>s on him is more <kanji>robust</kanji> than regular samurai. Can you imagine how robust you'd have to be to fight in weather cold enough to form icicles on your body?
data.meaning_hint: Picture samurai standing in a line. One, two, three... woah. You look up. This guy has icicles growing off him and he's the size of a bus. Now that's a robust samurai.
data.reading_mnemonic: You may think it's just his <kanji>robust</kanji> body, but it's actually the samurai's robust <reading>sou</reading>l (<ja>そう</ja>) that keeps him fighting through the cold and the icicles.
data.reading_hint: Physical robustness is just a reflection of the strength of your soul!

data.meaning_mnemonic: Put your <radical>fingers</radical> on the <radical>bed</radical>, <kanji>grasp</kanji> the sheets and <kanji>bundle</kanji> them up. Now you can do the laundry!
data.meaning_hint: Imagine pressing your fingers into the bed, grasping tightly and ripping the sheets free. Then you bundle them up into your arms so you can stuff them into the washing machine.
data.reading_mnemonic: In between <kanji>grasp</kanji>ing and <kanji>bundle</kanji>-ing, you shout <reading>HA</reading> (<ja>は</ja>)! That's when the sheets come off the bed.
data.reading_hint: The next time you grasp your bedsheets yell "Ha!" as you yank them off. Now chuckle a bit, ha ha ha, as you bundle them up into a ball. You can't beat me, bedsheets.

data.meaning_mnemonic: With your <radical>fingers</radical> you put some <radical>weapon</radical>s in a <radical>boat</radical> for <kanji>transport</kanji>. This is a transport boat and its your job to get these weapons from one place to another.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine loading a bunch of weapons into a boat and sailing off to transport them somewhere else.
data.reading_mnemonic: Hey! You're <kanji>transport</kanji>ing weapons just like <reading>Han</reading> (<ja>はん</ja>) Solo! I mean, it was a spaceship, not technically a boat, but he definitely used the Millennium Falcon as a transport.
data.reading_hint: Picture yourself as a cool smuggler, transporting stolen... I mean... totally legitimate weapons from one place to another. Just like Han Solo!

data.meaning_mnemonic: The sun hits this and breaks into three <radical>sun</radical>s. What can split the sun in three directions? A <kanji>crystal</kanji>!
data.meaning_hint: Crystals take light and refract it around into many directions. That's why there are three suns in this kanji.
data.reading_mnemonic: Who is hoarding and harnessing the power of these <kanji>crystal</kanji>s? That would be the <reading>Shou</reading>gun (<ja>しょう</ja>).
data.reading_hint: Imagine the Shougun laying in his bed of crystals. He still has his really serious, angry face though. Even as he rubs the crystals to his face, he's glowering.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> is the <radical>same</radical> as a <kanji>cave</kanji>. Because, if a wave is big enough, it will curl over on itself, creating a sort of cave within the wave. That's why it's the same as a cave!
data.meaning_hint: Also, imagine a tsunami hitting a cave, becoming the same as the cave (since a cave will shape it).
data.reading_mnemonic: Best way to remember the reading for this kanji is to think about how the shape of a cave is the shape of a <reading>dou</reading>ghnut (<ja>どう</ja>).
data.reading_hint: Also note that the <ja>同</ja> part of this kanji gives away the reading as well. <ja>同</ja> and <ja>洞</ja> have the same readings!

data.meaning_mnemonic: There is a <radical>tsunami</radical> coming up over a <radical>cliff</radical> made of <radical>dirt</radical>. You can see this happening very far away because it's right on the <kanji>horizon</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Picture the tsunami breaking over the cliff on the horizon. It would be beautiful if it wasn't so frightening.
data.reading_mnemonic: You squint into the <kanji>horizon</kanji> and see something else. There's some <reading>guy</reading> (<ja>がい</ja>) up there. And he's... he's being swept away by the tsunami. The guy disappears into the horizon. The guy is gone.
data.reading_hint: You wonder who that guy was. You wonder why he was there. You wonder if he's still alive out there, past the horizon.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Turn a <radical>sick</radical>ness into a <radical>weapon</radical> and it becomes an <kanji>epidemic</kanji>. This sickness spreads to everyone and it's all your fault because you put it in the water supply.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine if countries decided to make sick weapons that would spread epidemics like this all over part of the world. Let's hope they don't...
data.reading_mnemonic: These <kanji>epidemic</kanji>s spread by <ja><reading>駅</reading></ja> (<ja>えき</ja>). Each train takes the sickness and shoots of in a different direction, spreading it further.
data.reading_hint: Picture a single <ja>駅</ja> on a map, bright red. Now watch the red spread to all of the other <ja>駅</ja> on the map, dyeing them red and spreading the epidemic all over your country.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You see a <radical>child</radical> with an <radical>umbrella</radical> in front of you. Suddenly, they fall straight down into a <kanji>cavity</kanji> in the road. It's a big <kanji>hole</kanji>!
data.meaning_hint: You run over to where the child fell. They are just fine! Because they had an umbrella, they were able to float to the bottom.
data.reading_mnemonic: "Into my <kanji>cavity</kanji> you go!" yells a voice. It is <ja><reading>こう</reading>いち</ja>.
data.reading_hint: "You will stay in that cavity and/or hole until you repent." If it hasn't been clear up until now, Emperor <ja>こういち</ja> is going mad with power.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>leader</radical> of <radical>Korea</radical> is destined for <kanji>greatness</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: I mean, they're the leader of Korea already, right? So they have to have a decent chunk of greatness in them already to get that far.
data.reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>greatness</kanji> radiates off of the leader of Korea, so much so that you can hardly look. Just when you're about to close your eyes to shield them from the greatness, a great <reading>ea</reading>gle (<ja>い</ja>) soars over them, letting out a cry.
data.reading_hint: Picture the greatness of the scene before you: the leader of Korea, a great eagle overhead, it's so great!!

data.meaning_mnemonic: Take the <radical>street</radical> all the way to that <radical>geoduck</radical>, way up there. When you reach it, you will have made it to the <kanji>summit</kanji>. You <kanji>humbly</kanji> present the road to the geoduck and bow before it.
data.meaning_hint: There is a giant geoduck at the summit of the mountain, and the street will lead you right there. Imagine the grueling climb up the mountain to the summit. Feel it in your legs, and keep looking at that tall, tall geoduck. Now imagine kneeling those same aching legs humbly to the street below the geoduck.
data.reading_mnemonic: You are at the top, the <kanji>summit</kanji> of everything! You <kanji>humbly</kanji> survey your surroundings from the top of the geoduck, only to see someone on the street, running toward you. It is Mrs. <reading>Chou</reading> (<ja>ちょう</ja>), and she looks angry.
data.reading_hint: Anytime you use the street, you're in Mrs. Chou's territory. After detecting you were using her street to reach the geoduck, she started coming after you. Remember, wherever there's a street (radical), Mrs. Chou is not far behind.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>call</radical> radical and the <kanji>call</kanji> kanji are the same. This kanji can also mean <kanji>eat</kanji>, because why would you call someone if not to ask them to eat with you?!
data.meaning_hint: Call your mom or dad and ask them to go out to eat with you right now.
data.reading_mnemonic: You are <kanji>call</kanji>ed to come <kanji>eat</kanji> by the <reading>Shou</reading>gun (<ja>しょう</ja>). He's been really impressed with you lately and he wants to chat over drinks, he says on the phone.
data.reading_hint: Imagine getting a call from the Shougun himself. He's come to your house before, but he's never asked you to eat with him. This is huge!

data.meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>fingers</radical> have <radical>husband</radical> <radical>horns</radical>. They are there right <kanji>between</kanji> each of your fingers.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine little husband horns (the horns your husband has) between all your fingers. Emphasis on _between_.
data.reading_mnemonic: What is <kanji>between</kanji> your fingers? Your <reading>hus</reading>band (<ja>はさ</ja>) horns.
data.reading_hint: Husband, between. Between, husband.

data.meaning_mnemonic: When a <radical>tree</radical> grows <radical>old</radical>, it will <kanji>wither</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Old trees' roots and leaves grow inefficient, and they can't get enough nutrients. It's only natural for them to wither up a little bit.
data.reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>wither</kanji>ed tree's best friend is a human <ja><reading>子</reading></ja> (<ja>こ</ja>). Imagine the child hugging the tree.
data.reading_hint: It gave the <ja>子</ja> its shade, its sap, and eventually its body to build a house. What an awful child, and what a generic giving tree.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If a <radical>tsunami</radical> hits a <radical>dollar</radical> the water will instantly start to <kanji>boil</kanji>!
data.meaning_hint: Imagine standing in front of an incoming tsunami. Suddenly in the distance you see someone throwing dollar bills into it and it starts to boil. Ahh!
data.reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>boil</kanji>ing water crashes onto the land and you realize your foot is in it! No, not one foot, both your <reading>foots</reading> (<ja>ふつ</ja>)! It hurts so much that you can't even remember the word for two foots.
data.reading_hint: Feel your poor little foots burn in the boiling water. You really want to know who that jerk was that threw dollars into the tsunami to make it boil!

data.meaning_mnemonic: You need to throw your two <radical>wolverine</radical>s and your <radical>turkey</radical> into the oncoming <radical>tsunami</radical> if you want to <kanji>wash</kanji> them at the same time. It's the only way you can get them clean at once without the wolverines fighting over the turkey and somebody getting hurt. The tsunami is big enough to wash them all before anything bad happens.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine the tsunami coming toward you. Two wolverines in one hand and a turkey in the other. You're gonna wash them so good they'll never get dirty again.
data.reading_mnemonic: Once they're nice and <kanji>wash</kanji>ed you need to subdue them by poking each of them with a <reading>tack</reading> (<ja>たく</ja>). The tack has special sleeping medicine on it, so once they're nice and clean you can put them back in their cages without them trying to eat each other.
data.reading_hint: If you want to wash your animals make sure to have your special tack ready. The tsunami will recede pretty fast so get it out!

data.meaning_mnemonic: Put <radical>syrup</radical> too close to <radical>fire</radical> and it will <kanji>dry up</kanji>. Put any liquid substance near fire and it will dry up actually, but syrup especially. It goes from being sticky and gooey and yummy to a pile of hard, dry sugar. Not so yummy.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine putting some syrup over a fire and watching it dry up. Watch as the sides slowly bubble and harden and lose what makes syrup so good in the first place.
data.reading_mnemonic: If you <kanji>dry up</kanji> syrup like this, you're removing its <reading>sou</reading>l (<ja>そう</ja>). Have you ever seen dry syrup before? No soul in that. In fact, you probably have no soul if you can dry out syrup like this without feeling bad about it.
data.reading_hint: Go back to imagining a fire drying up some syrup and watch as a tiny little syrup soul cries and is released into the air. Oh no!

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>lantern</radical> with <radical>horns</radical> that can hold <radical>ten thousand</radical> <radical>drop</radical>s of water is sitting on the <radical>ground</radical>. You get closer and realize it's not a lantern, it's a <kanji>bottle</kanji>. It's got horns, and a weird handle, but it's definitely a bottle with water inside of it.
data.meaning_hint: Picture this horned bottle sitting on the ground. You don't know who left it here or why, but it's here and the weirdest looking bottle you've ever seen.
data.reading_mnemonic: Even though you're not the one who left this <kanji>bottle</kanji> here, you decide to do the right thing and throw it in the trash <reading>bin</reading> (<ja>びん</ja>). It's not right to leave a bottle just sitting on the ground, you know.
data.reading_hint: Imagine picking up this weird bottle with your bare hands and putting it in a trash bin. You did your good deed for today! Yay!

data.meaning_mnemonic: You have a <radical>plow</radical> and a (water) <radical>well</radical>. These are the two things you need in order to <kanji>plow</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: You'd think you'd only need a plow, but you also need water if you're going to plow a field, otherwise what's the point?
data.reading_mnemonic: <kanji>plow</kanji>ing all the fields are <ja><reading>こう</reading>いち</ja>s. Not Emperor <ja>こういち</ja>. These are the <ja>こういち</ja> clones the government made, and now they're being put to use.
data.reading_hint: Thousands and thousands of <ja>こういち</ja>s, set free unto the world to do all our <kanji>plow</kanji>ing work.

data.meaning_mnemonic: We must <radical>stop</radical> the <radical>moon</radical>. That, at least, we can come to an <kanji>agreement</kanji> on.
data.meaning_hint: There are a group of people pointing at pictures of the moon coming closer to earth. They are the world's leaders, and although they don't get along normally, this new attack from the moon has united them in agreement: we must stop the moon.
data.reading_mnemonic: "We have <kanji>agreement</kanji>," the world's leaders all say. "We will work together to stop the moon, and we have <kanji>agreement</kanji> on who we will follow, Emperor <ja><reading>こう</reading>いち</ja>.
data.reading_hint: The world has united against the moon, and they have made Emperor <ja>こういち</ja> their temporary leader.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you eat both the <radical>moon</radical> and the <radical>sun</radical> with a <radical>spoon</radical> you'll get <kanji>fat</kanji>. Maybe if you only ate one you could get away with it, but you wanted both and now you're pretty fat.
data.meaning_hint: Picture yourself digging your spoon into the moon, then into the sun, and gulping them both down. Watch your stomach swell with the sun and moon fats. No going back now, gotta finish.
data.reading_mnemonic: Once you're nice and <kanji>fat</kanji>, you look in the mirror to admire your new girth. But that's not you... it's a <reading>shee</reading>p (<ja>し</ja>)!
data.reading_hint: Oh nooo you've turned into a fat sheep! You're actually pretty adorable and round and fluffy, but you liked being a human!

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you look in a <radical>tiger</radical>'s <radical>stomach</radical> you'll find a bunch of <kanji>skin</kanji>. It's really gross but what else did you think you'd find? Everyone knows tigers can't digest the skin of the things it eats.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine yourself opening a tigers mouth and looking all the way down into its stomach and seeing a bunch of skin. Why would you imagine that? Eww.
data.reading_mnemonic: The only person who would try to take <kanji>skin</kanji> from a tiger's stomach is a <reading>foo</reading>l (<ja>ふ</ja>). You'll probably get your head bitten off looking for skin that way.
data.reading_hint: Imagine a fool trying to pull skin out of a tiger's stomach. You can imagine them getting their skin added to the pile too if you want.

data.meaning_mnemonic:
Your <radical>car</radical> is <radical>dry</radical> because you kept it under the <kanji>eaves</kanji> of your house. 

This kanji has a second meaning too: <kanji>house counter</kanji>. Imagine counting all the houses on your block by the number of eaves you see keeping cars dry.
data.meaning_hint: One eave, one house. Two eaves, two houses.
data.reading_mnemonic: On top of the <kanji>eaves</kanji> of your house <reading>Ken</reading> (<ja>けん</ja>) the samurai is counting houses too.
data.reading_hint: Ken hops down and explains that he's been hired to count all the houses in his lord's domain just because his name is the same as the counter for houses. It isn't really fair, he complains to you, as you try to sneak by and lock him out of your house.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>car</radical> that's <radical>lack</radical>ing is really <kanji>soft</kanji>. Cars need to be hard so that things like bugs and other cars wont hurt the people inside when you hit them. But if your car is lacking the hardness it needs, you'll have a really soft, useless car.
data.meaning_hint: Picture a soft car lacking what it needs to drive down the road. It's so soft it just flops down and won't move.
data.reading_mnemonic: This car is probably so <kanji>soft</kanji> because it's made entirely of <reading>naan</reading> (<ja>なん</ja>). Naan may be delicious, but it makes a really crappy car. No wonder it was so soft (and yummy).
data.reading_hint: Picture trying to drive this soft naan car. It probably just sinks into the ground and then gets eaten by wild animals (and me).

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you <radical>mix</radical> a bunch of <radical>building</radical>s together, you have yourself a <kanji>suburb</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Isn't that all a suburb is? Just a mix of a variety of buildings in one area?
data.reading_mnemonic: "<kanji>Suburb</kanji>s are what we need!" says Emperor <ja><reading>こう</reading>いち</ja>.
data.reading_hint: "That suburb life will encourage more people to study kanji," Emperor <ja>こういち</ja> continues.

data.meaning_mnemonic: So my <radical>building</radical> has a big <radical>splinter</radical>, right in the <kanji>corner</kanji>. So what?
data.meaning_hint: Imagine a huge splinter coming out of the corner of the building. It's in a really dangerous spot, but the owner doesn't seem so worried about it.
data.reading_mnemonic: That <kanji>corner</kanji> is dangerous, but what are you going to do, <reading>sue me</reading> (<ja>すみ</ja>)?
data.reading_hint: Actually, please don't sue me. I'll fix the splinter coming out of the corner of my building.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>turkey</radical> sitting on a <radical>stool</radical> is something every ship has in its crow's nest. That's why the universal <kanji>ship counter</kanji> is a turkey on a stool. Not a crow.
data.meaning_hint: Picture yourself counting ships by pointing your finger from one turkey propped up on a stool to the next. You'll be the best ship counter in the world at this rate!
data.reading_mnemonic: Once you become the best <kanji>ship counter</kanji> in the world everyone will think you are super <reading>sexy</reading> (<ja>せき</ja>)! Nothing is sexier than being able to count, and counting ships is the sexiest thing you can count.
data.reading_hint: Imagine yourself, a sexy ship counter. Sexily counting ships. You go guy/girl/non binary person! So sexy!

data.meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>clan</radical> is breaking <radical>ground</radical> and <radical>building</radical> your new <kanji>residence</kanji>. You're all working together to make you a new home!
data.meaning_hint: Picture your clan, working together, to build a new residence for you on their land.
data.reading_mnemonic: Your new <kanji>residence</kanji> is complete! You step closer and the smell of <reading>ta</reading>ter (<ja>てい</ja>) tots hits your nose. Someone is making you tater tots in your new residence. Wait, no they aren't. Your residence is MADE of tater tots! Thank you, clan!
data.reading_hint: Imagine living in a tater tot residence. Whenever you're hungry, you just lean over to the wall and munch.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>buddy</radical> <radical>building</radical> is in the next <kanji>county</kanji>. If it was in your county then it wouldn't be a buddy, it would be a neighbor. You're aware of this building, but they aren't that close, so they're just a buddy.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine looking at a map of your county and the surrounding ones. All of the buildings in the counties next to yours are buddy buildings!
data.reading_mnemonic: Your <kanji>county</kanji> is everything you can reach when shooting a <reading>gun</reading> (<ja>ぐん</ja>). If the bullet can't reach a building you know, it's a buddy building in another county.
data.reading_hint: Imagine taking out a gun and shooting in a random direction. When you find where the bullet landed, you know that's the county line. Though if it gets stuck in a building or a person it doesn't count. You'll have to try again.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Kill a <radical>shrimp</radical> with a <radical>sickle</radical> and you'll need a really good <kanji>explanation</kanji> for yourself. What did that shrimp do to you? Why use a sickle? Well? What's your explanation?
data.meaning_hint: Try to come with an explanation for picking up a sickle and cutting the head off a shrimp with it.
data.reading_mnemonic: In your <kanji>explanation</kanji> you blame everything on <reading>Shaq</reading> (<ja>しゃく</ja>). He told you to do it! It's all Shaq's fault, you explain.
data.reading_hint: Picture Shaq popping into your head as you struggle to come up with an explanation for me. Picture Shaq's face. This is payback for Shaq Fu, you think, as you finalize the rest of the explanation in your mind.

data.meaning_mnemonic: When the <radical>moon</radical> faces the right <radical>direction</radical>, everyone on earth becomes <kanji>obese</kanji>. The pull of the moon moves all the water on earth as well as inside us, so when it faces the right way, we all get super <kanji>fat</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Picture the moon turning to face a different direction. Feel your body start to become really obese. You get huge and round just like the moon.
data.reading_mnemonic: You look around and everyone is <kanji>obese</kanji> like you. You try to reach out to them, but you roll over like a big <reading>bow</reading>ling (<ja>ぼう</ja>) ball. The person next to you does too. Soon you're all rolling around like helpless, obese bowling balls.
data.reading_hint: Picture yourself, as obese and round as a bowling ball, rolling faster and faster down hills. Other people are rolling around you too. You're all screaming. You want the moon to face the other direction so it will stop. You don't like being a human bowling ball!

data.meaning_mnemonic: You wake up in <radical>prison</radical> and there is a <radical>big</radical> <radical>mouth</radical> full of <radical>legs</radical> coming really, really close to your own <radical>mouth</radical> so you <kanji>scream</kanji>! Scream because this is terrifying. Scream because it's all you can think to do.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine a prison where horrible mouth leg creatures are trying to get in your mouth. You don't want to scream because they might get in there, but you can't help it.
data.reading_mnemonic: You <kanji>scream</kanji> and scream and scream until a door bursts open. It's Genghis <reading>Khan</reading> (<ja>かん</ja>) and he looks mad. Apparently your screaming is bothering him and now he's gonna give you a real reason to scream.
data.reading_hint: Imagine Genghis Khan doing something to make you scream. What is it? What could Genghis Khan do that's worse than what's already happening to you?

data.meaning_mnemonic: Everyone knows that when a <radical>woman</radical> plays <radical>football</radical> she becomes a <kanji>princess</kanji>. Thats how princesses are made.
data.meaning_hint: Picture the awesome princess, kicking butt and taking names, out on the football field.
data.reading_mnemonic: Remember the word <ja>姫</ja>? It means <kanji>princess</kanji> too. If you remember the <ja>ひめ</ja> from <ja>姫</ja>, you'll be able to remember this one too.
data.reading_hint: Make sure you know both princess words and you'll know their readings too.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You try to put your <radical>toe</radical> inside a <radical>shellfish</radical>, but it just won't open. That's because this shellfish has sworn an oath of <kanji>chastity</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: "No, I won't open up until I meet the toe I will marry," it says to you.
data.reading_mnemonic: "<kanji>Chastity</kanji> is really important to me," the shellfish says. "But, maybe if you give me a <reading>ta</reading>ter (<ja>てい</ja>) tot, I'll change my mind."
data.reading_hint: You give the shellfish a tater tot, and it breaks its vow of chastity, opening up for your toe. You look the other way, but you can hear the sounds of passion below.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>mysterious</radical> radical and the <kanji>mysterious</kanji> kanji are the same!
data.meaning_hint: Know your radicals, yo!
data.reading_mnemonic: There is no one more <kanji>mysterious</kanji> than <reading>Gen</reading>ji (<ja>げん</ja>). He's tall, dark, handsome, and most of all... <ja>〜</ja>mysterious<ja>〜</ja>!
data.reading_hint:
Who's the mysterious man who's always reciting poetry? Genji!
Who's the mysterious man who gets all the ladies? Genji!
Who's the mysterious man crying over there because someone turned him down? G... Genji...

data.meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Flowers</radical> that grow in a <radical>rice paddy</radical> only live to be <kanji>seedling</kanji>s. Once they sprout, they're plucked away to make room for more rice. Poor little seedlings.
data.meaning_hint: Picture the seedlings growing among the rice plants. Once they bloom they'll be picked, so let's hope they stay small as long as they can.
data.reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>seedling</kanji>s try their best to blend in by referring to themselves as <reading>myou</reading> (<ja>みょう</ja>), you know, me and you combined. That's myou.
data.reading_hint: Listen to the little seedlings say myou over and over. Too bad the farmers can tell they aren't rice plants.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you put two <radical>mustache</radical>s on either side of a <radical>tsunami</radical> it won't know which way to go and spin back and forth until it becomes as <kanji>whirlpool</kanji>. Mustaches are pretty gross, so I don't blame the tsunami for avoiding them.
data.meaning_hint: Picture the tsunami spinning in a circle, trying not to hit the mustaches until it spins itself into a giant whirlpool.
data.reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>whirlpool</kanji> is huge, and it starts pulling things into itself. Oh no, is that my <reading>ca</reading>r (<ja>か</ja>)? Hey, wait! Whirlpool give my car back!
data.reading_hint: Picture my car getting sucked into the whirlpool. Picture me crying as my car disappears into it forever.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A person with <radical>horns</radical> has you on the <radical>ground</radical> and lets loose two <radical>poops</radical> over your <radical>heart</radical>. "<kanji>Mercy</kanji>! Mercy!" You cry, but the horned dude doesn't stop until there are two gross poops sitting on your heart. "M-mercy..." is the only thing you can think to say.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine yourself saying "mercy" over an over as this horned guy has you on the ground and keeps pooping over your heart.
data.reading_mnemonic: As you shout "<kanji>Mercy</kanji>!" one more time, suddenly <reading>Je</reading>sus (<ja>じ</ja>) appears out of no where and punches the horned guy into the stratosphere. Jesus snaps his fingers and the poop is gone and you're off the ground. Your heart is safe.
data.reading_hint: Imagine yourself saying mercy and seeing Jesus appearing just in time to save the day. The word "mercy" must be his bat signal. Jesus signal? Sure.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>spirit</radical>s of the two <radical>tree</radical>s you destroyed with your <radical>jackhammer</radical> live on in the <kanji>collar</kanji> you made out of them.
data.meaning_hint: You took the shredding tree bits and carefully molded them into a nice collar to go with all of your shirts. But now it's haunted.
data.reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>collar</kanji> keeps whispering, "<reading>Eri</reading>c (<ja>えり</ja>)!" into your ear. Your name isn't Eric (I mean it could be, in that case wow, weird, right?), so you assume one of the trees you killed was named Eric. But that's the only name you hear, so maybe they were both named Eric? It's weird.
data.reading_hint: Whenever you put on your collar you hear a constant stream of, "Eric, pssst, hey Eric, hey!" and you just have to pretend it isn't happening.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You put <radical>flowers</radical> on your <radical>scooter</radical> and your <radical>car</radical>. The flowers you put on them are <kanji>lotus</kanji> flowers.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine placing lotuses on top of your scooter and car. They are the right kind of flowers for these vehicles.
data.reading_mnemonic: You're putting a <kanji>lotus</kanji> on both your scooter and car because they are <reading>ren</reading>tals (<ja>れん</ja>).
data.reading_hint: You always put a lotus on top of your rental cars and scooters. Come up with a personal reason why you do this.

data.meaning_mnemonic: There is a special type of meditation where you put a <radical>lid</radical> on your <radical>mouth</radical> and touch your <radical>forehead</radical> down to your <radical>legs</radical>. If you can do this pose, everything in life will become completely <kanji>clear</kanji>. Everything will clear out of your head too. You should try it.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine this pose, imagine everything becoming clear. Clear your mind. Clear your head.
data.reading_mnemonic: Your mind is as <kanji>clear</kanji> as a sparkling clear pond. On this pond you see yourself in a <reading>row</reading> (<ja>りょう</ja>) boat. A single row boat on the clear pond that is now your mind.
data.reading_hint: Picture the row boat on the clear pond in your mind. Watch the clear water flow over the row boat's oars.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you have an <radical>ear</radical> for the <radical>public</radical>'s <radical>heart</radical>, you must be very <kanji>wise</kanji>. You can understand everything the people want, and you know how to give it to them because you listen to their hearts so well.
data.meaning_hint: Close your eyes and open your ears. Feel all of the wise things fill you.
data.reading_mnemonic: All of these <kanji>wise</kanji> things are stored in your <reading>sou</reading>l (<ja>そう</ja>), not your brain. That's where all of these kinds of intuitive feelings live.
data.reading_hint: Picture your wise soul, living inside your body. Somehow it just seems to know what the public really wants. It's like your soul is connected to their souls, granting you this wisdom.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you want to have a <radical>tsunami</radical> at your <radical>wedding</radical>, you need to make sure you have it at the <kanji>bay</kanji>. Anywhere more inland, and the tsunami won't reach it in time.
data.meaning_hint: Picture the tsunami coming towards your beautiful wedding as you stand by the bay. It's not safe, but it's memorable!
data.reading_mnemonic: How did you get a tsunami to show up in the <kanji>bay</kanji> in the first place? By throwing a bunch of <reading>ura</reading>nium (<ja>うら</ja>) in there, of course! Its highly unstable nature can make any body of water, especially a calm bay, turn violent.
data.reading_hint: Imagine throwing buckets of uranium into the bay. It only burns your hands a little. And now they glow green, just like the bay does!

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>dirt</radical> on the <radical>forehead</radical> of a <radical>pig</radical> makes a small <kanji>mound</kanji>. Picture it, if you will. A pig is rooting through the dirt. It lifts its head and there is a mound of dirt right on its forehead.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine that you're the pig. How big can you make your forehead dirt mound?
data.reading_mnemonic: The pig's forehead dirt <kanji>mound</kanji> keeps getting bigger until it's the size of <reading>two cars</reading> (<ja>つか</ja>)! Pigs are big, but you didn't think one could balance a mound the size of two cars on its forehead and not fall over.
data.reading_hint: Picture a pig with a mound of dirt the size of two cars leisurely stomping around on a farm.

data.meaning_mnemonic: This <radical>building</radical> was a <radical>former</radical> <radical>prison</radical> until the <kanji>cave in</kanji>. You see, prisons aren't built very carefully, they just try to get them done fast enough to stuff people in there. So while you can tell this was once a building, it definitely isn't a prison anymore, since the whole thing caved in.
data.meaning_hint: Picture the cave in in your mind. Can you see all the little prisoners and guards being squished as the building tumbles down around them? Oh no!
data.reading_mnemonic: You keep picturing the <kanji>cave in</kanji> and you see Genghis <reading>Khan</reading> (<ja>かん</ja>) climbing over the rubble. He's the one who took down this prison! And he's coming for your town next!
data.reading_hint: Genghis Khan is all about being smart and using better tactics. In this case, why fight a bunch of guards and prisoners when you can just cause a cave in and win immediately? The ol' Khan cave in, a classic war maneuver.

data.meaning_mnemonic:
Under the <radical>window</radical>, you place a <radical>shellfish</radical>, then slam the window shut to <kanji>pierce</kanji> its tough shell. This is the best way to pierce a member of the shellfish family, I promise.

This kanji also has a second meaning. That shellfish you pierced with the window is in two halves now. You can use those halves as plates for sushi. If you count the broken shells you'll know how much sushi you have. That makes them <kanji>sushi counter</kanji>s!
data.meaning_hint: Imagine the window piercing into the shellfish's shell. Then imagine lining up the pieces, putting sushi on them, and counting them all.
data.reading_mnemonic: Now that your shellfish is properly <kanji>pierce</kanji>d and turned into <kanji>sushi counter</kanji>s, you can serve them to Genghis <reading>Khan</reading> (<ja>かん</ja>) and his men. I really hope you counted them correctly too, because there are a lot of them.
data.reading_hint: Carefully count out all the sushi on their pierced shell plates and place them in front of Genghis Khan and his army. As you reach Genghis Khan himself, you realize it's just his ghost, but he's still staring at you as you serve his troops. Ghost or not, you don't want him to pierce you if you mess up.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Take a <radical>leather</radical> <radical>helicopter</radical> to the <radical>moon</radical> to prove your excellent <kanji>leadership</kanji>. Some people called you crazy, but you'll show them, as you lead an entire crew of leather helicopter pilots on their first mission to space!
data.meaning_hint: Not many people have the leadership it takes to lead such a mission. Imagine what it takes to do it!
data.reading_mnemonic: Under your superior <kanji>leadership</kanji> you and your leather helicopter crew are able to make it to the moon. The moon! Your crew is so impressed by your leadership, and their lack of being very dead, and they all start laughing, "<reading>Ha</reading> (<ja>は</ja>) ha ha ha!" They thought they were going to die but you lead them to the moon safely!
data.reading_hint: Imagine laughing along with the crew, in awe at your own leadership skills. Ha ha ha! We didn't die!

data.meaning_mnemonic: I hope all you're doing in the <radical>bathtub</radical> is taking a <kanji>bath</kanji>. I mean, you can do other things if you want I guess. But bathtubs were made just for baths!
data.meaning_hint: Picture yourself taking a bath in your bathtub. Relaxing!
data.reading_mnemonic: When do you miss taking a <kanji>bath</kanji> the most? When you're on the <reading>ro</reading>ad (<ja>ろ</ja>). Traveling is fun and all, but when you're stuck in a car, traveling down a dirt road for days, all you want to do is take a nice long bath.
data.reading_hint: Imagine being stuck on the road all day for a week. Imagine how good a bath will feel when you finally get home. Nice and hot and relaxing. Mmmm...

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you look at <radical>flowers</radical> the first thing you notice are the leaves and petals themselves, then the <radical>next</radical> thing you notice are the <kanji>briar</kanji>s. You never see <kanji>thorn</kanji>s first, only after you've looked at the flowers.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine what you see next after looking at the pretty flowers. The briars are what you see next. Spiky and sharp. It would have been nice if you had seen them first.
data.reading_mnemonic: When you see the <kanji>briar</kanji>s you can't help but yell, <reading>Eee! Ba riars</reading>! (<ja>いばら</ja>)! You pause funny because you prick your finger on one while you're yelling. Ouch!
data.reading_hint: Imagine seeing the briars and yelling out "Ba RI ars!" as you prick your finger on one.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>fingers</radical> grasp this <radical>lid</radical> and when you raise it you see a <radical>poop</radical> <radical>turkey</radical> (a turkey covered in poop). You can't help yourself, you <kanji>embrace</kanji> the turkey.
data.meaning_hint: Someone was obviously going to cook this poop turkey in a pot, and if you hadn't looked under this lid it surely would have died. Now as you embrace it you can hear the turkey weeping softly.
data.reading_mnemonic: As you <kanji>embrace</kanji> the sad turkey it makes a funny sound and suddenly starts pooping <reading>yo</reading>gurt (<ja>よう</ja>) all over you. But you don't want to stop embracing it! It's probably just scared still. But the more you squeeze, the faster the yogurt comes out of it!
data.reading_hint: Imagine embracing the turkey as it covers you in yogurt poo. You hope it's yogurt at least. You aren't gonna taste it to find out. Maybe. Okay you might taste it a little.

data.meaning_mnemonic: There was once a <radical>melon</radical> <radical>child</radical>, that is, a child with the body of a melon. When he was born, his parents didn't want him, so he became an <kanji>orphan</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: The "melon boy orphan," is what they called him. Imagine a melon (your favorite kind) with a face and arms and legs sticking out. He walks up to you and says "hello kind person, could you help an orphan?"
data.reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>orphan</kanji> melon boy is but a <ja><reading>子</reading></ja> (<ja>こ</ja>).
data.reading_hint: That's the sad thing about the melon orphan boy... he's just a child. "Hello gov, I'm just a child," he says to you.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You give a bunch of <radical>shellfish</radical> to a <radical>clown</radical> as <kanji>compensation</kanji>. The clown did you some favors, and everyone knows clowns only accept shellfish as a form of currency. So your compensation is a pile of random shellfish.
data.meaning_hint: Picture the shellfish in your hands. Imagine handing them over to the clown as compensation for the unspeakable acts you had him do for you.
data.reading_mnemonic: Once the clown has been properly <kanji>compensate</kanji>d, he looks you in the eyes, one hand full of shellfish, the other in the air, and waves, "<reading>Bye</reading> (<ja>ばい</ja>)" he says. "Bye, bye."
data.reading_hint: All you have to do is give him the right amount of compensation and you'll hear his sweet "bye, bye." Then you never have to see him again.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The famous <radical>gold</radical> <radical>triceratops</radical> <radical>shellfish</radical> is good for only one thing, and that's being made into <kanji>chain</kanji>s. They link their triceratops horns together and form an unbreakable gold chain. You can't eat them, because they're gold. So they're only really good for their chaining together ability.
data.meaning_hint: Picture these little gold triceratops shellfish linked together by their horns in a chain around your neck. Feel them hanging there. Sparkly and cold.
data.reading_mnemonic: However, the only way to break the <kanji>chain</kanji> is to <reading>saw</reading> (<ja>さ</ja>) it open. Once the triceratops shellfish start holding on, they never let go. So when you want to take the chain off you have to really hack at it with your saw.
data.reading_hint: Picture the saw in your hands, sawing back and forth on the gold chain around your neck. Maybe this isn't the best fashion accessory if you have to use a saw to get it off.

data.meaning_mnemonic: From your <radical>mouth</radical> comes a <radical>cross</radical>, some <radical>flowers</radical>, and <radical>shellfish</radical>. It all <kanji>erupt</kanji>s from your mouth!
data.meaning_hint: Imagine these three things coming out of your mouth not one at a time, but all together like an eruption. Perhaps you're laying on your back, and they burst out of your mouth.
data.reading_mnemonic: When do inanimate objects <kanji>erupt</kanji> from your mouth? Mostly when you're having <reading>fun</reading> (<ja>ふん</ja>).
data.reading_hint: It's really inconvenient that things erupt from your mouth whenever you're having fun. Makes it hard to have fun.

data.meaning_mnemonic: When a <radical>spirit</radical> lives in a <radical>sheep</radical> it becomes the most <kanji>auspicious</kanji> creature on the planet. Lights shine out of it and the whole world weeps at its beauty. Look at the sheep's fluffy glowing head. Nothing could be more auspicious and glorious than this.
data.meaning_hint: Picture this auspicious spirit sheep. Blessing the children with its fluffy hooves.
data.reading_mnemonic: The spirit sheep is so <kanji>auspicious</kanji> that the <reading>Shou</reading>gun (<ja>しょう</ja>) declares this day to be the most auspicious of all days. The day when the spirit sheep appeared.
data.reading_hint: Picture the Shougun telling the world that they must fly spirit sheep flags on this day forever, because of how auspicious it is.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you take a <radical>cow</radical>'s <radical>life</radical> you're turning it into an <kanji>offering</kanji>. In the old days, cows' lives were given to the gods as offerings pretty often.
data.meaning_hint: Picture yourself offering the cow's life up to the god(s). It's a good thing we don't actually have to do this anymore, you think.
data.reading_mnemonic: You prepare the <kanji>offering</kanji> with your holy blue <reading>sa</reading>ber (<ja>せい</ja>). Normally this would be gruesome, but your saber glows and the cow's life shoots up into the sky without you laying a hand on it.
data.reading_hint: Thanks to the mercy of your saber, the offering is quick and painless. A normal saber, however, would have cut that cow to bits. Like, really just wrecked it. Good thing we didn't make you think about that, huh?

data.meaning_mnemonic: If a <radical>grain</radical> has a <radical>fault</radical>, it needs to be put back in <kanji>order</kanji>. Grains must be perfectly identical at all times, otherwise they'll be thrown out. That's why special people will go out and check them to confirm their <kanji>regularity</kanji>. Keeping order is a tough job!
data.meaning_hint: Imagine being one of these people who maintain order by going out in the fields and inspecting every single grain, keeping the good ones and plucking off the ones with faults.
data.reading_mnemonic: You can always tell if a company keeps <kanji>order</kanji> or if it <reading>cheats</reading> (<ja>ちつ</ja>) just by looking at the grains.
data.reading_hint: If there are faulty grains in there, they cheated and order was not maintained. Now you have to go through all the grains and throw out the weird ones yourself.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you have <radical>spider</radical>s in your <radical>mouth</radical>, then you're going to <kanji>instigate</kanji> fights between people. Mostly because the spider in your mouth makes you grumpy, but also because the spider keeps telling you to be an instigator with its little mouth inside your own mouth.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine having a spider in your mouth. Imagine being angry about it and instigating fights between people because of it.
data.reading_mnemonic: The spider in your mouth tells you to <kanji>instigate</kanji> a fight by <reading>saw</reading>ing (<ja>さ</ja>) the other person's leg off. It even whispers where you can find a nice big saw.
data.reading_hint: Picture the fight you and the spider instigated. The guy pointing at the saw, then pointing at his sawed off leg. Listen as the spider tells you to shake your head.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Play your <radical>drum</radical> under the <radical>moon</radical> and your <radical>hair</radical> will <kanji>swell</kanji>! The more you play and the longer it's under the moon, the larger your hair will swell.
data.meaning_hint: Have you been suffering from flat, boring hair? Well do I have the swelling treatment you've been looking for!
data.reading_mnemonic: Using this method, your hair <kanji>swell</kanji>s so much it looks like a giant <reading>bow</reading>ling (<ja>ぼう</ja>) ball is sitting on top of your head. It's all round, and well... swollen is probably the only word that fits.
data.reading_hint: Imagine watching your hair swell to the size of a large bowling ball. Imagine never being able to go bowling again because the comparison is too easy for people to make.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you point <radical>flowers</radical> in the same <radical>direction</radical> you'll be able to smell their wonderful <kanji>perfume</kanji>. The best way to get perfume out of flowers is to make them face the same way. Then the smell will go the same direction, making you smell great.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine aiming a bunch of flowers in the same direction towards you. The perfume coats your body. You smell great now!
data.reading_mnemonic: You decide to <kanji>perfume</kanji> your entire <reading>ho</reading>me (<ja>ほう</ja>) by planting flowers all the way around it, all facing in toward it.
data.reading_hint: Now when you're in your home the overwhelming smell of perfume assaults your nostrils. It's actually... really strong. Oh... oh no it's too strong, you can't breathe. And you live alone. Help! Someone!

data.meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>soul</radical> is like the <radical>ground</radical> or the <radical>dawn</radical>. It is <kanji>constant</kanji>, never changing.
data.meaning_hint: Think of some other things your soul is like, but always make sure you come back to one word: constant.
data.reading_mnemonic: Also <kanji>constant</kanji> is the Emperor <ja><reading>こう</reading>いち</ja>, who will surely rule for a thousand more years!
data.reading_hint: A constant rule from Emperor <ja>こういち</ja> means constant kanji learning and constant WaniKani reviews. They will always be constant!

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>leader</radical> puts their <radical>hat</radical> on the <radical>ground</radical> next to a <radical>bookshelf</radical>. This is a test in <kanji>ethics</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: People hang around the bookshelf, and the leader wants to see if anyone will steal the hat or not. That's why its a test of ethics.
data.reading_mnemonic: To test your <kanji>ethics</kanji> even more, the leader puts down a <reading>rin</reading>g (<ja>りん</ja>) as well.
data.reading_hint: Now we'll really see how everyone's ethics are. Will they turn in the ring to lost in found? will they ignore it? Will they steal it?

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>building</radical> to the <radical>east</radical> is an <kanji>exhibit</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: It's a pretty large building and you can see inside to all of the different exhibits within the main exhibit.
data.reading_mnemonic: Right now the <kanji>exhibit</kanji> has a bunch of <reading>chin</reading>s (<ja>ちん</ja>) on display. Animal chins, human chins, every chin you can think of is in the exhibit.
data.reading_hint: Go up to the first exhibit and look very closely at some turtle chins, then some crab chins, then some alligator chins. This is weirdly familiar.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Shaving the <radical>hair</radical> off a <radical>geoduck</radical> before you try to eat it is absolutely <kanji>necessary</kanji>. If you don't, the hair will get caught in your throat and you'll choke. It is necessary that you remove the hair.
data.meaning_hint: Picture the page in your cookbook where it says "Shaving the hair off your geoduck = Necessary!!" It's absolutely necessary that you follow that instruction!
data.reading_mnemonic: It is also <kanji>necessary</kanji> that you wear a <reading>su</reading>it (<ja>す</ja>) when eating shaved geoduck. It's a super fancy meal so a suit is necessary for you to enjoy it correctly.
data.reading_hint: What's necessary? To shave the hair off your geoduck and to wear a suit. That's not too hard. You should do it.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>leader</radical> of the <radical>library</radical> thinks that all the books in their library are better than everyone else's books. He's a very <kanji>biased</kanji> person. If he wasn't the leader of that specific library he'd probably feel differently.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine showing the leader your favorite book. "That's not a book in MY library," he says, and throws it in the trash. That's so biased! He didn't even give it a shot!
data.reading_mnemonic: You decide to give in to his <kanji>biased</kanji> recommendations and look at what he has in his library. It doesn't take long until you realize that these books are all about <reading>hen</reading>s (<ja>へん</ja>) and hen care. This guy is so biased about his favorite books that he only filled his library with what HE wants to read. And apparently that thing is taking care of hens... weird.
data.reading_hint: "This is such biased crap," you say, as you finish reading the title of a book called "Hens are better than all other birds." Screw this leader guy and his books.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>scooter</radical> gave you a <radical>splinter</radical>, so you had to go in for <kanji>treatment</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine how bad a scooter splinter would be! You would need special treatment for that.
data.reading_mnemonic: After you get <kanji>treatment</kanji>, you feel really <reading>goo</reading>d (<ja>ぐう</ja>).
data.reading_hint: Not just "good," but "goooooood." Emphasize the long vowel for the long vowel in <ja>ぐう</ja>. You feel this way because when you went in for treatment, they gave you the good, good drugs. You know the ones.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>rice</radical> that's prepared at <radical>dawn</radical> by the <radical>village</radical> are <kanji>provisions</kanji> for the army. The army is scheduled to arrive right after dawn, so all of the village's provisions for them have to be ready by then.
data.meaning_hint: Picture everyone in the village getting all of their rice together as provisions for the army. Even the kids and old people are helping out.
data.reading_mnemonic: Once all of the <kanji>provisions</kanji> are ready, the soldiers show up in their <reading>row</reading> (<ja>りょう</ja>) boats and load it all up. But they aren't done there. "Rice isn't enough, we need <reading>roe</reading> (<ja>ろう</ja>) so we will have the strength to row our row boats back." And so the village brings them all of their roe too.
data.reading_hint: Picture the soldiers gobbling down their provisions of rice and roe in their row boats as they row away.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If the <radical>yakuza</radical> <radical>slide</radical> you into a <radical>jet</radical>, things are <kanji>especially</kanji> bad for you. Not just normal bad, like, especially bad.
data.meaning_hint: First of all, the yakuza have you, that's bad already. But they're sliding you into their jet? That means you aren't upright, you might even be knocked out or dead. That's especially worrying, don't you think?
data.reading_mnemonic: You're <kanji>especially</kanji> worried now, because they're putting you in some kind of <reading>chu</reading>te (<ja>しゅ</ja>). You already took a slide in here, and now you're teetering over the edge of a dark, steep chute into who knows where!
data.reading_hint: As you slide down the chute, it's especially dark. And especially scary. And especially bad! How did this happen to you?!

data.meaning_mnemonic: If your <radical>soul</radical> is acting like the <radical>sun</radical> trapped in a <radical>net</radical> sitting on a <radical>stool</radical>, then people will <kanji>ridicule</kanji> you for your <kanji>laziness</kanji>. You're just sitting there, trapped and not moving.
data.meaning_hint: Your soul just doesn't want to move or do anything though... and that may look like laziness, but you can't help it. You wish your friends and family wouldn't ridicule you. You're going through enough, internally.
data.reading_mnemonic: When people <kanji>ridicule</kanji> you, when you can't stop the <kanji>laziness</kanji>, you read <reading>man</reading>ga (<ja>まん</ja>). Manga helps you feel better about the mean things people say. Manga helps you feel like you're doing something, and that you aren't just a lazy person.
data.reading_hint: Picture yourself reading manga and watch as the people who ridicule you and call you lazy fade away into the background. You're going to be okay.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you figure out how to use a <radical>tsunami</radical> as a <radical>weapon</radical>, everyone is going to <kanji>die</kanji>. You can't control a tsunami, you fool. Now you've doomed us all.
data.meaning_hint: Picture everyone in the world being swept away in a tsunami to die. This is what happens when you try to use nature as a weapon.
data.reading_mnemonic: The only way to maybe not <kanji>die</kanji> is to find <reading>boats</reading> (<ja>ぼつ</ja>). As long as the boats don't get smashed by the tsunami, you might be able to cheat death by holding onto the boats and not drowning.
data.reading_hint: You don't want to die, do you? Get to the boats!

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you give a <radical>machine</radical> a <radical>heart</radical> it will get <kanji>lazy</kanji>. Hearts give us emotions and with emotions we become weak. Why would a machine with a heart want to work anymore? Nah. It's lazy time now.
data.meaning_hint: Picture a machine with a heart, laying on the couch, eating oil snacks, and snoozing. What a lazy machine!
data.reading_mnemonic: The machine is so <kanji>lazy</kanji> it won't even wear its <reading>tie</reading> (<ja>たい</ja>) anymore. That was the only official thing left about it, but now it's as lazy as a human. Would a lazy human put on a tie? I don't think so.
data.reading_hint: Picture the lazy machine sitting on the couch again. There are untied ties all over the floor.
