data.reading_hint: Picture a bunch of muddy ducks munching on some muddy trapped insects, in a some muddy leftover tsunami water.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You're walking down the street when you see <radical>twenty</radical> <radical>big</radical> <radical>cross</radical>es lined up in front of you. Crosses creep you out and this is way too many for you to keep walking so you decide to <kanji>run</kanji> as fast as you can to get past them.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine trying to run down a street with twenty big crosses lining it. It's so scary that you keep running faster and faster as you go.
data.reading_mnemonic: You figure since you're already on the <kanji>run</kanji> that you might as well <reading>hone</reading> (<ja>ほん</ja>) your running skills while you make your way down this scary, cross lined street.
data.reading_hint: Imagine distracting yourself from the scary crosses by honing your running skills while you do it.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You see a <radical>triceratops</radical> standing in front of a full <radical>moon</radical> and you can't help but see a really strong <kanji>resemblance</kanji>. The triceratops has that round frill thing behind its horns and it looks just like the round full moon. Who knew that a triceratops would resemble the moon!
data.meaning_hint: Look at the triceratops. Now look at the moon. See the resemblance? Uncanny, don't you think?
data.reading_mnemonic: The first person to see this <kanji>resemblance</kanji> was the <reading>Shou</reading>gun (<ja>しょう</ja>). That's why he decided to put a triceratops head with the moon behind it on his mon (family crest). Now he's known as the full moon dinosaur shogun, and he's very famous.
data.reading_hint: Imagine being the Shougun and seeing the resemblance between a triceratops and the moon for the first time. You'd put that on all your stuff too, if you were him.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tree</radical> is stuck in a <radical>prison</radical> under the <radical>ground</radical> and it's starting to <kanji>rot</kanji> and <kanji>decay</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Trees can't live without sunlight, and it's too damp underground in a prison. The water gets all moldy and the tree will rot and die.
data.reading_mnemonic: You get close to the <kanji>rot</kanji>ting tree and see some rotten <reading>cu</reading>cumbers (<ja>きゅう</ja>) hanging from its branches. No!
data.reading_hint: This poor cucumber tree, left in this ground prison to rot. There's nothing worse than eating a rotten cucumber.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>samurai</radical> puts his <radical>forehead</radical> on the <radical>table</radical> next to his <radical>weapon</radical>. He is just a <kanji>husk</kanji> of his former self. This <kanji>shell</kanji> of a samurai has nothing left.
data.meaning_hint: He's just sitting there, he can't even pick up his weapon or raise his head anymore.
data.reading_mnemonic: The only way to bring a <kanji>husk</kanji> of a samurai back to life is to have a <reading>cock</reading> (<ja>かく</ja>) crow right in his ear.
data.reading_hint: "Co co co co cooooock!" the cock screams, shocking the samurai back into his lifeless shell. You did it!

data.meaning_mnemonic: If someone gives you a <radical>sock</radical> you should <kanji>receive</kanji> it and thank them. You can't just say no or put the sock on the ground and walk away. You should always receive a sock properly, with both hands, when it's handed to you.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine Dobby reaching out to receive his first sock. Don't you want to be happy like that too?
data.reading_mnemonic: The best place to <kanji>receive</kanji> a sock is in <ja><reading>きょう</reading>と</ja>. They're famous for their sock stores and schoolgirls who have too many socks. If you walk down the street someone is bound to try to hand you a sock in <ja>きょうと</ja>, and you should receive it happily.
data.reading_hint: Imagine standing in <ja>きょうと</ja> and receiving sock after sock. People just keep giving and you keep receiving!

data.meaning_mnemonic: You have to reach a certain <radical>number</radical> of <radical>flowers</radical> and <radical>tsunami</radical>s hits to become a legitimate <kanji>fiefdom</kanji>. At least in the old days. If you don't meet one of these conditions, like if you get hit by tsunamis all the time but you only have two or three flowers that will grow, you can't be your own fiefdom.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine being the person who has to check whether each fiefdom has enough flowers and tsunamis per year to keep their status.
data.reading_mnemonic: The most famous <kanji>fiefdom</kanji> checker is <reading>Han</reading> (<ja>はん</ja>) Solo. He takes his Millennium Falcon and swoops around checking for flowers and signs of past tsunamis and then he'll either say you can or cannot be your own fiefdom. Thanks Han Solo!
data.reading_hint: Picture Han Solo flying around Japan checking to make sure all the fiefdoms are up to code.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>sweet</radical> <radical>woman</radical> sits under a <radical>tree</radical> and works as a <kanji>mediator</kanji>. If you're having a fight with someone, bring them to the sweet woman under the tree and she'll mediate for the two of you. Problem solved! Thanks sweet lady!
data.meaning_hint: Imagine the sweet tree woman being a mediator for you and your arch rival. What she says fixes everything between you two!
data.reading_mnemonic: You go to pay the woman for being your <kanji>mediator</kanji> for you two but she just says, "<reading>Bye</reading> <ja>ばい</ja>)." You try to hand her some money and she stares into your eyes. "Bye." Oh... okay, bye then.
data.reading_hint: Imagine her refusing to let you pay her for her mediator services and just saying "bye" over and over until you leave. Weird.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>husband</radical> was wearing his <radical>cleats</radical> when he accidentally stepped on a <radical>bird</radical>. Luckily this particular bird is a <kanji>chicken</kanji>, and chickens are really durable!
data.meaning_hint: Picture the sad, stepped on chicken. It's angrily clucking and chasing your husband around your yard for what he did.
data.reading_mnemonic: The only way to stop the <kanji>chicken</kanji> from putting on your husband's cleats and stepping on him to death in revenge is to feed it the <reading>ca</reading>ke (<ja>けい</ja>) you were making.
data.reading_hint: This cake was for your husband, but now he gets nothing. The chicken gets to eat all of the cake in front of him instead.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you want to take a <radical>flag</radical> out of the <radical>mouth</radical> of a <radical>mantis</radical> you have to make a formal <kanji>request</kanji> first. Mantises don't like to just give things away, and they're kind of mean so if you try to steal the flag it will probably bite you. So make a formal, polite request if you want it.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine trying to request a flag from a scary mantis that has it sitting in it's mouth. Will it give it to you? Will it bite you? You'll have to wait and see.
data.reading_mnemonic: After you <kanji>request</kanji> the mantis give you its flag it <reading>shock</reading>s (<ja>しょく</ja>) you by actually spitting it out of its mouth at your feet. You didn't think your request would work, or even if the mantis understood human speech, but it shocked you by doing exactly what you asked!
data.reading_hint: Imagine your shock at finding out the mantis not only understood your request, but agreed! This is great but also makes you wonder what other creatures can understand you...

data.meaning_mnemonic: When your <radical>scooter</radical> has a <radical>fault</radical>, you need to get an <kanji>alternate</kanji>. Hopefully your insurance will cover it too.
data.meaning_hint: You have a scooter that you drive every single day, but if you notice a fault, you need to send it in to get it fixed. That's when you break out your alternate scooter.
data.reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>alternate</kanji> scooter is made entirely of <ja><reading>鉄</reading></ja> (<ja>てつ</ja>). It's hard and cold and not very comfortable when you sit on it. That's why you chose to keep it as an alternate and not as your everyday scooter.
data.reading_hint: Imagine riding on your alternate <ja>鉄</ja> scooter. Feel the hard iron under your bum and the loud sounds it makes as you scoot down the street. I hope your normal scooter is fixed soon.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The only <radical>tree</radical> a <radical>turkey</radical> will live in is an <kanji>oak</kanji> tree. They really only do this because oak trees have really yummy acorns and turkeys loooove acorns.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine seeing a turkey sitting in an oak tree munching on acorns. You didn't even know turkeys could fly, but it got up there somehow.
data.reading_mnemonic: If you see a bunch of <kanji>oak</kanji>s but no turkeys just yell, "<reading>SOOEY</reading> (<ja>つい</ja>)!" and they'll all come jumping out! Just because you can't see a turkey in there doesn't mean there isn't one!
data.reading_hint: Imagine standing in a grove of oak trees and yelling SOOEY! SOOOOOEY! Now watch as hundreds of turkeys come flying at your face! They think you have more acorns for them. RUN!

data.meaning_mnemonic: Put <radical>thread</radical> in the <radical>mouth</radical> of a worm while the <radical>moon</radical> is out and it will poop out some <kanji>silk</kanji>. That's why they call them silkworms, didn't you know? But it has to be while the moon is out, otherwise normal thread will come right back out the other end of the worm. The moon is what makes the magic happen.
data.meaning_hint: Picture feeding some thread into the mouth of a worm as the light from the full moon shines in on you. See the silk come out of the worm's butt and into your hands.
data.reading_mnemonic: The biggest fan of <kanji>silk</kanji> is <reading>Ken</reading> (<ja>けん</ja>) the samurai. Everything he wears is silk, even his armor.
data.reading_hint: Picture Ken with a silk helmet, silk fundoshi, and a silk sheath for his sword.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>building</radical> <radical>clown</radical> is the only clown allowed to <kanji>accompany</kanji> you. You hate all clowns, and so does the rest of your town. But this clown is really good at building buildings, and he's allowed to leave his part of town and accompany you while you fix buildings together.
data.meaning_hint: I know it's been a long time, but try not to mix this one up with 	<ja>部</ja>, if you can. Remember, the clown building is in another part of town and the clowns aren't supposed to leave. But the building clown is okay to accompany you through the rest of the city.
data.reading_mnemonic: He can only <kanji>accompany</kanji> you for so long though and soon it's time to say <reading>bye</reading> (<ja>ばい</ja>) again.
data.reading_hint: Wave bye to the clown, he'll accompany you on your building job tomorrow, but right now he has to go home and be with the rest of his clown people. He can't accompany you after dark.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>clown</radical> takes a <radical>knife</radical> and <kanji>divide</kanji>s himself. First he divides himself into two pieces, then he's in four pieces, then... oh why won't he stop?!
data.meaning_hint: Instead of dying, the clown divides into slightly thinner clowns.
data.reading_mnemonic: The clown finally stops trying to <kanji>divide</kanji> himself, and you can't stand to look at all of him. You grab a <reading>bow</reading>ling (<ja>ぼう</ja>) ball and bowl all of his divided parts over!
data.reading_hint: The many clowns crash to the floor as the bowling ball plows through their... his(?) divided bodies. You can't bear to look anymore.

data.meaning_mnemonic:
If you <radical>say</radical> the <radical>lineup</radical> of your family members that have lived on this earth under the <radical>sun</radical>, you're really explaining your <kanji>genealogy</kanji>.

This kanji has a second meaning too. It means score. So if you're <radical>say</radical>ing the <radical>line up</radical> of what happened today under the <radical>sun</radical> you're really just saying the <kanji>score</kanji> of a game. So which is it? Are you talking about the past or something that happened today? That's what makes the difference.
data.meaning_hint: Say the line up of what happened under the sun. It's the genealogy of your family or the score of your game!
data.reading_mnemonic: if you can't tell the difference between your <kanji>genealogy</kanji> and a game's <kanji>score</kanji> you're a <reading>foo</reading>l (<ja>ふ</ja>) and I can't help you. You aren't a fool, are you? You know the difference.
data.reading_hint: Your family genealogy and your game's score aren't even close to being the same thing. Memorize these or everyone will think you're a fool.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You can only manage to avoid a <radical>tsunami</radical> by standing <radical>above</radical> it on a <radical>small</radical> <radical>stool</radical> if you are very <kanji>graceful</kanji>. If you aren't graceful enough the tsunami will knock you and the stool over and you'll be swept away like everyone else.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine being graceful enough to balance on a small stool above a raging tsunami! Sooo cool!
data.reading_mnemonic: No matter how <kanji>graceful</kanji> you are, the still tsunami <reading>shook</reading> (<ja>しゅく</ja>) the small stool. That's where your gracefulness came in. The stool shook, but you didn't. You balanced yourself and refused to go down.
data.reading_hint: It doesn't matter how badly the stool shook, you stayed graceful and didn't fall!

data.meaning_mnemonic: You hoist your <radical>towel</radical> above your <radical>table</radical>, <radical>drop</radical> into the water and <kanji>sail</kanji> away. You turned the towel into an actual sail and you're balancing on top of the table, which is now a boat.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine sailing out into the open sea, drops of water hitting your face, as the towel sail catches the air and carries you away.
data.reading_mnemonic: As you <kanji>sail</kanji> off into the ocean you hear a familiar voice shout out, "Ahoy!" <reading>Han</reading> (<ja>はん</ja>) Solo calls. He's also got a towel sail, but it's on the Millennium Falcon, which is half-submerged in the water.
data.reading_hint: You sail nervously past Han Solo who also seems to be sailing, though in worse shape than you. But he keeps throwing you finger guns so you figure it's best to just sail on and pretend this never happened.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You see a <radical>soul</radical> on a <radical>cross</radical> covered in <radical>flowers</radical> with <radical>shellfish</radical> at its feet and you suddenly <kanji>resent</kanji> them. It's not like you want to be the one up there on the cross, but so many people left flowers and shellfish for them. It should have been you...
data.meaning_hint: Picture the soul on the cross, flowers all around it and shellfish at its feet. Feel your resentment grow.
data.reading_mnemonic: You realize you <kanji>resent</kanji> them because it looks like they're having <reading>fun</reading> (<ja>ふん</ja>). You aren't having fun, and you wanna be! How dare they have fun when you aren't!
data.reading_hint: You wanna have fun hanging out on a cross with flowers and all the shellfish you can eat. Your resentment grows and grows as you watch the soul having everything you suddenly want.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Pour all of your <radical>alcohol</radical> in the <radical>pool</radical> to <kanji>serve</kanji> all your guests at once! They can all help themselves to as much or as little alcohol as they want! What a great idea!
data.meaning_hint: Imagine serving all of your guests their alcohol by dumping it all in the pool! Now jump in and drink all you want!
data.reading_mnemonic: As you <kanji>serve</kanji> your guests (and yourself) you look over and see <reading>Shaq</reading> (<ja>しゃく</ja>) also trying to serve them. And by serving I mean getting served because he's throwing them into the pool.
data.reading_hint: Picture Shaq serving your guests by tossing them into your alcohol filled pool. Thanks, Shaq... I guess.

data.meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Gambler</radical>s usually only see the <radical>sun</radical> at <kanji>dawn</kanji>. They gamble all day and through the night, and if they leave it's at the crack of dawn to get home, clean up, and then go back. I haven't known a gambler who's seen the sun ... well ever!
data.meaning_hint: Imagine being a gambler and seeing the bright dawn sun when you come out of the casino or pachinko parlor. It burns your eyes! Evil dawn, get back inside quick!
data.reading_mnemonic: If you're up at <kanji>dawn</kanji> you'll also see the <ja><reading>あか</reading></ja> (red) <ja><reading>つき</reading></ja> (moon). The <ja>あかつき</ja> only happens as the sun comes up at dawn so usually only gamblers see it. But if you get up early, you can see it too!
data.reading_hint: Imagine getting up at dawn and seeing the <ja>あかつき</ja> in the sky near the sun. It's so beautiful!

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>leader</radical> does a <radical>dance</radical> on top of the <radical>tree</radical> to show his <kanji>greatness</kanji> to everyone around. If he dances all the way up there on top of the tree, then no one can deny his <kanji>excellence</kanji>!
data.meaning_hint: "Look upon your leader's greatness!" he shouts, doing a jig around on the branches.
data.reading_mnemonic: If you don't recognize the leader's <kanji>greatness</kanji> he will throw <reading>ketsu</reading>p (<ja>けつ</ja>) all over you (it's a special mix of ketchup and catsup). And it's ketsup because it looks like blood. The blood he'll spill if you don't look up and clap at his great dancing.
data.reading_hint: "Oh leader, your greatness is so... great!" you shout up at him. He's holding the ketsup bottle over your head and staring into your eyes as he dances in the tree. He isn't sure if he wants to dump it on you yet. He isn't sure if you really recognize his excellence.

data.meaning_mnemonic: This is a <radical>gold</radical> <radical>roof</radical>, <radical>correct</radical>? It's important to <kanji>lock</kanji> it up, then.
data.meaning_hint: It's only natural that you'd want to lock a gold roof so nobody can steal it.
data.reading_mnemonic: The person who <kanji>lock</kanji>ed the gold roof was <reading>Jou</reading>rm (<ja>じょう</ja>).
data.reading_hint: He's the big farmhand who turned out to be an undercover Viking in your town, only to pillage and destroy everything. Under the gold roof is where he locked up all your village's valuables, after wiping you all out.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you touch <radical>ice</radical> for too long you'll get <radical>frostbite</radical> and that's a really hard thing to <kanji>endure</kanji>. A lot of people can't, and die. Then again, you managed to endure touching ice long enough to get frostbite in the first place, so maybe this is baby stuff for you.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine having to endure the pain of frostbite because you were a jerk who put his hand on ice for a few hours.
data.reading_mnemonic: The best people in the world at being able to <kanji>endure</kanji> the pain are the <reading>shino</reading>bi (<ja>しの</ja>) ninjas! They train by hanging out in frozen areas all the time and don't complain at all. Maybe if the pain gets to be too much you can go ask them for advice.
data.reading_hint: Imagine if you were one of these cool Shinobi ninjas that could endure the extreme cold and pain of frostbite!

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>king</radical> <radical>rake</radical>d all the <radical>mountain</radical>s down into flat land so he could see everyone in the kingdom from his castle windows. You should share your <kanji>congratulations</kanji> with him. Now, quick tell him this was a great idea.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine saying "Congratulations!" to a king who just ordered his servants to rake down all the pretty mountains in his kingdom.
data.reading_mnemonic: The moment you say "<kanji>Congratulations</kanji>!" you've already started to <reading>miss</reading> (<ja>みず</ja>) those beautiful mountains. But you can't let missing them ruin your congratulations! Don't let the king know!
data.reading_hint: Imagine how hollow your congratulation sounds when you really miss those mountains. This king doesn't deserve your nice words.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>flowers</radical> that grow on your <radical>roof</radical> that look like a sleeping <radical>bear</radical> is <kanji>sedge</kanji>. Sedge grow all over the world!
data.meaning_hint: You've probably seen them before, you just didn't know what they were called! Looks like a green sleeping bear bum, right?
data.reading_mnemonic: The next time you see a <kanji>sedge</kanji> bite into it. It tastes like <reading>suga</reading>r (<ja>すが</ja>)! Luckily, it don't taste like bear.
data.reading_hint: Imagine biting into a sedge flower and tasting the yummy sugary taste. Mmmm.

data.meaning_mnemonic: As the <radical>tsunami</radical> hits your <radical>scooter</radical> and your <radical>car</radical>, it alters the wave, creating <kanji>ripples</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: They're hard to see because a tsunami is pretty big, but your scooter and car do create ripples in the water as it goes past.
data.reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Ripples</kanji> come off of your scooter and car from when they were hit by a tsunami. More importantly, those things were <reading>ren</reading>tals (<ja>れん</ja>), so ripples or not, it doesn't matter if they were hit by a tsunami.
data.reading_hint: As you watch the ripples come off your car / scooter, be sure to imagine the relief you'd feel if you knew they were rentals and not something owned by you.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>king</radical> wants you to make a <radical>rocket</radical> that looks <kanji>glassy</kanji>. It won't be very stable, and it probably won't work, but making it glassy and pretty is the only way to make the king approve.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine a king who won't accept a rocket that isn't made of glassy material. He's not very smart...
data.reading_mnemonic: You take the <kanji>glassy</kanji> rocket and try to stuff some thin <reading>reed</reading>s (<ja>り</ja>) inside to support it. But because it's clear and glassy the king sees them at the last second.
data.reading_hint: Picture the king admiring himself in the glassy surface and then his face contorts. He smashes his fist through the rocket and rips out the reeds. "REEDS AREN'T GLASSY!" he cries, and starts hitting you with them.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Going from a <radical>scooter</radical> to a <radical>helicopter</radical> that's <radical>big</radical> even for yourself (<radical>oneself</radical>), is huge <kanji>transition</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: It's an upward transition, so that's nice, but it's still going to take you a long time to get used to using a big helicopter instead of a scooter.
data.reading_mnemonic: You decide one <kanji>transition</kanji> isn't enough, so you transition to a <reading>cen</reading>taur (<ja>せん</ja>) too. Now you're a big half horse-half human creature and you'll fit in the big helicopter better.
data.reading_hint: A centaur is just a human halfway between transitioning into a horse, so it isn't even that hard to do!

data.meaning_mnemonic: You have to use your <radical>fingers</radical> to make an <radical>exit</radical> because you're so <kanji>clumsy</kanji>. You can't seem to get the door to open, your hands just slip around on the nob uselessly. Instead, you take your fingers and stick them into the door frame, pulling the whole thing off the hinges so you can leave.
data.meaning_hint: Of course, you're too clumsy to do that right either, you accidentally threw the door backwards and hurt some people...
data.reading_mnemonic: After you make your <kanji>clumsy</kanji> mistake you realize that these doors come in <reading>sets</reading> (<ja>せつ</ja>). And now you have to try to open another door. And another door. So many sets of doors!
data.reading_hint: Imagine trying to use your clumsy fingers all over the sets of doors. You keep falling over and hurting yourself. Why is it so hard to leave?!

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you're on a <radical>mountain</radical> looking from <radical>above</radical> to <radical>below</radical> that means you're on the <kanji>peak</kanji> of the mountain.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine standing right at the peak of a mountain looking at down from above and everything down below. You're really, really high up!
data.reading_mnemonic: It's only on this type of mountain <kanji>peak</kanji> that you'll be able to find the rare and adorable <reading>To</reading>kyo <reading>ge</reading>cko (<ja>とうげ</ja>). These tiny little critters can only be found on the ridges going above and below the mountains in Tokyo. There are like six mountains in Tokyo, so the next time you're scaling the ridges keep your eyes open for the Tokyo gecko!
data.reading_hint: Picture yourself sitting on a mountain peak in Tokyo and watching a little Tokyo gecko run up and down on them. It's adorable and totally worth the climb.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If someone makes a <radical>bamboo</radical> <radical>horse</radical>, you know it's <kanji>deliberate</kanji>. You can't accidentally make an entire horse out of bamboo.
data.meaning_hint: Someone sat down and deliberately planned the entire horse out, collected the materials, and made it by hand.
data.reading_mnemonic: As you admire all the <kanji>deliberate</kanji> details in this bamboo horse, the ghost of <reading>Toku</reading>gawa (<ja>とく</ja>) Ieyasu appears before you! "I deliberately made this horse to show you how important being deliberate is. You should be absolutely certain and decisive about your decisions."
data.reading_hint: Tokugawa Ieyasu then poofs out of existence and so does the bamboo horse.

data.meaning_mnemonic: There were lots of things that were <radical>above</radical> you when you were <radical>small</radical> that you would need a <radical>stool</radical> to reach, so you just asked your <kanji>aunt</kanji> or <kanji>uncle</kanji> to get them for you.
data.meaning_hint: Your parents didn't want you having those things, which is why they put them up high, but your aunt and uncle would always spoil you and get them for you.
data.reading_mnemonic: You ask your <kanji>aunt</kanji> and <kanji>uncle</kanji> to help you reach your special <reading>o</reading>bi (<ja>お</ja>) from high up in the closet.
data.reading_hint: You aren't supposed to wear your obi unless it's a special occasion, but your aunt and uncle don't know that. Now you can run around with it on your head and your parents can't stop you by putting it up high!

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you can <radical>stop</radical> a <radical>turkey</radical> by putting a <radical>spoon</radical> in its face you'll know it's a <kanji>female</kanji> turkey. A male turkey will peck the spoon out of your hand and run away. But a female turkey will wonder why you're putting a spoon there, stop, and look up at you wondering if you're okay.
data.meaning_hint: Picture the female turkey stopping when it sees you holding out a spoon. Why are you doing that human? it thinks. Are you sick?
data.reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>female</kanji> turkey then runs around making a <reading>mess</reading> (<ja>めす</ja>) of things trying to figure out what's wrong with you. She kicks around her hay, water bowl, and scratches at your pants, making more mess marks on them. But you don't move and she gets even more worried.
data.reading_hint: Imagine watching a female turkey make a mess of her own cage because she thinks you need help. How sweet.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If there is <radical>dirt</radical> in a <radical>crab trap</radical>, it's a lot for the crabs to <kanji>endure</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine a little crab getting stuck in a crab trap with dirt and other crabs. Endure the horror as long as you can, little friend.
data.reading_mnemonic: You decide to make the little crab that <kanji>endure</kanji>d being stuck in a dirty crab trap your pet, and put a <reading>colla</reading>r (<ja>こら</ja>) round its little neck.
data.reading_hint: Imagine yourself putting a collar around the crab's neck, then adding a leash and taking your crab for a walk around your neighborhood.

data.meaning_mnemonic: We want you to say things with your <radical>mouth</radical> right <radical>now</radical> because it's <kanji>recital</kanji> time! Go, perform please. What do you mean you didn't know the recital was right now? Well, tough luck. Recite!
data.meaning_hint: The recital is happening now. So open your mouth and start already!
data.reading_mnemonic: Here, if you are too afraid to start the <kanji>recital</kanji> now drink this <reading>gin</reading> (<ja>ぎん</ja>) to get your courage up. But once you're done drinking it the recital starts!
data.reading_hint: Drink gin before all your recitals! It'll help!

data.meaning_mnemonic: Making a mnemonic for a <radical>crab trap</radical> is <kanji>VERY</kanji> hard. So hard that I couldn't come up with one. But it's very possible that one of you will!
data.meaning_hint: How hard is it to come up with a good mnemonic for a crab trap? Very hard!
data.reading_mnemonic: You know what else is <kanji>very</kanji> something? <reading>Jean</reading>s (<ja>じん</ja>). Jeans are very expensive. Jeans are very tight. Jeans are very popular. Jeans are very a lot of things.
data.reading_hint: How many sentences can you make with very and jeans? More than me I hope.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Under the <radical>mountain</radical>'s <radical>roof</radical> are people using <radical>jackhammer</radical>s to <kanji>worship</kanji> the gods. The noise from their jackhammering echos up through the mountain and up toward the sky where the gods live. As long as each person uses their own jackhammer, the sound will be loud enough to reach them.
data.meaning_hint: Man your own jackhammer! (And worship the gods.)
data.reading_mnemonic: Unfortunately, the people who live around here can also hear you and the others <kanji>worship</kanji> in the mountain and they're going to <reading>sue</reading> (<ja>すう</ja>) you for the noise.
data.reading_hint: You try to argue that you can't sue someone for the way they choose to worship, but they say they're all deaf now, all the animals have gone, and no one sleeps anymore because of the shaking. Yikes, they might have a case!

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> hits a <radical>tree</radical> and your <radical>hat</radical> protects you from the <radical>water</radical>, but the hat itself is now covered in <kanji>lacquer</kanji>. You take it off and see that it's shiny and hard and protected.
data.meaning_hint: Picture your hat and all of the other things the tsunami + tree water touched. It's all been hardened with a thick coating of the lacquer.
data.reading_mnemonic: You decide to scoop up the rest of the <kanji>lacquer</kanji> water and use it on your furniture to protect it from your <reading>shih tzu</reading> (<ja>しつ</ja>). Now it can't bite or scratch or ruin any of your things anymore!
data.reading_hint: Watch as your shih tzu tries to bite your now lacquered chair. It gets its teeth around the leg, but it's hard as a rock. The shih tzu starts sneezing and spitting, letting go. Looks like it tastes bad too. Perfect!

data.meaning_mnemonic: You see a <radical>mountain</radical> in the shape of a <radical>turtle shell</radical> sticking out into the ocean. It's a <kanji>cape</kanji>! No, not the kind you wear, the geographical kind. When you're on land, most capes look like turtle shell mountains sticking out into the sea. Do you know any capes like that near where you live?
data.meaning_hint: Picture the turtle shell shaped cape. Feel the salty wind in your hair!
data.reading_mnemonic: You decide to walk along this <kanji>cape</kanji> because it looks like the perfect place to get rid of your old <reading>me</reading>at <reading>sack</reading> (<ja>みさき</ja>). It's starting to smell, but the ocean breeze from the cape pulls the meat sack out of your hands and off into the sky (then probably into the sea too).
data.reading_hint: The next time you go to the cape, remember to bring your old, used meat sack. You can toss it right into the ocean and it won't bother you ever again! Just make sure no one sees you.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Move <radical>thread</radical> in the right <radical>direction</radical> and you'll end up <kanji>spinning</kanji> it into yarn. Then you can spin that yarn into a sweater or a scarf with your favorite half tofu half fugu mascot on it!
data.meaning_hint: Imagine spinning thread into whatever your imagination wants.
data.reading_mnemonic: While you're <kanji>spinning</kanji> you realize that you've always wanted to make your own <reading>bow</reading>ling (<ja>ぼう</ja>) ball. And bowling ball cover. And bowling ball shoes.
data.reading_hint: Picture all of these thread-made bowling items. You're a really big bowling fan, huh?

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>stone</radical> that looks like a <radical>turkey</radical> <radical>boil</radical>ing underwater is just a <kanji>reef</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: It may seem like there are a bunch of turkeys under there, but it's just the shape the reef takes. Though I guess if you're looking from above the water it really does look like a bunch of turkeys freaking out.
data.reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>reef</kanji> is the <reading>Shou</reading>gun's (<ja>しょう</ja>) favorite place to be nowadays. He sits next to the water, and stares down into it for hours.
data.reading_hint: You don't know if the Shougun likes the reef because he likes the beauty of the ocean, or if he's fantasizing about turkeys boiling. He's a... complex man.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>barracks</radical> radical and the <kanji>barracks</kanji> kanji are the same!
data.meaning_hint: Know your radicals, yo!
data.reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Barracks</kanji> are pretty big, so they weigh a <reading>ton</reading> (<ja>とん</ja>). And they probably take tons of materials to build.
data.reading_hint: Imagine trying to lift some barracks. They weigh a ton! How are you supposed to do this? Why would you even try to lift something that obviously weighs a couple tons?!

data.meaning_mnemonic: You meet a <radical>woman</radical> whose <radical>mouth</radical> is <radical>big</radical> and you instantly know this is the person you want to <kanji>marry</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: When you think about the person you want to marry, picture their mouth wide in a big, beautiful smile, a wide-open laugh. That's the lady for you, alright!
data.reading_mnemonic: You <kanji>marry</kanji> this woman right away and you both go straight to an <reading>inn</reading> (<ja>いん</ja>) together!
data.reading_hint: When you get to the inn all you do is make her laugh and smile so you can bask in her bright, big, mouth smiles.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You try to use your <radical>fingers</radical> to cast <radical>doubt</radical> on people by using them to <kanji>imitate</kanji> each other. Right now you're using your fingers as finger puppets, imitating one of your friends to the others.
data.meaning_hint: Picture your angry friend standing up next to your fingers, shouting, "I'm the real me! That's just an imitation!" The rest of your friends look nervously at each other. They doubt this person is real now.
data.reading_mnemonic: Everyone thinks the friend you were trying to <kanji>imitate</kanji> is the imitation now and they have them in a <reading>gui</reading>llotine (<ja>ぎ</ja>). You even doubt if they're an imitation or if your fingers are the imitation.
data.reading_hint: Okay, so that's a lie, Your fingers are definitely imitating them, but you don't want to end up in the guillotine so you keep your mouth shut.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you see someone <radical>eye</radical>ing your <radical>womb</radical> you're probably going to be weirded out by how <kanji>friendly</kanji> they're acting. You only let people who are really, really close to you look at your womb. So if this guy is acting that friendly he should have introduced himself first.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine having someone you aren't friendly with trying to have a look at your womb. No thank you.
data.reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>friendly</kanji> guy comes up to you and start to introduce himself, "<ja><reading>ぼく</reading></ja>-" but you stop him. He's been getting way too friendly with your womb and you don't want to hear who he is. He can <ja>ぼく</ja> at someone else, you're out.
data.reading_hint: Imagine only letting this guy start to introduce himself with <ja>ぼく</ja> before walking the heck outta there. Just because he was acting friendly doesn't mean he was actually your friend.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You see a <radical>gate</radical> with a <radical>tree</radical> growing through it and it reminds you that you need more <kanji>leisure</kanji> time. You walk up to the gate tree and curl up under its branches. No one will bother you because the tree is blocking the gate from being used.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine spending your leisure time curled up under a tree that's growing through a gate. It's so cozy and secluded!
data.reading_mnemonic: As you <kanji>leisure</kanji>ly nap, you hear a gruff voice, "Ah, you're done too, huh?" It's Genghis <reading>Khan</reading> (<ja>かん</ja>)! He's spending his leisure time relaxing under this abandoned gate just like you.
data.reading_hint: But wait. Isn't Genghis Khan dead now? He winks at you, "Leisure time is for the dead." He smiles, and fades away, disappearing into the tree.

data.meaning_mnemonic: When under<radical>ground</radical> <radical>music</radical> makes it out into the light of the <radical>sun</radical> (the public), it finally becomes <kanji>official</kanji>. Music isn't really real unless people hear it outside of those secret underground concerts.
data.meaning_hint: Think of all that music you listened to underground but not in the light of the sun. None of that was official music. None of it!
data.reading_mnemonic: Once the music is <kanji>official</kanji>, you'll feel it in your <reading>sou</reading>l (<ja>そう</ja>). When you listen to it outside, under the bright sun, your soul gets to finally hear it too.
data.reading_hint: The official music penetrates into your soul, instead of just your ears, and it's affecting everyone else's souls too! Oh no... wait that's too many people. This was your song! No, it's too popular now, stop your souls from liking it! Ahhh!

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you want to <radical>say</radical> how <radical>eternity</radical> sounds you have to <kanji>compose</kanji> a poem. Or an essay. Or a song. <kanji>Recite</kanji> those deep thoughts about eternity and impress everyone who hears it.
data.meaning_hint: Try to compose a poem about eternity right now. Just jot it down somewhere.
data.reading_mnemonic: You decide to <kanji>compose</kanji> a poem about an <reading>a</reading>corn (<ja>えい</ja>). The tiny acorn is the perfect vessel for you to say how eternity feels to you.
data.reading_hint:
Let me recite the acorn poem to you now:

Acorns start small
Grow up big and tall
Spread their baby acorns for all
Live on for all eternity

data.meaning_mnemonic: You <radical>drop</radical> to the ground in a <radical>rice paddy</radical>, and then <radical>drop</radical> down in front of the <radical>cross</radical> you keep on you because you're trying to make yourself as <kanji>lowly</kanji> as you can in front of God. He said to lower yourself and this is the only way you can interpret that.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine dropping down in a rice paddy, then again in front of your cross. Be as lowly as you can make yourself.
data.reading_mnemonic: The only problem about being <kanji>lowly</kanji> is the <reading>he</reading>at (<ja>ひ</ja>). Everyone always told you that heat rises, but not here. The rice paddy is incredibly hot... unless oh no. Is that the heat of hell?
data.reading_hint: You tried to make yourself lowly in front of God but this heat is probably a sign that you didn't do it well enough.

data.meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Every</radical> <radical>leader</radical> will come to <kanji>despise</kanji> their followers. In the beginning everything is fine and dandy, but eventually the leader's followers will ask for more and more things, eventually ridiculous things, and the leader will really despise them for it.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine yourself as a leader who's come to despise every single one of their followers. Look down at them in disgust as they ask you to grant them all a pony.
data.reading_mnemonic: The more you <kanji>despise</kanji> them, the more <reading>boo</reading>ze (<ja>ぶ</ja>) you drink. This is not smart or healthy, but it's what this kind of hate does to people.
data.reading_hint: This is not a healthy way to handle things! If you despise someone you should talk to them, don't turn to booze. Don't be like every leader that's come before you.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Take <radical>three</radical> <radical>measurement</radical>s of <radical>gold</radical> and <radical>slide</radical> them into a mold to make a <kanji>cast</kanji>! You'll have cast three gold swords, or goblets, or ducks. Just make sure you follow those directions, or your casting won't come out right.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine yourself carefully measuring out the three portions of gold and sliding them into your mold to make a cast of whatever you want. I wonder what it could be?
data.reading_mnemonic: You open the <kanji>cast</kanji> to reveal your gold statue of <reading>Chew</reading>bacca (<ja>ちゅう)</ja>! It's life-size and now you have three! Your new gold Chewbacca casts are going to guard the entrance to your house.
data.reading_hint: Picture your majestic Chewbacca casts. Carefully set them outside your front door to guard you. This was a great idea!

data.meaning_mnemonic: In a <radical>flowers</radical> <radical>net</radical> a <radical>drunkard</radical> <radical>slide</radical>s down like a <radical>drop</radical>. There they stay, an icon of <kanji>scorn</kanji> and <kanji>neglect</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: It's embarrassing to fall down a flowers net while drunk. Despite that, there you are. Everyone who goes by scorns you or neglects you.
data.reading_mnemonic: Every time you receive <kanji>scorn</kanji> and <kanji>neglect</kanji> from someone walking by, you say in your drunken voice: "I <reading>bets you</reading> (<ja>べつ</ja>) I can get up if I want. I bets you I can."
data.reading_hint: You try to get up, but no matter how much you "bets you" someone that you can get up, you slide back down the flowers net. "I bets you I can do it next time," you say.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you stay up for so long that you get to watch the <radical>moon</radical> go down and the <radical>dawn</radical> come, then people will say you have serious <kanji>guts</kanji>. Staying up that late is really hard, and not everyone can do it. If you don't have the guts to stay up, you'll just fall asleep and never see the moon and the sun switch places in the sky.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine the guts you'd have to have to stay up for so long that you see the moon and the sun switch places! A lot of guts!
data.reading_mnemonic: You were outside for so long, proving you had <kanji>guts</kanji>, that you also got a sweet <reading>tan</reading> (<ja>たん</ja>) out of it! It's a really deep tan though, and you probably need more guts if you ever want to do all that again.
data.reading_hint: Imagine having the guts to stay outside to watch the moon and the sun and then getting a really deep tan from it.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>tsunami</radical> that is <radical>good</radical>. This fabled creature has never been seen, but you <kanji>wander</kanji> the lands in search of it.
data.meaning_hint: You wander everywhere, with no particular direction in mind.
data.reading_mnemonic: As you <kanji>wander</kanji>, you come across a clue. It is fish <reading>roe</reading> (<ja>ろう</ja>).
data.reading_hint: Wherever the good tsunami goes, it leaves delicious fish roe behind. That's what makes it a good tsunami.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>spirit</radical> wearing two <radical>mustache</radical>s must be <kanji>evil</kanji>. Everyone knows a mustache makes you evil, but two? And on a spirit? Yup, definitely evil.
data.meaning_hint: Look at the evil spirit with two mustaches on its spirit face. Imagine its face in detail, especially those mustaches.
data.reading_mnemonic: You're watching the <kanji>evil</kanji> mustache spirit when it starts to float toward your <reading>ca</reading>r (<ja>か</ja>). And it's... hey! It's trashing your car! You knew this guy was evil!
data.reading_hint: Imagine running around, flailing your arms, trying to get the spirit to stop ruining your car. But your hands go right through him and his two mustaches. You can't stop his evil doings.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You can only give a <radical>kiss</radical> of <radical>alcohol</radical> to <kanji>dairy</kanji>. If you add anymore than a kiss the dairy will curdle and you won't be able to drink it anymore. Bleh.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine trying to give more than a kiss of alcohol to dairy and watch it bubble and curdle and get all gross and chunky.
data.reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Dairy</kanji> isn't kept with other drinks, it needs to be placed on a <reading>rack</reading> (<ja>らく</ja>). I hope you've been using your dairy rack to store your dairy. If you haven't you should get one right away!
data.reading_hint: Look at all your dairy products: milk, yogurt, cheese, all of it sitting nicely on your dairy rack.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>soul</radical> <radical>stand</radical>s in the <radical>village</radical> you <kanji>long for</kanji>. It's the village you're from, and no matter how far you go, no matter how old you get, your soul is still there, and you <kanji>yearn</kanji> for it.
data.meaning_hint: Have you ever been away from your village? Maybe you're far away right now, studying Japanese alone. Can't you feel your body longing for your soul back home?
data.reading_mnemonic: No matter how much you <kanji>long for</kanji> it, you can't go back because <reading>a cougar</reading> (<ja>あこが</ja>) is in the way. Whenever you try to return to your village to be reunited with the soul you yearn for, a cougar is back, and won't let you in.
data.reading_hint: You long for a cougar to leave you alone! You yearn for a cougar to bother someone else!

data.meaning_mnemonic: If a pilot manages to land under a <radical>canopy</radical> with a <radical>helicopter</radical> that's pierced with a sideways <radical>barb</radical> in the <radical>heart</radical> of <radical>winter</radical> you should <kanji>congratulate</kanji> them! People should always be congratulated for doing good things, and this is one of the best things you've ever heard of!
data.meaning_hint: Can you imagine how hard landing a helicopter in just one of these horrible conditions? Congratulate them!
data.reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Congratulate</kanji> the pilot with <reading>ca</reading>ke (<ja>けい</ja>)!
data.reading_hint: Cake is always the appropriate celebratory food.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the radical that look like this are exactly the same. They are both <kanji>Asia</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: As long as you know the radical Asia, you know the kanji Asia.
data.reading_mnemonic: What's the first sound in <kanji>Asia</kanji>? It's <reading>A</reading> (<ja>あ</ja>). Nice and easy!
data.reading_hint: A is for Asia!

data.meaning_mnemonic: If the <radical>tsunami</radical> that's heading for your village is <radical>fat</radical> you should try to <kanji>select</kanji> a different one to hit instead. You don't want to select fat tsunamis because they do more damage.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine being at the tsunami store and selecting the least fat one there.
data.reading_mnemonic: If you're having trouble <kanji>select</kanji>ing which one is the least fat just check to see which tsunamis are eating <reading>ta</reading>cos (<ja>た</ja>). Only fat tsunamis will be eating them, so just look for one without a taco.
data.reading_hint: While you select the tsunami that's right for you. Keep an eye out for those fat taco-eating ones. And then stay away from them!

data.meaning_mnemonic: You make a tree spicy by turning it into a wood block print. The spice comes from all the porn you put on there. What? It wasn't me. Porn wood blocks have been around for ages!
data.meaning_hint: Imagine the journey a tree took to become a spicy wood block. MmMmm.
data.reading_mnemonic: You make these <kanji>wood block</kanji>s using <reading>a zoo saw</reading> (<ja>あずさ</ja>) because a regular saw can't handle how spicy these wood blocks are gonna get once they're covered in dirty pictures.
data.reading_hint: Imagine using a zoo saw to cut the blocks out of a tree that you're going to spice up with awesome smut.

data.meaning_mnemonic: People think <radical>tsunami</radical>s are only made of water but they have a <radical>few</radical> pieces of <kanji>sand</kanji> in there too. There's actually more sand in the ocean than most people think. And tsunamis can't just have water and sharks in them. A few grains of sand will always slip in.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine how those few grains of sand feel to get swept up into a tsunami. They didn't ask for this. They just wanted to stay at the bottom of the sea.
data.reading_mnemonic: How do I know there's <kanji>sand</kanji> in there? Because I <reading>saw</reading> (<ja>さ</ja>) them!
data.reading_hint: I saw the sand, stop doubting me!

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you ride a <radical>scooter</radical> with your <radical>fingers</radical> around an <radical>axe</radical> you're going to <kanji>die</kanji>. I mean, probably. There's a 99% chance you'll die.
data.meaning_hint: Picture someone else riding a scooter with an axe in their fingertips. That's so dangerous! One bump, one bad turn, and that axe slips and they'll die.
data.reading_mnemonic:
You slip. The axe collides with your face. You <kanji>die</kanji>. But... wait! There's a bright, blue glow and suddenly you're un-dead. You watch in slow motion as your holy blue <reading>sa</reading>ber (<ja>せい</ja>) brings you back to life and takes the hit from the axe instead.

Wait, no!

It shatters.
data.reading_hint: Your holy blue saber died for you. It saved you from certain death and now it died. After all you've been through together. All 60 levels. This is the end.

data.meaning_mnemonic: This <radical>cage</radical> is full of <radical>flowers</radical> on the <radical>right</radical> side to <kanji>hide</kanji> the fact that you're in here too.
data.meaning_hint: You don't really want to be in this cage, but there were some things you didn't want to do today, so you hid. Luckily these flowers block the right side of the cage and hide you completely.
data.reading_mnemonic: As you <kanji>hide</kanji> the ghost of <reading>Toku</reading>gawa (<ja>とく</ja>) Ieyasu appears before you, inside the cage! His arms are crossed and he's shaking his head at you. "Do you think I managed to become the first shougun of Japan by hiding?"
data.reading_hint: "N-no?" you respond. "Wrong! I hid all the time. There's nothing wrong with hiding, you're doing a great job." he says, and disappears.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Under your own <radical>roof</radical>, a <radical>geoduck</radical> jumps out of the <radical>ground</radical> with a <radical>sword</radical> and stabs your husband/wife/marriage partner to death. Now you're a <kanji>widow</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine the geoduck laughing and screaming, "Now you're a widow! Now you're a widow!" flailing the sword around. It's awful.
data.reading_mnemonic: You may be a <kanji>widow</kanji>, but that doesn't make you weak. You run outside, jump into your <reading>ca</reading>r (<ja>か</ja>), and run your entire house and the geoduck over.
data.reading_hint: It's just you and your car now, living the widow life, driving on into the sunset and forgetting your past.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You ate some <radical>grain</radical>s that made you so <radical>sick</radical> it feels like a <radical>knife</radical> is stabbing in your guts and all your poop is falling out. This is called <kanji>diarrhea</kanji>. Everyone's had diarrhea before, so you should know this feeling by now.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine back to the last time you ate something bad and it gave you diarrhea. It felt like someone was sticking you with a knife, didn't it?
data.reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>diarrhea</kanji> is here. It's happening. And it smells so awful you can't breathe. You have to take some hollow <reading>reed</reading>s (<ja>り</ja>) and shove them up your nose and out the bathroom door so you can get some fresh air in you.
data.reading_hint: You learned this reed technique from a group of ninjas who use them to breathe underwater, and you never thought you'd use them like this.

data.meaning_mnemonic: In the <radical>dirt</radical>, you find a <radical>lid</radical> under the <radical>table</radical>. You lift it to reveal a deep <kanji>pit</kanji>. Why is there a <kanji>hole</kanji> under your table?
data.meaning_hint: You pull away the lid and crawl inside. There is a ladder that takes you deep into the pit.
data.reading_mnemonic: When you reach the bottom of the <kanji>pit</kanji>, you hear someone scuffling around and the sounds of chains. You light a match and inch closer to see what it is. In the darkness, you see <ja><reading>こう</reading>いち</ja>, starved and chained in a pit under your table.
data.reading_hint: After you've nursed <ja>こういち</ja> back to health, he explains that he was put here by a clone <ja>こういち</ja>–the very same <ja>こういち</ja> who became emperor. He tells you he can think of around 61-70 different pain levels of revenge, but also that "it probably wouldn't be worth it, so let's just hang out for a while instead. Ooh, are those cookies?"

data.meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Flowers</radical> that you <radical>oversee</radical> are always <kanji>indigo</kanji>. You aren't sure why though...
data.meaning_hint: Imagine if every flower you were supposed to oversee was indigo. Indigo everywhere!
data.reading_mnemonic: Wait, maybe these flowers are only <kanji>indigo</kanji> because there is something wrong with your <reading>eye</reading>s (<ja>あい</ja>)! Maybe your eyes are indigo and that's why it's all you see!
data.reading_hint: Can you imagine having indigo-only seeing eyes? I can. Because of this awesome mnemonic.

data.meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Half</radical> of a <radical>rice paddy</radical> is always on the <kanji>shore</kanji>. Japan is surrounded by water, after all. So it only makes sense that half of every rice paddy is right next to the ocean shore, right?
data.meaning_hint: Picture a rice paddy. Half of it is trailing off into the shore. Hear the seagulls. Feel the ocean breeze!
data.reading_mnemonic: You decide to walk along this <kanji>shore</kanji> when you see <reading>Han</reading> (<ja>はん</ja>) Solo lounging in the sand. He's waving for you to join him! You get to lay on the shore with Han!!
data.reading_hint: Imagine laying on the shore with Han Solo. Enjoying a cool drink. Smelling the fragrance of the rice paddy behind you. Yeah, this is the life!

data.meaning_mnemonic: Use your <radical>mouth</radical> to sing and a <radical>shellfish</radical> to stroke your shamisen, and you'll be performing a <kanji>shamisen song</kanji> just like that! Yes, it's that easy. Just go find a shell, open your mouth, and you'll be singing one too in no time!
data.meaning_hint: Imagine using your mouth to sing and a shell to play the shamisen to perform your shamisen song!
data.reading_mnemonic: A <kanji>shamisen song</kanji> is just an <ja><reading>歌</reading></ja> (<ja>うた</ja>) but with a shamisen. They're still songs so they're said the exact same way!
data.reading_hint: A shamisen song is a song, yay!

data.meaning_mnemonic: You put your <radical>fingers</radical> in the <radical>coffin</radical> to tickle the <radical>beggar</radical> inside. What you're doing is a new form of <kanji>torture</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: First, you put them in a coffin to make them think they're going to die. Then you tickle them with your fingers. There is no greater psychological + physical torture than this.
data.reading_mnemonic: The beggar you will coffin tickle <kanji>torture</kanji> is <ja><reading>ごう</reading>いち</ja>, a.k.a. Grandpa Koichi. He is a frail old man, and doesn't like to be tickled.
data.reading_hint: He keeps screaming: "STOP THIS TICKLE TORTURE. I CAN'T TAKE IT JUST BURY ME."

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>tsunami</radical> swept away one of the <radical>cleat</radical>s your <radical>husband</radical> just bought and creates an entire <kanji>valley</kanji> with it.
data.meaning_hint: Watch as the tsunami rakes your husband's cleat across the mountain, carving a valley and an easier path for itself. Nature is brutal.
data.reading_mnemonic: When the water clears, you and your husband go to the <kanji>valley</kanji> to look for the cleat and instead you find a bunch of <reading>ca</reading>ke (<ja>けい</ja>)! Maybe this is the tsunami's way of saying, "Thanks for letting me steal your cleat so I could make this valley shortcut."
data.reading_hint: Imagine yourself eating cake with your husband in this newly formed valley. You both agree that this should be called Cake Valley!

data.meaning_mnemonic: Under this <radical>canopy</radical> is the <radical>Mona Lisa</radical>, being sold for cheap, what a great <kanji>bargain</kanji>! You never know what kind of bargains you'll find when you look under a canopy at the wares of a traveling salesperson.
data.meaning_hint: Look really closely at this Mona Lisa. Hmm, I don't remember her having a mustache, but I guess it is a little dark under this canopy.
data.reading_mnemonic: You want to make sure this <kanji>bargain</kanji> is as good as it seems, so you ask if you can get this Mona Lisa as a <reading>ren</reading>tal (<ja>れん</ja>). Just for now, so you can make sure it's real before you buy it at that low, low price.
data.reading_hint: The salesperson pulls the painting away and mutters, "Ah, yes, well this is such a good bargain already! And besides... it's already a rental, you see. From the, uh, the Louvre. So you really should just take this bargain and buy it!"

data.meaning_mnemonic: You <radical>say</radical> something to a <radical>boot</radical> when you want to be <kanji>humble</kanji>. You're down there because you're bowing in front of the person you're humbling yourself before. Because of that, your face is really close to their boots and you're speaking directly at them, instead of at the person's face, so it's more <kanji>discreet</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Picture yourself trying to be humble. You're down on the ground talking to a pair of boots. You don't dare raise your eyes past that.
data.reading_mnemonic: You're being <kanji>humble</kanji> like this because those boots belong to the <reading>Kin</reading>g (<ja>きん</ja>) of England. You can't just say whatever you want at eye level to a king. He'll have your head chopped off for insolence, or worse!
data.reading_hint: Imagine saying something to the King. Get low down on the ground to be as humble as you can. Whisper into the King's boots. Lick them if you have to.

data.meaning_mnemonic: When you see a <radical>tsunami</radical> coming <radical>courage</radical> <kanji>well</kanji>s up inside you and you gain the power to save everyone you meet before they get washed away! Feel that courage <kanji>boil</kanji> and spread throughout all your limbs. You feel like you have super strength. This tsunami isn't going to hurt anyone while you're alive to stop it!
data.meaning_hint: Imagine what it feels like to have courage well up inside you. Courage in the face of certain death!
data.reading_mnemonic: Who does that courage <kanji>well</kanji> up inside? <reading>You</reading> (<ja>ゆう</ja>)! In fact, YOU feel like there is a never ending well of courage bursting out of you now. You are going to be a hero!
data.reading_hint: Who wells up with courage? You do!

data.meaning_mnemonic: Give <radical>alcohol</radical> to a <radical>demon</radical> and you'll see how <kanji>ugly</kanji> it really is. Demons need to concentrate to keep their disguises going. Even if it looked pretty when you met it, like super handsome, give it a few drinks and its facade will slide off and reveal its super gross demon face.
data.meaning_hint: Picture the drunk demon as its pretty face drips off revealing the ugly crap piled underneath.
data.reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>ugly</kanji> demon is drunk and taking off his <reading>shoe</reading>s (<ja>しゅう</ja>) and swinging them around his head. And, oh no, he's drinking more alcohol out of the shoes.
data.reading_hint: The demon drinking alcohol out of its nasty shoes is the ugliest scene you've ever seen.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You see <radical>twenty</radical> <radical>slide</radical>s lined up like a <kanji>grid</kanji>. You don't know who put them here, but they almost look like the grid paper you do your maths homework in. But who would use a slide as grid paper?
data.meaning_hint: Picture twenty slides laid out in a grid systems.
data.reading_mnemonic: As you stare at the slide <kanji>grid</kanji> you see some people come out and overhear them talk about their mass <reading>maths</reading> (<ja>ます</ja>) tournament happening later today. Oohhh it IS a giant grid. And they're going to use it to do maths later!
data.reading_hint: You can make a grid out of anything if you set your mind to it. And you can do math anywhere as long as you have some grid paper!

data.meaning_mnemonic: Put a <radical>yakuza</radical> member in a <radical>prison</radical> on the <radical>sun</radical> and he'll become a <kanji>martyr</kanji> to all the other yakuza still on earth. He died up there so the rest of them wouldn't have to. Because they definitely aren't getting caught now, if the penalty is a burning death in the new sun prison.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine all the yakuza coming out into the streets and holding up signs saying this guy was a martyr. A hero to all who do bad stuff in bad groups but don't wanna get caught.
data.reading_mnemonic: The only reason he ended up a <kanji>martyr</kanji> in the first place is because they put him up there in <reading>June</reading> (<ja>じゅん</ja>). Everyone knows the sun is way too hot for humans in June. It's summer!
data.reading_hint: Really, it's not the fault of the people who put him there that he's become a martyr. It's the month of June. PUNISH JUNE! PUT JUNE IN THE SUN PRISON! (Is what I assume those yakuza are shouting.)

data.meaning_mnemonic: Set <radical>fire</radical> to a <radical>geoduck</radical> if you want to <kanji>annoy</kanji> it. Fire won't kill a geoduck, but have you ever been on fire? It's not really pleasant. So you'll just annoy it pretty badly.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine how annoyed you would be if someone set YOU on fire for no reason. The geoduck has every reason to find you annoying, dude.
data.reading_mnemonic: You know who loves <kanji>annoying</kanji> geoducks more than anyone else in the universe? <reading>Han</reading> (<ja>はん</ja>) Solo! If you watch Star Wars closely enough you can see him shooting geoducks with his blaster and catching them on fire for fun.
data.reading_hint: Think how annoying it must be to be a geoduck when Han Solo comes around.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you want to <radical>slice</radical> the <radical>power</radical> out of someone just <kanji>censure</kanji> them. Then they'll be cut down in front of everyone and they'll feel super embarrassed. It's the best way to slice them down without actually cutting them and getting arrested.
data.meaning_hint: Picture yourself as you slice the power out of that senator you hate by censuring them in front of the world!
data.reading_mnemonic: Once you <kanji>censure</kanji> them and they lose all their power, they'll be just another <reading>guy</reading> (<ja>がい</ja>). A normal guy with everything lost to him. HAHAHA!
data.reading_hint: Look at that guy now. What a loser.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Carve a <radical>tree</radical> into a <radical>bar</radical> and lay it sticking out into the water to make a <kanji>jetty</kanji> or a <kanji>pier</kanji>. Now you can walk out on the jetty and go further into the water without needing a boat or getting wet.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine laying your tree turned bar into the water to make your own jetty. Innovative!
data.reading_mnemonic: You made this <kanji>jetty</kanji> so it would be easier for <reading>San</reading>ta-san (<ja>さん</ja>) to dock his sleigh. Oh, you didn't know? His sleigh is more of a speed boat now, so he needs a jetty to give you presents, not a chimney anymore.
data.reading_hint: Picture Santa-san coming in from the water on his speedboat and docking on your jetty to deliver presents to you.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Have you heard the tale of the <radical>woman</radical> who fell in love with a <radical>coat rack</radical> during a full <radical>moon</radical> and made him her <kanji>groom</kanji>? It's a true story! She even had a wedding ceremony and had more coat racks sitting in the grooms side. The moon will make people do craaaazy things.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine what it would be like to fall in love with a coat rack and make it YOUR groom.
data.reading_mnemonic: The best part of the story is that the only coat on the coat rack <kanji>groom</kanji> was a <reading>moo</reading>se <reading>co</reading>at (<ja>むこ</ja>). So the groom was a really skinny stick with a giant moose hair coat hanging down it.
data.reading_hint: Could you love a moose coat enough to marry it?

data.meaning_mnemonic: You're walking in a <radical>greenhouse</radical> when you see a <radical>small</radical> <radical>drop</radical> of water fall and it makes you <kanji>yearn for</kanji> the person you <kanji>adore</kanji>. You haven't seen them in so long. But something about being in this greenhouse and seeing that tiny water droplet made your heart burst with longing.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine how it feels to yearn for someone else when you see the small water drop. Imagine how your heart feels.
data.reading_mnemonic: As you <kanji>yearn for</kanji> that person from your past, you look back at the drop and see... <reading>Bo</reading>bo (<ja>ぼ</ja>) the clown?! Uhg. Apparently Bobo dropped that small drop of water.
data.reading_hint: Now you yearn for being somewhere Bobo is not.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You're in a <radical>net</radical> but you have the <radical>ability</radical> to quit playing along and <kanji>leave</kanji> at any time.
data.meaning_hint: Your captors think they have you trapped, but you know you can leave whenever you feel like it.
data.reading_mnemonic: You don't know if you want to <kanji>quit</kanji> this charade until you feel an uncomfortable <reading>hea</reading>t (<ja>ひ</ja>). You look down and the net you're in is being hung above a large fire.
data.reading_hint: As the heat spreads you decide to leave. You hop out of the net and watch the shock spread in your captors eyes.

data.meaning_mnemonic: An <radical>arrow </radical>is shot from <radical>heaven</radical> and hits right between your <radical>mouth</radical> and your <radical>mustache</radical> to <kanji>correct</kanji> your crooked smile. It also <kanji>straighten</kanji>s your teeth and the crooked cut of your mustache too. Who told you that looked good? Well, it doesn't matter. The heaven arrow corrected it for you.
data.meaning_hint: An arrow from heaven will correct all your problems!
data.reading_mnemonic: These heavenly <kanji>correct</kanji>ing arrows actually come from <ja><reading>きょう</reading>と</ja>. They hate seeing people with crooked mustaches, so they shoot them out on the regular. It just looks like they're coming from heaven because they fall out of the sky.
data.reading_hint: If you want someone to correct your teeth or mustache, just wander around <ja>きょうと</ja>, staring up at the sky. Then when you see an arrow, run for it and try to catch it with your face!

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you think a <radical>tree</radical> looks <radical>sweet</radical> you have to be <kanji>certain</kanji> before you bite into it. Trees are really hard, and usually pretty bitter (believe me) so if you don't want a mouthful of broken teeth, sap, and sadness, you really need to be sure it's the one before you start munching.
data.meaning_hint: Which tree do you think is sweet? That one? Or that one? Are you absolutely certain? I hope you are!
data.reading_mnemonic: If you really want to be <kanji>certain</kanji>, and not just guess, take out your <reading>bow</reading>ling (<ja>ぼう</ja>) ball and roll it as hard as you can into the tree. If its the right one it will let out a sweet smell, if it's not the tree will punch you.
data.reading_hint: So now let me ask you again, are you certain, or would you like to try the bowling ball test?

data.meaning_mnemonic: Inside this giant <radical>mouth</radical> is a <radical>person</radical>, trapped, because they're a <kanji>criminal</kanji>. They did something bad (they touched the mouth of another person without consent) and now they're in mouth jail for criminals.
data.meaning_hint: Picture the criminal, trapped inside the mouth. They don't even look sorry!
data.reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>criminal</kanji> is only wearing <reading>shoe</reading>s (<ja>しゅう</ja>). They're completely naked otherwise. They have to wear shoes because the mouth jail would be too slippery for them to stand otherwise.
data.reading_hint: Wearing nothing but shoes is also really uncomfortable too, so it's actually part of the criminal's punishment. They don't seem to know that though.

data.meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Tsunami</radical>'s have a <radical>certain</radical> tendency to <kanji>secrete</kanji> things as they go back out to sea. When they bash themselves onto the land they just throw a bunch of sea water around, but there are only certain things that they'll secrete when they're leaving.
data.meaning_hint: Certain tsunami secretions are dangerous. Can you think of any?
data.reading_mnemonic: Most tsunami's <kanji>secrete</kanji> <reading>he</reading>at (<ja>ひ</ja>). It takes a lot of energy for a tsunami to crash onto the land so the water is really really hot, and it has to secrete that heat as it's going back out to sea.
data.reading_hint: The next time someone asks you what does a tsunami secrete? You'll say heat!

data.meaning_mnemonic: You're stuck in your <radical>car</radical> during a <radical>tsunami</radical> and all you have to break out is an <radical>axe</radical>. You whack and whack but you're only <kanji>gradually</kanji> making progress. You thought an axe would be an easy way to get out of a car but it's not working like you'd planned! You have to make more than gradual progress if you don't want to drown.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine gradually denting your car door open with an axe while you're trapped in a tsunami. This isn't fast enough!
data.reading_mnemonic: As you're <kanji>gradually</kanji> making your door open with the axe you look up to see the New York Yankees floating by on top of their bus. You yell, "<reading>YO YA</reading>NKEES (<ja>ようや</ja>) to get their attention. They see your gradual progress and start throwing balls at your car to help dent it open.
data.reading_hint: YO YANKEES! Gradually yelling that saved your life!

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>flowers</radical> that wash up on shore in <radical>tsunami</radical>s that we make into <radical>syrup</radical> is <kanji>seaweed</kanji>. Okay, so it's more like soup or tea than syrup, but you can make them both out of seaweed.
data.meaning_hint: Seaweed is the flower of the sea!
data.reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Seaweed</kanji> is true <reading>sou</reading>l (<ja>そう</ja>) food. Which means it's good for your soul. Didn't you ever read those books about chicken soup being good for your soul? Well that was a lie. Miso soup with seaweed is what's really good for your soul.
data.reading_hint: Feed your soul with seaweed and it will thank you. Promise! <3

data.meaning_mnemonic: If the <radical>death</radical> of a <radical>woman</radical> occurs it's because she was being <kanji>reckless</kanji>. People don't just die out of nowhere! They have to have done something super crazy to cause it. Right? Yes... right.
data.meaning_hint: Picture yourself watching the news about a woman's death. The word RECKLESS?! pops up on your screen and keeps flashing. Huh, she must have been, you think to yourself.
data.reading_mnemonic: As you watch the news about this <kanji>reckless</kanji> woman you find out that she died from <reading>mow</reading>ing (<ja>もう</ja>) her lawn. You're not sure how, but now you really believe that she had to be doing it really recklessly to die doing it.
data.reading_hint: Imagine what reckless thing that woman had to have done to die while mowing the lawn. Eww.

data.meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Red</radical> <radical>insect</radical>s only bite <kanji>barbarian</kanji>s. If a red insect bites you then you have barbarian blood! Waaay back a barbarian was your aunt or uncle or great great grand pappy! But the insects kinda hurt, so it's a bit of a downside I guess.
data.meaning_hint: If you see a red insect follow it and see who it bites. Then you'll know that person is at least part barbarian.
data.reading_mnemonic: You follow the red insect and see it bite someone who must be a <kanji>barbarian</kanji>! You look up at their face but all you can see are giant Ray-<reading>Ban</reading> (<ja>ばん</ja>) sunglasses. You really want to look at his face to see what a barbarian looks like but those darn things are in the way!
data.reading_hint: Thanks to those Ray Bans you still don't know what a real life barbarian looks like. After going to all the trouble of following a red bug too. What a waste.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>leader</radical> <radical>squid</radical> tells all of its squid people to be <kanji>thrifty</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine the leader squid giving a speech about how you shouldn't buy new things, and how you should live with a roommate to save money. Every squid yen counts!
data.reading_mnemonic: Who is a <kanji>thrifty</kanji> squid? <reading>Ken</reading> (<ja>けん</ja>) the samurai's squid buddy, who gets carried around in a bucket and never pays rent.
data.reading_hint:
Ken's squid is always shaking his head at Ken the samurai's obsession with wearing all silk. He should visit Thrifty Threads, the second hand shop, and get some cotton clothes that would do the job just fine.

Hint: Whenever there's a squid, remember that Ken (<ja>けん</ja>) the samurai is nearby.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>animal</radical> that hangs out in <radical>melon</radical> patches is the elusive <kanji>fox</kanji>! They like to steal melons then come back into town disguised as human melon sellers. Foxes are tricky like that.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine seeing a red fox scampering through a melon patch trying to take melons with it.
data.reading_mnemonic: If you want to stop <kanji>fox</kanji>es from stealing your melons you can get one of those <reading>kits</reading> that <reading>neigh</reading> (<ja>きつね</ja>) when one is around. The kits neigh when they sense a fox, but because it sounds like a horse the fox won't run. But you'll be able to get out there and take your melons back!
data.reading_hint: Imagine buying kits that neigh and putting them around your melon patch to warn you when foxes are around.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Open your <radical>mouth</radical>. A <radical>tiger</radical> fell in there on some <radical>spikes</radical>! That's what you tell everybody, but when they look in your mouth there's nothing there. It's all a big <kanji>lie</kanji>!
data.meaning_hint: Of course there isn't a tiger in your mouth. And those spikes are just normal teeth. No matter how you look at it, you're saying a lie.
data.reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Lie</kanji> about spikes in your mouth and I'll put soap with spikes in it in your mouth to teach you a lesson. That's why I'm using <reading>u</reading>ni <reading>so</reading>ap (<ja>うそ</ja>).
data.reading_hint: Now at least you're not lying about spikes being in your mouth.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>soul</radical> is going <radical>wild</radical> because you're <kanji>confused</kanji>. If you're confused, it's usually because you don't know what's going on or what to do. This makes the soul inside your body go absolutely wild!
data.meaning_hint: Think back to the last time you were confused. Remember how your soul felt? You were so confused it went wild and made you feel dumb and bad, like a wild person.
data.reading_mnemonic: Whenever you're <kanji>confused</kanji>, <ja><reading>こう</reading>いち</ja> appears to offer you guidance. He's confused a lot, so he knows how to help. And knowledge offered by <ja>こういち</ja> is the best medicine for confusion.
data.reading_hint: Imagine being confused about Japanese, for example. In your confusion everything seems scary and wild and your soul is utterly bewildered, but then here comes <ja>こういち</ja>. He sits with you and pats your back and tries to help you stop being so confused.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You use your <radical>fingers</radical> when you're in <radical>private</radical> to use an <radical>arrow</radical> to <kanji>push open</kanji> things.
data.meaning_hint: You're in private in your own room, no one else is around. Now you wrap your fingers around this big arrow, and you push open your door, your curtains, your windows. It's weird, but you really enjoy this.
data.reading_mnemonic: Your favorite thing to <kanji>push open</kanji> is your own <reading>eye</reading> (<ja>あい</ja>). You take the arrow into your fingers and gently push each lid open until you can see.
data.reading_hint: Picture the arrow in your hands. You're facing a mirror, but you can't see because you're about to push open your eyes. The anticipation is killing you, push them open now!

data.meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>fingers</radical> told you that a <radical>flood</radical> last <radical>evening</radical> seemed to <kanji>be imminent</kanji>, and that there was nothing you could do to stop it. You felt it <kanji>draw close</kanji>, coming in the darkness of the evening.
data.meaning_hint: Think back to last evening, when your fingers twitched and twisted, warning you as the flood started to draw close.
data.reading_mnemonic: As the flood began to <kanji>draw close</kanji> you knew there was nothing you could do, so you <reading>sat</reading> (<ja>さつ</ja>) down  and waited.
data.reading_hint: You sat down and now you're still there, waiting for the flood. It's still drawing closer... it'll come eventually.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>ice</radical> <radical>wife</radical> is <kanji>amazing</kanji>. She's also <kanji>terrible</kanji>, because she's very cold and has many ice powers, but that's also part of what makes her amazing!
data.meaning_hint: Picture your amazing and terrible ice wife. She's floating in your backyard cackling and shooting ice all around.
data.reading_mnemonic: She turns her <kanji>amazing</kanji> gaze onto your <reading>sa</reading>ber (<ja>せい</ja>) and hits it with an ice beam. Woah! Instead of turning to ice or shattering, it steals her awful powers. Now your saber is amazing and terrible too!
data.reading_hint: Now you're floating in the backyard cackling with your amazing wife as you use your terrible saber and freeze things with her!

data.meaning_mnemonic: In the <radical>foot</radical> <radical>capital</radical>, it's tough to be a <radical>dog</radical> because you're always getting <kanji>kick</kanji>ed.
data.meaning_hint: In the foot capital, you can only use your feet. So petting dogs looks a lot like kicking them.
data.reading_mnemonic: When you <kanji>kick</kanji> a dog, there's an explosion of <reading><ja>毛</ja></reading> (<ja>け</ja>).
data.reading_hint: People in the foot capital are very kick-happy, so you can imagine how much <ja>毛</ja> is in the streets.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>mouth</radical> <radical>proclaim</radical>s "I am <kanji>noisy</kanji> and I am <kanji>picky</kanji>!" It keeps repeating this over and over to everyone you pass by.
data.meaning_hint: The townsfolk agree with your mouth, you are noisy and you are picky and you need to shut up.
data.reading_mnemonic: You are so <kanji>noisy</kanji> and <kanji>picky</kanji> that the townsfolk hired <reading>Ken</reading> (<ja>けん</ja>) the Samurai to shut you up.
data.reading_hint:
"Ken, your armor color is so last year. That squid you have is gross. Your sword is so gaudy. You talk like you're from the Edo Period, but it's Reiwa right now."

Your noisy and picky self just goes off on Ken the Samurai. He skulks off, defeated by your noisy and picky words.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>mouth</radical> is <radical>showy</radical> so it makes everybody around you <kanji>rowdy</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Your mouth is showy because it's covered in grills and bright red lipstick. People get rowdy because you're a celebrity and your showy mouth is your signature look, and everyone's so excited to see your mouth in person.
data.reading_mnemonic: Everyone is getting <kanji>rowdy</kanji> so you get in your <reading>ca</reading>r (<ja>か</ja>) to escape.
data.reading_hint: As you drive away in your car you flash that signature mouth at them one more time, and you can see them getting even more rowdy.
